description: It’s a simple idea: strip CO2 from the air and use it to produce carbon-neutral fuel. But can it work on an industrial scale?
og_fields.og:description: It’s a simple idea: strip CO2 from the air and use it to produce carbon-neutral fuel. But can it work on an industrial scale?
og_fields.og:title: How Bill Gates aims to clean up the planet
text:
It’s nothing much to look at, but the tangle of pipes, pumps, tanks, reactors, chimneys and ducts on a messy industrial estate outside the logging town of Squamish in western Canada could just provide the fix to stop the world tipping into runaway climate change and substitute dwindling supplies of conventional fuel.
It could also make Harvard superstar physicist David Keith, Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates and oil sands magnate Norman Murray Edwards more money than they could ever dream of.
The idea is grandiose yet simple: decarbonise the global economy by extracting global-warming carbon dioxide (CO2) straight from the air, using arrays of giant fans and patented chemical whizzery; and then use the gas to make clean, carbon-neutral synthetic diesel and petrol to drive the world’s ships, planes and trucks.
The hope is that the combination of direct air capture (DAC), water electrolysis and fuels synthesis used to produce liquid hydrocarbon fuels can be made to work at a global scale, for little more than it costs to extract and sell fossil fuel today. This would revolutionise the world’s transport industry, which emits nearly one-third of total climate-changing emissions. It would be the equivalent of mechanising photosynthesis.
The individual technologies may not be new, but their combination at an industrial scale would be groundbreaking. Carbon Engineering, the company set up in 2009 by leading geoengineer Keith, with money from Gates and Murray, has constructed a prototype plant, installed large fans, and has been extracting around one tonne of pure CO2 every day for a year. At present it is released back into the air.
But Carbon Engineering (CE) has just passed another milestone. Working with California energy company Greyrock, it has now begun directly synthesising a mixture of petrol and diesel, using only CO2 captured from the air and hydrogen split from water with clean electricity – a process they call Air to Fuels (A2F).
“A2F is a potentially game-changing technology, which if successfully scaled up will allow us to harness cheap, intermittent renewable electricity to drive synthesis of liquid fuels that are compatible with modern infrastructure and engines,” says Geoff Holmes of CE. “This offers an alternative to biofuels and a complement to electric vehicles in the effort to displace fossil fuels from transportation.”
Synthetic fuels have been made from CO2 and H2 before, on a small scale. “But,” Holmes adds, “we think our pilot plant is the first instance of Air to Fuels where all the equipment has large-scale industrial precedent, and thus gives real indication of commercial performance and viability, and leads directly to scale-up and deployment.”
The next step is to raise the money, scale up and then commercialise the process using low-carbon electricity like solar PV (photovoltaics). Company publicity envisages massive walls of extractor fans sited outside cities and on non-agricultural land, supplying CO2 for fuel synthesis, and eventually for direct sequestration.
“A2F is the future,” says Holmes, “because it needs 100 times less land and water than biofuels, and can be scaled up and sited anywhere. But for it to work, it will have to reduce costs to little more than it costs to extract oil today, and – even trickier – persuade countries to set a global carbon price.”
Meanwhile, 4,500 miles away, in a large blue shed on a small industrial estate in the South Yorkshire coalfield outside Sheffield, the UK Carbon Capture and Storage Research Centre (UKCCSRC) is experimenting with other ways to produce negative emissions.
Critics say these technologies are unfeasible. Not producing the emissions in the first place would be much cleverer
The UKCCSRC is what remains of Britain’s official foray into carbon capture and storage (CCS), which David Cameron had backed strongly until 2015. £1bn was ringfenced for a competition between large companies to extract CO2 from coal and gas plants and then store it, possibly in old North Sea gas wells. But the plan unravelled as austerity bit, and the UK’s only running CCS pilot plant, at Ferrybridge power station, was abandoned.
The Sheffield laboratory is funded by £2.7m of government money and run by Sheffield University. It is researching different fuels, temperatures, solvents and heating speeds to best capture the CO2 for the next generation of CCS plants, and is capturing 50 tonnes of CO2 a year. And because Britain is phasing out coal power stations, the focus is on achieving negative emissions by removing and storing CO2 emitted from biomass plants, which burn pulverised wood. As the wood has already absorbed carbon while it grows, it is more or less carbon-neutral when burned. If linked to a carbon capture plant, it theoretically removes carbon from the atmosphere.
Known as Beccs (bioenergy with carbon capture and storage), this negative emissions technology is seen as vital if the UK is to meet its long-term climate target of an 80% cut in emissions at 1990 levels by 2050, according to UKCCSRC director Professor Jon Gibbins. The plan, he says, is to capture emissions from clusters of major industries, such as refineries and steelworks in places like Teesside, to reduce the costs of transporting and storing it underground.
“Direct air capture is no substitute for using conventional CCS,” says Gibbins. “Cutting emissions from existing sources at the scale of millions of tonnes a year, to stop the CO2 getting into the air in the first place, is the first priority.
“The best use for all negative emission technologies is to offset emissions that are happening now – paid for by the emitters, or by the fossil fuel suppliers. We need to get to net zero emissions before the sustainable CO2 emissions are used up. This is estimated at around 1,000bn tonnes, or around 20-30 years of global emissions based on current trends,” he says. “Having to go to net negative emissions is obviously unfair and might well prove an unfeasible burden for a future global society already burdened by climate change.”
The challenge is daunting. Worldwide manmade emissions must be brought to “net zero” no later than 2090, says the UN’s climate body, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). That means balancing the amount of carbon released by humans with an equivalent amount sequestered or offset, or buying enough carbon credits to make up the difference.
But that will not be enough. To avoid runaway climate change, emissions must then become “net negative”, with more carbon being removed than emitted. Many countries, including the UK, assume that negative emissions will be deployed at a large scale. But only a handful of CCS and pilot negative-emission plants are running anywhere in the world, and debate still rages over which, if any, technologies should be employed. (A prize of $25m put up by Richard Branson in 2007 to challenge innovators to find a commercially viable way to remove at least 1bn tonnes of atmospheric CO2 a year for 10 years, and keep it out, has still not been claimed – possibly because the public is uncertain about geoengineering.)
The achilles heel of all negative emission technologies is cost. Government policy units assume that they will become economically viable, but the best hope of Carbon Engineering and other direct air extraction companies is to get the price down to $100 a tonne from the current $600. Even then, to remove just 1% of global emissions would cost around $400bn a year, and would need to be continued for ever. Storing the CO2 permanently would cost extra.
Critics say that these technologies are unfeasible. Not using the fossil fuel and not producing the emissions in the first place would be much cleverer than having to find end-of-pipe solutions, say Professor Kevin Anderson, deputy director of the Tyndall Centre for Climate Change Research, and Glen Peters, research director at the Centre for International Climate Research (Cicero) in Norway.
In a recent article in the journal Science, the two climate scientists said they were not opposed to research on negative emission technologies, but thought the world should proceed on the premise that they will not work at scale. Not to do so, they said, would be a “moral hazard par excellence”.
Instead, governments are relying on these technologies to remove hundreds of millions of tonnes of carbon from the atmosphere. “It is breathtaking,” says Anderson. “By the middle of the century, many of the models assume as much removal of CO2 from the atmosphere by negative emission technologies as is absorbed naturally today by all of the world’s oceans and plants combined. They are not an insurance policy; they are a high-risk gamble with tomorrow’s generations, particularly those living in poor and climatically vulnerable communities, set to pay the price if our high-stakes bet fails to deliver as promised.” According to Anderson, “The beguiling appeal of relying on future negative emission technologies is that they delay the need for stringent and politically challenging policies today – they pass the buck for reducing carbon on to future generations. But if these Dr Strangelove technologies fail to deliver at the planetary scale envisaged, our own children will be forced to endure the consequences of rapidly rising temperatures and a highly unstable climate.”
Kris Milkowski, business development manager at the UKCCSRC, says: “Negative emissions technology is unavoidable and here to stay. We are simply not moving [to cut emissions] fast enough. If we had an endless pile of money, we could potentially go totally renewable energy. But that transition cannot happen overnight. This, I fear, is the only large-scale solution.”

[{u'author': u'maqimu', u'text': u'A fella named Bill Gammage wrote a book which is worth reading. Ties in nicely with all the water management issues we're not allowed to comment on. Whatever you think of his conclusions, definitely food for thought:

We have so much to learn with respect to caring for this country.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518104187000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16474867', u'id': u'111975675', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Julian Robinson', u'text': u'It will horrify governments and departments, but the time has come to freeze. We have little enough undeveloped land left, and even that is heavily compromised by fragmentation and other effects. So it is time to say that cities have to live within their current boundaries, unlogged forests (if there are any) will remain so, agricultural land can not expand and must be improved, no more tree clearing, and generally any changes to land use will be positive for the environment, not negative. Farmed forestry can continue but no new deforestation.
This will, of course, mean stopping population growth as soon as we can't fit within our current footprint, which in turn means limited immigration. It also means examination of how to successfully run a non-expanding economy. The fossil fuel companies have spent hundreds of millions of dollars to turn the neutral scientific fact of global warming into a divisive "wedge" issue for hardcore conservatives and a lot of good people have been fooled by this professional PR campaign.
And our politicians are accustomed to the art of compromise. But we cannot compromise with physics; Earth has a tremendous energy imbalance right now. (It is more than equal to exploding 400,000 Hiroshima size atomic bombs every day, 365 days a year). That is how much extra energy the Earth is absorbing daily. Unless we get atmospheric CO2 concentration below 350ppm the planet will continue to heat dangerously.
As we watch temperature records falling around the world we might ask where are we now, long before feeling the full effects of a rise in temperature of just over 1 degree C, due to lags in the system.
We are seeing numerous impacts catching many scientists by surprise with how soon they are occurring. In 2014 two independent teams of scientists reported that the West Antarctic Ice Sheet is likely irreversibly retreating. 3.3 meters of sea level rise equivalent of ice there is being destabilized by warming oceans and energy is going into the net melting of ice all over the planet. 
The paleoclimate record shows that increasing global temperature by just 1.5-2 degrees C commits the system to an eventual 6-9m of sea level rise.
Corals may not survive this century of warming and acidifying oceans, and droughts and floods linked to global warming—and conflict linked to those droughts—are already causing four countries to face famine.
Because of the decades to millennial long lag between a climate forcing and our feeling the effect, due to the thermal inertia of the ocean and response time of the ice sheets, the effects we are feeling now are largely just the beginning of the result of emissions from the 20th century. And emissions have been increasing steadily for decades.
We are also seeing numerous amplifying feedbacks: loss of albedo (heat reflectivity) from ice melt, permafrost melt, methane release and massive wildfires; the Earth is starting to wrest any possible further human control of the climate away.
We're about out of time on this, if not already, and leaders are not only still acting as if this is not a planetary emergency, but some are acting as if there isn’t a problem at all.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1517890824000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'lags in the system', u'effect': u'as we watch temperature records falling around the world we might ask where are we now long before feeling the full effects of a rise in temperature of just over 1 degree c'}, {u'cause': u'the thermal inertia of the ocean and response time of the ice sheets', u'effect': u'our feeling the effect'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'id': u'111837525', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'moneytherootofevil', u'text': u'I agree mate, they are truely immoral fools.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1517890289000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14041826', u'in_reply_to': u'111837138', u'id': u'111837391', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'esmereldabollocks', u'text': u'I think your comment should be essential reading for anyone living in Australia.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1517884566000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14985262', u'in_reply_to': u'111832630', u'id': u'111835734', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Friarbird', u'text': u'Your mob STILL don't do irony, then.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1517902586000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12641156', u'in_reply_to': u'111840677', u'id': u'111841118', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'moneytherootofevil', u'text': u'The ordinary people that could get a say are influenced by Murdoch’s 70% of power which gives us the written word according to him! The then Baird government’s determination to guard the interests of the private sector is nowhere more obvious than in its approach to those who protest against coal and coal seam gas developments.
Legislation passedincreased tenfold the fines faced by protesters to $5500 and provided for jail for up to seven years for “unlawful aggravated entry” to mine sites. The new laws also gave police new search and seizure powers and allowed them greater latitude under “move on powers” to break up demonstrations.
“This changed laws in place since 1901,” the chief executive and principal solicitor with the state’s Environmental Defenders Office, Sue Higginson, says.

description: Public should be given a greater say on development plans, experts say
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Public should be given a greater say on development plans, experts say
og_fields.og:title: 'Everything is made into a political issue': rethinking Australia's environmental laws
text:
Environmental lawyers and academics have called for a comprehensive rethink on how Australia’s natural landscapes are protected, warning that short-term politics is infecting decision-making and suggesting that the public be given a greater say on development plans. 
The Australian Panel of Experts on Environmental Law has launched a blueprint for a new generation of environment laws and the creation of independent agencies with the power and authority to ensure they are enforced. The panel of 14 senior legal figures says this is motivated by the need to systematically address ecological challenges including falling biodiversity, the degradation of productive rural land, the intensification of coastal and city development and the threat of climate change. 
Murray Wilcox QC, a former federal court judge, said the blueprint was a serious attempt to improve a system that was shutting the public out of the decision-making process and failing to properly assess the impact of large-scale development proposals. 
“We found the standard of management of the environment is poor because everything is made into a political issue,” Wilcox said. “Nothing happens until it becomes desperate. 
“We need a non-political body of significant prestige to report on what is happening and have the discretion to act.” 
The legal review, developed over several years and quietly released in 2017, resulted in 57 recommendations. It was suggested by the Places You Love alliance, a collection of about 40 environmental groups that was created to counter a failed bid to set up a “one-stop shop” for environmental approvals by leaving it to the states. The panel undertook the work on the understanding it would be independent and not a piece of activism. 
Its work helped inform a motion passed by 250 Labor branches calling on the Labor leader, Bill Shorten, to put stronger national environmental laws and the introduction of an independent watchdog at the centre of his election pitch.
The Australian Panel of Experts on Environmental Law convener, Rob Fowler, an environmental lawyer for more than 40 years and adjunct professor at the University of South Australia, said a key finding was that cooperative federalism – different tiers of government working together to solve common problems – had not worked in protecting the environment. 
“It’s slow-moving, unwieldy and leads to compromised outcomes,” he said. 
Fowler said devolving responsibility for environmental protection to the states had been popular with politicians, having been proposed by both the Gillard Labor government and the Coalition under Tony Abbott, but not the public. The 2014 constitutional values survey conducted by Griffith University found nearly 45% of respondents believed Canberra should be solely responsible for protecting the environment. Just 16% said it should be left to the states.
He said the body of expert opinion was strongly in favour of the commonwealth taking responsibility. The panel believed a future government should introduce a mechanism that required states to act in line with plans and strategies developed by a commonwealth environment commission. If they failed to comply, they could be overridden.
Wilcox, who before becoming a judge was president of the Australian Conservation Foundation from 1979 to 1984, said creating an environment commission was the panel’s most important recommendation, likening it to the Reserve Bank. “It hopefully would involve people of considerable ability and achievement,” he said.
It would develop both national strategies and regional plans to protect biodiversity, and oversee a system of environmental data monitoring, collection, auditing and reporting. Where it did not do the monitoring itself, it would be required to ensure the work was done to a higher standard than currently, backed by federal funding.
Wilcox said the national Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act, which was introduced by the Howard government in 1999, was an advance at the time but now “well and truly out of date”.
The environment minister, Josh Frydenberg, has said the existing act continues to be the best mechanism for the federal government to protect the most important and sensitive matters. The opposition environment spokesman, Tony Burke, said the push to introduce national laws would be considered at ALP conference this year, and he was consulting about updating the act.
Wilcox said the public should have a greater say in response to developments. He said state planning systems were good at handling small neighbourhood development problems but larger proposals tended to be “waved through by governments mesmerised by the corporate dollars”. 
He cited the hotel and casino complex being developed at Barangaroo in Sydney. “Anything that did come out about that was released for political reasons. That story just applies again and again and again.
 “If you believe in a democracy, then you believe ordinary people should be encouraged to get in and have a say, and that’s not the case at the moment. If anything the opposite is the case.”

There is at least an order of magnitude difference to account for to suggest modern estimates on Aran, which gets some of the highest waves in present day climate from long-fetch high-powered mid-latitude N. Atlantic storm systems and where the cliff height is nearer 10 metres (I have been there myself), are a useful and useable analogue here. Meteorologically, fetch for Aran is likely substantially longer than for the location of the Boulders in question (I type this as the synoptic situation is a 4000Km straight run of SWrlys at 80-120Kph), arguably allowing more energetic ocean waves than meteorologically attainable in the subtropical location in question (wave energy being a function of wind speed, duration, and fetch), even with the strongest hurricanes...
I would note that Michael Wehner’s currently unanswered comment provides published evidence that we can expect hurricanes to increase in intensity with warming SSTs at most 10%. This provides a potential upper bound on storm intensity and size from which to infer meteorologically possible wave characteristics. Perhaps ancient storms were stronger still, but if so, the mechanisms would need elucidating with supporting references...
etc.

Awesome.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1517868482000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12717079', u'id': u'111826563', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'In a 2016 paper NASA’s former lead climate scientist James Hansen said that in the previous interglacial, at temperatures less than 1 degree C above today, there’s evidence of superstorms which moved boulders 10 times the size current storms move.

description: Boulders the size of houses and weighing 100 tonnes or more had been lifted up and bulldozed along cliff tops
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Boulders the size of houses and weighing 100 tonnes or more had been lifted up and bulldozed along cliff tops
og_fields.og:title: Weatherwatch: storm waves that can roll great slabs of rock
text:
Winter storms battering the British Isles are more powerful than often assumed. The stormy winter of 2013-14 along the west coast of Ireland produced waves so powerful they tore great slabs of rock out of coastlines and shoved them inland. Among those boulders was a 620-tonne colossus, equivalent to more than three blue whales, which was shoved several feet inshore, setting a new world record for the largest boulder ever known to have been moved by storm waves.
Scientists from Williams College, in Massachusetts, examined photos of shorelines before and after the violent storms and discovered many coastal sites had been completely rearranged. Boulders the size of houses and weighing 100 tonnes or more had been lifted up by waves, tilted over and bulldozed along cliff tops or shorelines, up to 220 metres (722ft) inland and up to 29 metres (95ft) above high water. It was a shocking revelation – previously it was thought that only tsunamis had the power to move such huge rocks.
The study published in Earth-Science Reviews also revealed that the storm waves had created many of the boulders by tearing the rocks out of cliffs, or peeling them out of rocky shores.

description: While the hole over Antarctica has been closing, the protective ozone is thinning at the lower latitudes, where the sunlight is stronger and billions of people live
headline: O
og_fields.og:description: While the hole over Antarctica has been closing, the protective ozone is thinning at the lower latitudes, where the sunlight is stronger and billions of people live
og_fields.og:title: Ozone layer not recovering over populated areas, scientists warn
text:
The ozone layer that protects people from the sun’s ultraviolet radiation is not recovering over most highly populated regions, scientists warned on Tuesday.
The greatest losses in ozone occurred over Antarctica but the hole there has been closing since the chemicals causing the problem were banned by the Montreal protocol. But the ozone layer wraps the entire Earth and new research has revealed it is thinning in the lower stratosphere over the non-polar areas. 
Reduced protection from cancer-causing UV rays is especially concerning towards the equator, where sunlight is stronger and billions of people live. The reason for the falling ozone at lower latitudes is not known, though scientists suspect a chemical used in paint stripper and a change in atmospheric circulation caused by climate change.
“The study is in lower to mid latitudes, where the sunshine is more intense, so that is not a good signal for skin cancer,” said Prof Joanna Haigh at Imperial College London, a member of the international research team. “It is a worry. Although the Montreal protocol has done what we wanted it to do in the upper stratosphere, there are other things going on that we don’t understand.”
Anna Jones, an atmospheric chemist at the British Antarctic Survey and not involved in the new study, said: “To identify what action might be needed to prevent further decreases, it is extremely important to understand what is causing the observed downward trend.” Scientists say budget threats to US satellite monitoring programmes must be reversed.
The new research, published in the journal Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics, carefully combined measurements of atmospheric ozone from 11 different datasets to produce a record of the last 30 years. It looked at ozone levels between the 60th parallels, an area that ranges from Scandinavia, Russia and Alaska in the north to the tip of South America. (London is 51 deg N, Sydney is 34 deg S and New York city is at 41 deg N.)
The stratosphere stretches from 10km above the Earth to 50km and ozone is slowly rising in the upper stratosphere, back towards the levels seen before CFC chemicals caused their damage.
But in the lower stratosphere, when there is the most ozone, levels are falling. Overall, the effects balance out but this means the ozone layer over the area studied is remaining in its depleted state. 
The cause of the decline is unknown but might be the result of global warming. Ozone is produced by chemical reactions in the atmosphere over the tropics and then distributed towards the poles world by large air circulation currents. But warming trends could be strengthening these currents, moving more ozone to the poles and leaving less at lower latitudes.
Another suspect is so-called “very short lived substances” (VSLS) - industrial chemicals that destroy ozone. It was thought they broke down too quickly to reach the stratosphere, but that may need to be re-examined. 
Research published in July by Ryan Hossaini, at Lancaster University, UK, and colleagues showed that levels of a key VSLS, called dicholoromethane and used in paint stripper and aerosol sprays, have doubled in the last decade. It is not banned by the Montreal protocol and little is known about where it is leaking from or why emissions have risen so rapidly. 
William Ball, an atmospheric scientist at ETH Zurich university in Switzerland, who led the new research, said: “The finding of declining low-latitude ozone is surprising, since our current best atmospheric circulation models do not predict this effect. Very short-lived substances could be the missing factor in these models.”
Hossaini welcomed the “important” new study, but he argues that the current concentrations of VSLS in the atmosphere are too low to explain the falling ozone in the lower stratosphere. 
“This work clearly highlights there are still unanswered questions regarding the drivers of long-term changes in stratospheric ozone,” he said. “The implications of the downward ozone trend from the perspective of surface UV and health need to be evaluated as a pressing matter.”

description: Move makes it the largest university fund in the UK to ditch all coal, oil and gas holdings, following a long student campaign
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Move makes it the largest university fund in the UK to ditch all coal, oil and gas holdings, following a long student campaign
og_fields.og:title: Edinburgh University divests from all fossil fuels
text:
The University of Edinburgh is dumping all its fossil fuel investments, making it the largest UK university endowment fund to be completely free of all coal, oil and gas holdings.
The decision was announced on Monday and followed a long student campaign. More than 60 UK universities have now divested from fossil fuels, with the University of Sussex the latest to make the move. 
Most existing fossil fuel reserves cannot be burned without causing dangerous climate change, and proponents of divestment argue this makes fossil fuel companies bad investments on both ethical and financial grounds. The risk to investments is taken seriously at the highest level, including the Bank of England, World Bank and the G20’s financial stability board, and many major investment firms have also divested.
The University of Edinburgh decided in 2015 to divest from the most polluting companies – those involved in coal and tar sands – but stopped short of full divestment. But now the university will sell its final £6.3m of fossil fuel holdings, in the companies Total, BG Group and Atlas Copco.
The University of Edinburgh’s £1bn endowment fund is the third largest in the UK, behind Cambridge and Oxford. Those universities have only committed to divest from coal and tar sands to date.
Tara Wight, campaigner at People and Planet Edinburgh and a PhD student, said: “We are thrilled that Edinburgh University has finally realised the importance of divestment, and decided to match their investment portfolio with the environmentally friendly image they present to the public.”
Prof Charlie Jeffery, senior vice-principal at the University of Edinburgh, said: “I’m very proud of the university’s decision. Climate change is one of the world’s biggest challenges. Over the past few years, we have thought hard about how to respond to that challenge. This change in our investment strategy is a vital step on that journey.”
A university spokesman said Edinburgh had invested more than £150m in low carbon technology, climate-related research and businesses that directly benefit the environment since 2010 and would become carbon neutral by 2040.
In January, New York City announced it would sell $5bn of fossil fuel investments held by the city’s pension funds. The value of investment funds around the world committed to selling off fossil fuel assets is at least $5tn.

The snow drought of 2015, described in the Guardian article and the study it was based on, was beyond anything seen for 500 years.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518497375000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'112130965', u'id': u'112153344', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'You describe my reply to your claim that the Guardian article you linked to on Sierra Nevada snowpack as "full of over-though, run on sentences" which seems to refer to the fact that I information in some detail and acknowledged where that information came. I don't think I'm overthinking but I do think that you should do a bit more thinking.
"Try not to over think this stuff".
There's nothing wrong with thinking particularly about the evidence presented.
"The claim is that snowpack is shrinking due to global warming per the Guardian."
The October 2015 article in the guardian that you linked to claims that the spring snowpack of that year had shrunk to a record low level not seen for 500 years.
"So you are saying that since data on the AHRO chart doesn't go past 2011, it is irrelevant to the context of AGW" (anthropogenic global warming) creating a declining snowpack trend???"
No. I didn't talk about a declining snowpack trend and neither did the Guardian article that you linked to. It talked about a record low snowpack in the spring of 2015. The reason the data on the chart reproduced by ARHO is irrelevant to the reality of the decline to that record low is that decline occurred after 2011 as shown in figure 1 top chart 1930-2015 on the first page of Balmecheri et al (2015).
"None of the 60 years prior" to 2015 "are relevant?"
The relevance of the 60 years prior to 2015 and the 1,440 years prior to them all shown in Balmecheri et al, is that they demonstrate that the last snowpack low of that extent occurred 500 years ago and that weather extremes of that extent were rare in the pre-industrial climate.  "The point Wally, is that there is no multi-decadal declining snowpack trend in the Sierra Nevada, regardless of what the Guardian would have us believe."
The Guardian article on snowpack in Sierra Nevada made no mention of a declining snowpack trend. It made mention instead of a record low snowpack for the spring of 2015.

I'll give you the benefit of the doubt and presume that you didn't notice the three words "on its own" in the text that you copied from KingInYellow's response! That may seem like nitpicking to you but such details and nuance are crucial in science. Your failure to respond specifically and directly to points made actually prevents serious debate.
Returning to the question you posed about how AGW made hurricane Harvey worse........
There is one element of science that I suspect you haven't grapsed: the crucial importance of deductive and inductive reasoning. This is one element that requires a better understanding of science than most bloggers possess.... and it is one of the key reasons why so many amateur "skeptics" don't "get" the science of climate change.
In short, there are some things that are so well established in science that it is safe to draw conclusions about them without data to back it up. The concept that a warming world will make tropical storms more damaging, based on sound empirical physics, is one of them. This is because higher SST will make storms more powerful, higher atmospheric temperature will increase the rainfall associated with storms and rising sea level will increase inundation due to storm surges.
It is unlikely that scientists will ever be in a position to say that a specific storm was caused by AGW, but there is sufficient evidence, backed up by empirical physics, to conclude that AGW has contributed to the damage caused by a particular storm for the reasons stated above.
Of course it is infinitely better to be able to dot the "i"'s and cross the "t"'s by establishing a statistical relationship, but this requires huge amounts of data, given the huge natural variability that is inherent to weather. The bottom line is that the real experts know that if we wait for this statistical confirmation before acting the problem will be far worse and much more difficult to resolve. In the meantime, they use other statistical approaches, as described in the articles you linked to.
I appreciate that this will not sit well with a "FUD" such as yourself, but it is the reality of the science of the real world.', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518463050000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'higher sst will make storms more powerful temperature increase will increase inundation due to storm surges', u'effect': u'this is'}, {u'cause': u'storm surges', u'effect': u'inundation'}, {u'cause': u'agw', u'effect': u'a specific storm'}, {u'cause': u'a particular storm for the reasons stated above', u'effect': u'the damage'}], u'author_id': u'16473314', u'in_reply_to': u'112131958', u'id': u'112140478', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RightSaid', u'text': u'It is false that "There are no deniers" if we take that statement in the most literal sense. BQSTART
Record rainfall amounts were recorded during Hurricane Harvey in the Houston, Texas, area, leading to widespread flooding. We analyze observed precipitation from the Global Historical Climatology Network with a covariate-based extreme value statistical analysis, accounting for both the external influence of global warming and the internal influence of El Niño–Southern Oscillation. We find that human-induced climate change likely increased the chances of the observed precipitation accumulations during Hurricane Harvey in the most affected areas of Houston by a factor of at least 3.5. Further, precipitation accumulations in these areas were likely increased by at least 18.8% (best estimate of 37.7%), which is larger than the 6–7% associated with an attributable warming of 1∘C in the Gulf of Mexico and Clausius-Clapeyron scaling. In a Granger causality sense, these statements provide lower bounds on the impact of climate change and motivate further attribution studies using dynamical climate models.
BQEND

What parts of this article, which is largely based on the above report, are exaggerations of the dangers of climate change?', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518428546000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'a 3 degrees rise above pre - industrial global temperatures', u'effect': u'to occur'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'112102347', u'id': u'112112431', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'guest90', u'text': u'Just to point out: a tax on pollution is not going to work for one major reason. That reason is that fossil fuels are heavily subsidised by a range of supports.
BQSTART
..World Trade Organization’s (WTO) definition of a subsidy which includes: fiscal support, such as direct spending by governments, tax breaks and income or price support; domestic, regional (EU) and international public finance through grants, loans, equity and guarantees; and investment by state-owned enterprises.
BQEND
Considering that just in Europe, their have been multiple pledges to phase out subsidies under the G7 and G20, with the latest one is to phase out 'inefficient' subsidies by 2020 - and none of these pledges have not amounted to action: it only says one thing; fossil fuels are not able to pay for themselves.
This means that rather than some kind of benign 'fee & dividend' scheme being easily slapped on the price of petrol at a local filling station; this industry actually has much more serious problems.
The EU spends
€112 billion per year on fossil fuel subsidies, and that is
not accounting for the EU ETS scheme which interestingly delivered a total of over €25 billion to the coal industry in cashable, 'unused emission allowances'; as well as similar amounts to heavy polluters such as cement.
So to say these industries need to be kept in check with a tax is to miss the point - if they were simply priced at a level that reflected the true costs involved we would not be so eager to spend all our money on them. To underline this, the cost of oil for the past few years has been quite low, at around $50 dollars a barrel; but this has meant that no-one makes any money - and only recently has the price crept up closer to $100 dollars a barrel where producers actually start to see a return on the production costs sunk into the product, its transport, bonuses and other payments. Even Russia and the Middle East don't see much profit at $50 dollars, although
fracking has never made money at any price, at all. It has
now cost almost $300 billion in debt (domestic debt; so QE - not as bad as owing to a foreign country, but still), roughly equating to about double the cost at the pump.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518428219000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17280722', u'in_reply_to': u'112103186', u'id': u'112112193', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'I asked you which media articles you were talking about where the dangers of climate and climate change had been exaggerated.

It was not about the dangers of climate and climate change let alone the exaggeration thereof.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518419927000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'112102347', u'id': u'112108166', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'I didn't put quotation marks around "extinction", "wildfires", "droughts" and "etc" - a words you used in the same sentence with "epic floods".', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518418409000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'112102493', u'id': u'112107887', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Aldous0rwell', u'text': u'It's too late for humans to become smarter. Here, in Ventura County, in California, we've had one (significant) rainstorm since last April. The excessive heat and drought of the summer and then fall and winter months led to the biggest fire in modern CA history hitting my county in December. When rain DID come, it came as a flood in one night and killed my dear friend Peter Fleurat in a mudslide at the beginning of January. One of the only positive things I could think of during Peter's memorial was that the grasses and flowers in the burn zone were germinating, coming back. Life was finding a way.
And then we've had no rain since. During this dry month, the native grasses have withered and died. The insects that need them have nothing, the birds that feed on those insects starve or migrate far away. Our climate has become that of Baja - this is not a "drought" - this is climate change. All the flora and fauna in our chaparral hills is now unsupportable. Most of it will be dead in a matter of decades, save for the opportunistic weeds which can flourish anywhere - but the species adapted to the Mediterranean climate will be gone.
Besides, stupidity is not the problem: greed is. No one wants to pay higher gas taxes or risk losing their oil-rig drilling job for a global problem that only periodically affects them for now. Our foot is on the accellerator and we are already flying off the cliff. Now I'm just waiting for the crash.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518413925000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the excessive heat and drought of the summer and then fall and winter months', u'effect': u'the biggest fire in modern ca history hitting my county in december'}], u'author_id': u'14173421', u'id': u'112107068', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'paulchevin', u'text': u'Sorry, it's past my bedtime, but I've just taken a quick look at the Guardian articles you claim are exaggerating the dangers of climate change.
One of them isn't about climate change caused by greenhouse gases and the others I've looked at are not even remotely "alarmist". In fact, a 2m rise in sea level for 3 Celsius of warming may well be on the conservative side!
Regarding the article about Sierra Nevada snowpack, you just haven't read it carefully enough. The article points out that it isn't yet clear whether the long term impact of climate change will be less snow because of warming or more snow because of extra moisture. Also, the data you have linked to is only the instrumental record from 1959 to 2011, whereas the recent record low was in 2015 and the paper described uses proxy data to look as far back as 1500.
"The authors found that this current episode was unsurpassed in the record and exceeded the 95% confidence interval for a 500 year period."
So this isn't alarmist at all. Indeed, all it shows is how poor your attention to detail is! It's also worth pointing out that the author Professor John Abraham is an actively researching climate scientist, so it would hardly be in his interests to use "doctored pictures".

Climate scientists consider future variables such as declining Northern Hemisphere high latitude summer insolation in 50,000 years time. They also consider the consequences of various CO2 emission scenarios. They do consider the possibility of future unknown variables such as bollide impacts which they know have happened in the past but don't know when and if they'll happen in the near future. As scientist they don't have a belief structure when it comes to reality but instead base what they know on evidence. Therefore they don't ignore any study or data that suggest that something contrary to their belief system, as they don't have a belief system that pertains to such studies and such data.

Don't blame meteorologists for your lack of understanding of the reality and stochasticity.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518345211000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'111941105', u'id': u'112073966', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'paulchevin', u'text': u'I can only presume that you have now conceded the point that you were wrong to describe a false claim about coral reefs as "science". In science, such details matter a lot and I make no apology at all for picking you up on it.
Context is everything in science and the central theme of your argument on this thread has been that there is "alarmism". You said:
"Extreme alarmist says "Climate change is our most serious issue now, and if we don't stop burning fossil fuels, extinction, epic flooding, wildfires, droughts etc. will continue to kill people."
Although a scientist would be unlikely to use the word "epic", there is little doubt, based on both evidence and empirical physics, that the warmer the Earth gets, the worse these problems will become. Clearly, mankind can't just stop burning fossil fuels overnight, but the threat if we don't move away from them as quickly as possible is all too real..... especially when population is rising rapidly.
The difficulty scientists face is that it is hard to quantify the extent to which the above are already being exacerbated by our warming world, but that does NOT mean that the threat from them is imagined or overstated and most sensible people would surely use the precautionary principle as sufficient basis for urgent action.
There are, of course, those who overstate the likely consequences of climate change, but they do NOT represent the scientific community and their claims CANNOT be used to suggest that the science itself is alarmist. 
"To use your terminology....UTTER RUBBISH!"
Let's not forget that I used that phrase in response to your baseless claim that "only the evidence that supports your assertions matter". Real scientists don't work that way!
Just go back and take a look at the context in which you presented your links. It was in an exchange that you started suggesting alarmism and in response to this paper that is sound rather than "alarmist" (and represents the views of most climate scientists, as far as I can tell):
http://www.pnas.org/content/114/39/10315.full#F1
"Yet no one in the science community will discredit Al Gore."
What Gore did in his original work was to do what politicians tend to do.... use the "worst case scenario". There are many critiques of "The Inconvenient Truth" around on the internet. The scientific community did not ask Gore to make his film and the scientific community did not endorse it as an accurate reflection of the science. However, in an era when right-wing politicians across the world are using false and misleading claims to delay action to reduce emissions, I suspect that many scientists feel they have no choice but to foster links with political leaders and other public figures who openly campaign for action.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518342586000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16473314', u'in_reply_to': u'112066558', u'id': u'112072177', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'In 1896 a suspicious junk was seen it the Baltic.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518340804000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'111925450', u'id': u'112071109', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'You're telling a bloke who says that CO2 at over 400 ppm is an insignificant trace gas in terms of greenhouse effect that CH4 at 170 ppb is the real problem.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518340690000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'111921493', u'id': u'112071039', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"If anything, using sea level rise as a cross-check, the former period looks to be the period with the higher radiative imbalance."
Comparing the sea level rise of the former period of deglacial warming over 10,000 years to the current sea level rise over the 150 years of current warming is no comparing "apples to apples" both temporally and in terms of the cryosphere being impacted by the warming.
During the last deglacial warming the rise in sea level due to melting f the cryosphere lagged the rise in temperature by 200 years. As the current warming has only been underway for 150 years it's too early to see any great impact on the cryosphere and consequent meltwater contribution to sea level rise.
The cryosphere of 17,000 years ago was very different and much larger than the cryosphere of the current period. Hence it's meltwater response would not be the same as today's smaller and more poleward cryosphere.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518335987000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'111920973', u'id': u'112069214', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'Every morning after a good nights sleep, I wake up from dreams. description: Dana Nuccitelli: A new paper shows that climate myths consistently fail critical thinking tests
headline: m
og_fields.og:description: Dana Nuccitelli: A new paper shows that climate myths consistently fail critical thinking tests
og_fields.og:title: Humans need to become smarter thinkers to beat climate denial | Dana Nuccitelli
text:
Climate myths are often contradictory – it’s not warming, though it’s warming because of the sun, and really it’s all just an ocean cycle – but they all seem to share one thing in common: logical fallacies and reasoning errors. 
John Cook, Peter Ellerton, and David Kinkead have just published a paper in Environmental Research Letters in which they examined 42 common climate myths and found that every single one demonstrates fallacious reasoning. For example, the authors made a video breaking down the logical flaws in the myth ‘climate changed naturally in the past so current climate change is natural.’
Cook has previously published research on using ‘misconception-based learning’ to dislodge climate myths from peoples’ brains and replace them with facts, and beating denial by inoculating people against misinformers’ tricks. The idea is that when people are faced with a myth and a competing fact, the fact will more easily win out if the fallacy underpinning the myth is revealed. In fact, these concepts of misconception-based learning and inoculation against myths were the basis of the free online Denial101x course developed by Cook and colleagues.
The new paper published today suggests an even more proactive approach to defeating myths. If people can learn to implement a simple six-step critical thinking process, they’ll be able to evaluate whether climate-related claims are valid.
Step 1: Identify the claim being made. For example, the most popular contrarian argument: “Earth’s climate has changed naturally in the past, so current climate change is natural.”
Step 2: Construct the argument by identifying the premises leading to that conclusion. In this case, the first premise is that Earth’s climate has changed in the past through natural processes, and the second premise is that the climate is currently changing. So far, so good.
Step 3: Determine whether the argument is deductive, meaning that it starts out with a general statement and reaches a definitive conclusion. In our case, ‘current climate change is natural’ qualifies as a definitive conclusion.
Step 4: Check the argument for validity; does the conclusion follow from the premises? In our example, it doesn’t follow that current climate change must be natural because climate changed naturally in the past. However, we can fix that by weakening the conclusion to “the current climate change may not be the result of human activity.” But in its weakened state, the conclusion no longer refutes human-caused global warming.
Step 4a: Identify hidden premises. By adding an extra premise to make an invalid argument valid, we can gain a deeper understanding of why the argument is flawed. In this example, the hidden assumption is “if nature caused climate change in the past, it must always be the cause of climate change.” Adding this premise makes the argument logically valid, but makes it clear why the argument is false - it commits single cause fallacy, assuming that only one thing can cause climate change.
Step 5: Check to see if the argument relies on ambiguity. For example, the argument that human activity is not necessary to explain current climate change because natural and human factors can both cause climate change is ambiguous about the ‘climate change’ in question. Not all climate change is equal, and the rate of current change is more than 20 times faster than natural climate changes. Therefore, human activity is necessary to explain current climate change.
Step 6: If the argument hasn’t yet been ruled out, determine the truth of its premises. For example, the argument that “if something was the cause in the past, it will be the cause in the future” is invalid if the effect has multiple plausible causes or mechanisms (as with climate change). In our example, this is where the myth most obviously falls apart (although it had already failed in Step 4).
The authors suggest that their six-step critical thinking process can be deployed via social media through ‘technocognition,’ and in the classroom. Co-author David Kinkead from the University of Queensland said:
We hope our work will act as a building block for developing educational and social media resources, which teach and encourage critical thinking through the examination of both misinformation and fallacious reasoning.
Lead author John Cook envisions that educators and others can use this approach to neutralize climate myths themselves:
Our critical thinking process is a useful tool that scientists, educators, and communicators can employ to identify fallacies in misinformation, which they can use to create inoculating messages that neutralize the myths. This approach is practical, achievable and potentially impactful in both the short-term (e.g., in social media applications) and long-term (incorporating this kind of content into curriculum). Misinformation needs short, sharp, immediate inoculation. Our paper provides a blueprint into how to write these inoculations.
Climate denial suffers badly from a lack of critical thinking, which has spread all the way to the White House. Teaching people to think critically can help prevent it from spreading even further.

description: Boss says his industry is changing but ‘the world is going to need oil and gas for decades’
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Boss says his industry is changing but ‘the world is going to need oil and gas for decades’
og_fields.og:title: BP aims to invest more in renewables and clean energy
text:
BP has declared it is looking to acquire more green energy firms, as the British oil giant pledged to set carbon targets for its operations.
However, while the chief executive, Bob Dudley, said the industry was in a period of major change, he made clear that hydrocarbons would remain the core of BP’s business.
“It’s not a race to renewables, it’s a race to lower greenhouse gas emissions. As fast as renewables and clean energy can grow, faster than any fuel in history, the world is going to require oil and gas for some decades to come,” he said.
The company reported on Tuesday that higher oil prices and growing crude production had pushed up profits 139% in 2017 to $6.2bn (£4.5bn) on an underlying replacement cost basis, the company’s preferred measure. 
Dudley said the firm had enjoyed its most successful year for exploration since 2004. The company said it would start six new oil and gas projects this year, up from five previously, as it outlined a plan to return to growth into the next decade.
But much of the company’s strategy update focused on clean energy, which BP said would amount to around $0.5bn of its $15bn-$16bn capital expenditure programme. The carbon targets, including one for methane, a powerful greenhouse gas, will be announced by BP in the next two months.
Discussing the shift to green energy, Lamar McKay, the deputy chief executive, said: “Our industry is changing faster than any of us can remember, certainly in my career.”
BP recently bought a $200m stake in Europe’s biggest solar developer, returning to solar power six years after it quit the sector, and is reportedly eyeing other bigger solar investments. 
The oil company is not the only one active in diversifying its business. In the last three months of 2017, its Anglo-Dutch peer, Shell, bought a Dutch car-charging network, partnered with the electric car charging firm Ionity and bought First Utility, one of Britain’s biggest energy suppliers.
One of the most eye-catching energy innovations of the last year – the deployment of the world’s first floating windfarm – was undertaken not by a renewables developer but Norway’s state-owned oil company, Statoil. Meanwhile, France’s Total took a 23% stake in the renewable energy firm Eren for €237.5m (£211m).
Big oil has flagged a switch to greener energy before. In the early 2000s, spurred by investor pressure, the international oil companies appeared to be pivoting to move their businesses away from crude. 
BP memorably tried to reinvent itself in 2000, promising that in the future its initials would stand for Beyond Petroleum, as the chairman, Sir John Browne, told the world: “We are not an oil company.” Shell also moved heavily into renewables. But not long after the financial crash, Shell stopped investment in wind and solar, and BP shut its alternative energy HQ.
Later, around 2016, the oil giants began to take baby steps back into the world of renewables, and take greater notice of the rapid growth of electric cars. 
Valentina Kretzschmar, the director of research at oil analysts Wood Mackenzie, said although activity had intensified in recent months, it was still small-scale. “It’s buzzing, but the amount of money spent is still peanuts compared to their core business,” she said.
Shell is seen by many industry watchers as the leader in this transition. The chief executive, Ben van Beurden, last week defended the company’s $1bn-$2bn spend on clean energy as modest but “not a pittance”.
“Ultimately, the only thing that matters to society is the carbon intensity of energy. How much we invest in aspects of our portfolio is only a secondary concern,” he said, in a message similar to BP’s.
Investor pressure, consumer attitudes and governments’ climate change policies are all driving big oil’s transformation. But increasingly it is the economics of renewables and electric cars that are key.
“For many of them, when they started diversifying it was because of investor pressure … but I think now it’s the market forces that are making them look into diversification,” said Kretzschmar.
However, she noted that returns for renewables were still lower than for oil and gas. Irene Rummelhoff, the head of Statoil’s low carbon unit, agreed that returns were lower but were often fixed at a set level, so diversifying made a “huge difference” to cutting risk from volatile oil prices.
“That’s one of the advantages we are seeing in the renewable world; the risk profile is very different,” she said.
But the rate of change is slow. Big oil companies own less than 1% of solar and wind capacity globally, according to Wood Mackenzie.
Jeremy Leggett, a former petroleum geologist turned solar entrepreneur, said: “All this is beyond greenwash, but far short of retreat consistent with the Paris [climate] agreement. The oil and gas companies and are essentially taking out hedge bets.”
Still, observers think that big oil might really be serious about moving beyond petroleum this time round, for existential reasons.
“It is different this time around,” said Kretzschmar. “This [the rise of renewables, electric cars and other clean technologies] is for the first time starting to pose a threat to their oil and gas businesses. That wasn’t the case in the early noughties.”

[{u'author': u'Rubens Camejo', u'text': u'3%. That means we're feeding 228 million of the 7.6 billion people on the planet.
That's population is growing at about 100 million annually. Our neighbours are growing at about half that rate.. 
Exponentially, we'll be feeding an extra 3 million next year and more the year after that and so on. 
By 2050 we could be required to feed an additional over 100 million on the numbers we now do if things continue as they are now. In the meantime, the rest of the world's farmers would be required to feed the other about 2.2 billion.
The thing is, apart from Africa, South America and Australia, there is little room to a expand traditional farming to cope with that volume of production.
The burden on the afore-mentioned continents would naturally increase as a result. 
That's barring huge investments in possibly multi storey greenhouses being built in the more populous regions and in the Northern hemisphere. That's not out of the question, of course. Greenhouse projects are a growing eventuality in the Middle East, for instance. 
However, an indication of where current thinking and planning can be found by following the money the two most populous countries in the world is headed. 
That money is heading towards the three continents I mentioned and it is aimed at resources, including arable lands. 
Now, we can stand by until it's too late and we should be ours is foreign owned or we could plan ahead and as a nation, make the government and private investments now. 
Unfortunately, a long vision of decades us required to make such decisions. That's something our 'she' ll be right' attitude and our political parties' election cycles limited vision make hard to attain', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518217930000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14556128', u'in_reply_to': u'111895674', u'id': u'112038719', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Rubens Camejo', u'text': u'It always intrigues me when people say "limit human population".

Maybe we should do as in the movie, "Logan's Run", and kill people when they reach 40?
As for trees: in Australia, as in sub-Saharan Africa. We need to plant MORE trees to protect lands we should turn into arable ones from losing their top soils. 
We need to spend money in bringing water and nutrients to those lands. It can be done, by the end of this century it will be done because it will need to be done. 
The costs, whilst not insignificant, are eminently affordable. 
I've written extensively on how we, in Australia, can achieve this and how that would place us at the forefront as a food's supplying nation to the world, especially to the nearly 4 billion prople living a stones throw to our north west.

Israel's use of water as a mechanism of control is a disgrace.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518177316000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13748050', u'in_reply_to': u'111999157', u'id': u'112010067', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JerryColebyWilliams', u'text': u'Bellis, my sustainable home and garden in Brisbane, won a National Save Water Award during Australia's Millennium Drought. Unique in Queensland, processed waste water helps nourish and water a subtropical food garden.
Our home grown food significantly reduces the household's virtual water footprint - irrigated agriculture uses a lot of water. Rainwater and recycling waste water reduce the need for potable mains water.
Here, home grown food uses between 1/5 and 1/12 of the water the equivalent food would consume if grown by an irrigated farm.
When ex-Cyclone Debbie dropped 219mm on 30.3.17, the water sensitive landscape soaked up every drop. Local flood mitigation is another benefit of applying whole of site water management principles. It works on any scale:
https://jerry-coleby-williams.net/bellis/whole-of-site-water/', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518168661000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4442598', u'id': u'112003375', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'yahali', u'text': u'In Israel 75% (!) of the drinking water supply of the entire country comes from desalination. 90% (!) of wastewater is treated and used for agriculture. Of course, it took a decade to plan and built the factories and a lot of money, but we have water.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518160603000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18537922', u'id': u'111999157', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'quokkaZ', u'text': u'The population of the OECD countries is only about 1.3 billion and will progressively fall as a percentage of world population because most of the population increase is coming from the developing world. Economic growth rates in many developing countries far exceed those in the developed world. It's time to face up to reality and understand that there will be continuing global economic growth for the foreseeable future. It will not be willingly abandoned. The only thing that will stop it is some catastrophe of unprecedented proportions.
This is THE environmental problem - how to deliver a decent standard of living to all without trashing the biosphere. It is a very, very difficult and the "no growth" crowd contribute nothing as they consign themselves to historical irrelevancy.
Yes, there is great inequality but there is no reason to believe that no growth would improve matters. The only thing that is likely to improve that is some powerful political movement from the left. Green parties are incapable and inept. I am very sad to say that I see little prospect of significant reductions in inequality at the moment but of course things sometimes can change rapidly in the right circumstances.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518153284000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'most of the population increase is coming from the developing world', u'effect': u'will progressively fall as a percentage of world population'}], u'author_id': u'4069809', u'in_reply_to': u'111954191', u'id': u'111997749', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Anna Pang', u'text': u'While cities are growing because of an increasing population, there are ways to create more sustainable water practices that can be introduced than just shipping in more water in plastic bottles. As briefly mentioned in the article, Singapore wanted to be more self-dependent when it comes to their water supply. The city state has an annual population growth rate of 1.3% and therefore has a growing city population. With this growth, they have begun to collect sewage water and through many filtration processes it becomes clean enough to drink. This is one way that a country is trying to reduce its freshwater use. Controlling populations can reduce fresh water use in a specific area but even if a population is more spread out, a greater rural population, water consumption can still increase as the population evenly grows. Water is needed for all food that we eat; growing fruit and vegetables takes a huge amount of water that is stored in the ground (soil). Meenakshi Arora makes a very good point that we should harvest rain and storm water as individual households and use this in our non-drinking, water using activities. There is so much water that is used indirectly by humans that even if populations grow evenly within a country, the water consumption can still increase.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518142506000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'an increasing population', u'effect': u'while cities are growing'}], u'author_id': u'18533197', u'in_reply_to': u'111913389', u'id': u'111996125', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'dejavou', u'text': u'A few hundred kilometres south of the highest mountain in the world.With the thousands of glaciers and hundreds of rivers fed by the Himalayas, it must seem odd that we face such a challenge when it comes to water;but we do.Thankyou for asking.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518096179000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13029792', u'in_reply_to': u'111934138', u'id': u'111969019', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'dejavou', u'text': u'Thank you for your kind suggestion and I know you mean well.I want to assure you that I have no other options than to buy water which has been extracted from the ground. We call it boring water ....a pipe drilled hundreds of feet into the ground and water pumped out(which has been tested by a lab and is 1/4th the price of your regular 20 L bottled water.Sewage and dead animals float in our pond and streams.I don't trust the lab neither the guy who is selling me the water so for drinking purposes I buy water from a different source,which as I mentioned earlier is 4 times more expensive)I am among the lucky as I live about 150 metres from the water source to my bathroom and kitchen.. I own a few empty 20 litre jars and have saved the lid and have figured out with (help from others) how to attach it so that the water will not spill. I haul it on my shoulders and carry it to my home.I am young and healthy and can carry all the volume that I use.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518095934000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13029792', u'in_reply_to': u'111956280', u'id': u'111968836', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Anthonyhu', u'text': u'BQSTART

Northern Europe, these problems are not really huge problems, the skilled operator are present and available, the infrastructure is present in most cases and funding is available to a large extent. Building , placing and maintaining a fully automated Water work or Sewage plant is possible, albeit costly. Distributed systems are not cost effective, countless studies on this has been done through the years, but only in our part of the world. In our part of the world, our cities do not swell either with explosive growth, which puts an incredible strain on sub-terran infrastructure. It is impossible to change a pipe's capacity.Lesser developed countries lack of skilled personnel makes distributed systems all but impossible, whether fully automated or low tech. In a sense it is just a different skillset needed.1 st world countries have a Damocles sword of their own, proven rising water levels and torrential rains our system were newer designed for, causing massive damage to property and in some cases life loss.Being in charge of water supply to a city with 350 000 people is a huge responsibility, and you tend to stick to proven methods. New desal plants will come on stream in March and tapping into the underground water has been successful. Earlier this week an agricultural cooperative in a different catchment area that privately built its own dams and has not suffered the same drought conditions started to release water to Cape Town.Local residents have become very innovative especially since the failure of last winters rain. Very little goes down the drain these days and thousands upon thousands of tanks have been installed to harvest rain water off house roofs. The predicted rainfall will fill all of them. (the municipality will not be overjoyed about this because they will lose water revenue)South Africans are pretty good at sorting themselves out especially when the chips are down. But in developed nations we have grown enough; our poverty comes from lack of distribution of wealth.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518072362000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13472177', u'in_reply_to': u'111897244', u'id': u'111954191', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Echlin', u'text': u'While I respect your professional skill and point of view, your warnings and general attitude are based on a limited world view. People can think intelligently about how to use water not supplied by a mains system. In many places all over the world rainwater collection is the only or principal way of obtaining a supply. Grey water use can be designed into living to provide either water for growing or recycling for some domestic uses. Local knowledge or private research can yield fine systems. I accept that water scarcity and illness and deaths caused by contaminated water is a serious problem IN SOME AREAS. There the skills of water engineers and NGOs added to the labour and intelligence of local people will help provide an answer. But in most places, safe water need not cost a lot. In my one location in the bush in Africa, for 18 people we collect all our domestic consumption needs from rainwater and use brackish water for flushing and cleaning. All wastewater is used for growing, some after filtration and resting. In the nearest town, piped water for subsequent distribution in plastic containers costs about 1.5 English pounds per 1000 litres and is widely distributed by bicycle and motorcycle..A great deal of the water distribution system in much of Africa, including urban areas, is commercial and uses a distributed network and is not ‘owned’ by experts. It works because it evolves in response to day to day need using local resources and transport. Waste water use, however, still needs a great deal of work by municipal authorities. After use, 80% to 95% of water is released without treatment and any further direct use. [2017 edition of the United Nations World Water Development Report] Thank you for your contribution but please do not discourage people from trying other ways of meeting their needs and using alternative sources of this precious fluid.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518066829000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'contaminated water', u'effect': u'illness and deaths'}, {u'cause': u'it evolves in response to day to day', u'effect': u'it works need using local resources and transport'}], u'author_id': u'15485155', u'in_reply_to': u'111932350', u'id': u'111953190', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AchmadOsman', u'text': u'The article makes good points, however, it glosses over a major elephant. An increase in the increase of a curve is beyond the cognitive abilities of most people most of the time. Hence our coming tragedy. While there is an increase in the increase of droughts, the survival of the human animal is distinctly linear and binary. After a a few days without water we die and never come back. Like a man jumping to escape an ever higher series of waves. He can only jump so high before he drowns. The solution. There are only two roles of the dice left - rebellion to overcome the global regime and replacement with with climate realist governments which do what it takes to reduce carbon emissions to zero. And geo-engineering. Both I would be totally opposed to a few years back. But now. Well we are all going to be changing a lot in the coming years. Better change now because it will only get worse later when we have to change under force. PS note the rich have the most to lose - the state will always take the wealth of the rich when it faces existential crises.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518021343000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it will only get worse later when we have to change under force', u'effect': u'better change now'}], u'author_id': u'12879387', u'id': u'111927767', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Chinawatcher', u'text': u'I have experienced water rationing in modern city, of 4 hours a day every fourth day and its is not nice at all. Water management for urban areas needs to be separated into potable and non potable water. 
For example following the crisis, all new buildings toilets had to flushed with seawater, thsi is now about 80% of all buildings. A side benefit is that sewage treatment costs are significantly reduced as the saltwater breaks down the sludge naturally.
Progressive pricing for water also helped, but the main fix was the building of aqueducts to rivers and massive reservoirs, including damming ocean bays to China. There was a desalination plant, but it cost more to run than buying water for the aqueduct/pipelines and was eventually sold to the middle east.
