description: As Day Zero looms and the South African city gets set to run out of water, experts say lessons learned during Melbourne’s brush with a similar fate may help avert a global crisis
og_fields.og:description: As Day Zero looms and the South African city gets set to run out of water, experts say lessons learned during Melbourne’s brush with a similar fate may help avert a global crisis
og_fields.og:title: What Cape Town can learn from Australia’s millennium drought
text:
In December 2017, Seona Candy drove through the vineyards of the Franschhoek Valley near Cape Town towards the banks of the Sonderend river. In the late 1970s, the waterway was dammed to create the biggest reservoir in South Africa’s Western Cape. Behind the thick walls of the Theewaterskloof dam lay the capacity to hold 480 million cubic metres of water, nearly half of Cape Town’s water supply.
“When I got there, it was mostly dust,” Candy says.
Candy, a post-doctoral research fellow in sustainable food systems at the University of Melbourne, was in the city for food security conference. Every conversation, with everyone from other delegates to her Airbnb hosts, turned back to the water crisis.
The city has been in drought since 2015. Its population has almost doubled since 1995, from 2.4 million to 4.3 million, putting pressure on the urban water system. At the end of last year’s dry season, the water behind Theewaterskloof dam was less than 13% full.
Day Zero, when municipal water supplies will officially run out, is looming. The local government say the taps will be turned off on 11 May. At that point, people will only be able to collect a daily allowance of 25 litres from 149 points around the city, marshalled by the police and military.
But experts believe this is a crisis that could easily face other major urban areas with similar population and climatic characteristics to Cape Town.
“Cape Town is the canary in the mine,” says Candy.
In Australia, the millennium drought, which parched the country for the first decade of the new century, left cities such as Melbourne a year away from running out of water.
This experience has put the country, and institutions like the University of Melbourne, at the forefront of cross-disciplinary research into water security.
“Experts overseas expect Australia to be one of the first developed countries to be really hit by climate change in terms of drought,” says Candy. “We already have been. The world is watching to see how we deal with climate change – either how badly or how well.”
Her own research in modelling future scenarios around food security and greenhouse gas emissions points to one major recommendation: the wholesale switch from fossil fuels to renewables in energy generation.
Agriculture accounts for the biggest use of water in most countries. But Candy has found the amount used in energy production is projected to leap to similar levels, fuelled by power demands from coal seam gas production.
“If you switched to 100% renewable energy generation, in the future we could save the same amount of water that we currently use in agriculture,” she says.
Expanding distributed, or decentralised, systems is another solution, she adds. It allows people to reduce the distance between collecting and using water. Rainwater tanks are the best example. The millennium drought saw nearly a third of households in Victoria install them.
“These are good, not just because they take pressure off existing infrastructure and resource by having a technological solution, but also by making people more aware of what they are using,” says Candy.
Any intervention in water security comes at a cost. With climate change amplifying both flood and drought, the risk of getting it wrong is also heightened.
Professor Andrew Western is part of the hydrology and water resource group in the University of Melbourne’s department of infrastructure engineering. He has been running simulations to help city authorities hold future Day Zeros at bay without going bankrupt.
Key to creating a buffer in a city’s water supply is having more than one source, he says. Reservoirs alone will not suffice for cities with highly variable climates like those in Australia or South Africa.
“You need diversity of water supply to get security,” says Western.
At the height of the millennium drought, Melbourne built a desalination plant and a pipeline to divert water from the Goulburn river in the rural north. Both were expensive – the plant cost $3.1bn – and politically contentious. But combined they now have the potential to supply more than half of Melbourne’s water needs.
Using reservoir levels as a key indicator, Western’s work will help cities know when to start using such technological interventions and what the associated costs – capital, operating and social – will be. The aim is to help authorities avoid panicked, costly decisions.
“It’s worth spending money to have really good plans in place for when crisis situations are emerging. With Cape Town, this is probably where it has fallen down,” he says.
Meenakshi Arora is also part of hydrology and water resource group. The senior lecturer in environmental engineering has run detailed simulations of the water demand caused by household activities such as cooking, laundry, toilet flushing and showering.
She recommends that houses should have two different water streams: drinking water for cooking and showering, and non-drinking water – including harvested rain and storm water and treated waste water – for toilet flushing, laundry and garden irrigation.
Urban water scarcity is a problem produced by social institutions. It is an issue of transition
Changing the water quality to suit the task would reduce demand for clean drinking water, lessen the risk of floods and reduce the amount of contaminated rainwater draining into rivers.
“In most established communities we are still flushing our toilet with drinking water,” she says.
The University of Melbourne’s chemical engineering department is also doing work on diversifying the mix of water. The team there is looking at advanced water treatment, converting sewage into drinking water, which uses less energy and produces more water than desalination plants. The real cost is political and social. It is a hard sell with most populations.
However, Professor John Langford, from infrastructure engineering, suggests that cities with water supply issues should follow the example of Singapore, which already mixes some recycled water into its drinking supply.
“The key point is they have a long-term plan of community engagement, so if Malaysia did turn off the tap [the city state is reliant upon its neighbour for most of its drinking water] Singapore could quickly take over the supply,” he says. “My argument would be, which has had no success with the politicians, is to have a long-term program of community engagement here in Australia so we also have that option.”
There is nothing natural about a city running out of water, according to Professor Jon Barnett, an expert on vulnerability and adaption to climate change from the school of geography.
“There are plenty of solutions to solve these problems,” he says. “It’s not like we don’t know what to do or that there is a shortage of options. Urban water scarcity is a problem produced by social institutions. It is an issue of transition.”
But what if cities don’t adapt?
 Barnett says examples already exist.
“You will get shadow markets,” he says. “Water barons move in to control the allocation of water as they would drugs or illegal tobacco and alcohol during periods of prohibition.”
Less clean drinking water means people will resort to using poorer quality, with all its attendant health risks. “There are still more than 2,200 children that die each day because they can’t access good-quality water,” he says.
But there is some good news. Scarcity of water is unlikely to provoke war. There have been more than 10 times as many treaties on shared waters and rivers than there are international rivers in the world, says Barnett. “Basically, the incentives to conflict are very low, the incentives to cooperate are very high.”
Despite this, action is needed. Increasingly volatile climates and booming populations will mean that more cities will have their own Day Zero.
“We’ve already seen it in Australia and there are huge issues in Brazil,” says Barnett. “These are problems that require a lot of organisation, a lot of leadership, a lot of willingness to change. And if that isn’t there, then all the inhibitors to change will prevail. And you end up with Cape Town.” 
• This article originally appeared in Pursuit, the University of Melbourne’s online magazine

description: Case brought by group from Hunter Valley town, which it says has been devastated by Peabody Energy’s Wilpinjong mine
headline: N
og_fields.og:description: Case brought by group from Hunter Valley town, which it says has been devastated by Peabody Energy’s Wilpinjong mine
og_fields.og:title: NSW court to hear 'landmark' challenge to coalmine over climate change impact
text:
In what is described as a landmark case, a New South Wales court will be asked to overturn a decision to extend the life of a coalmine on the grounds the state government failed to properly consider the impact on the climate.
The case is brought by a community group from the tiny Hunter Valley village of Wollar, which it says has been devastated by the development and gradual expansion of the Wilpinjong coalmine over the past decade.
Mine owner Peabody Energy won approval last April to further expand the mine, which sits between the towns of Mudgee and Denman, to extend its life by seven years to 2033.
In a case starting on Thursday, the Wollar Progress Association will argue the decision was unlawful as it did not properly consider the impact of the increased greenhouse gas emissions, including “downstream” emissions when the coal is burned in NSW and overseas power plants.
It says the state also did not look at whether the extension was in step with state and national climate change policies and targets, including Australia’s commitment under the 2015 Paris agreement to keep warming below 2C.
 Lawyer David Morris, from the Environmental Defenders Office NSW, said the association would argue 2007 legislation covering extractive industries was explicitly designed to ensure these two points were considered before decisions were made on whether projects could go ahead.
 “What is the point of commitments and targets if they are not factored into and reflected in decisions about projects which contribute to emissions?” he said. 
“We say it is a landmark case. When you think about a coalmine in 2017, it is difficult to think of a more important consideration than its contribution to climate change.”
The secretary of the Wollar Progress Association, Bev Smiles, said the mine had gradually grown from approval in 2006 to mine 9.5m tonnes a year to the current 13m tonnes. She said the proposed expansion would bring it to within 1.5 kilometres of the village.
She said many landholders had sold to the company, and the population had fallen from about 300 to 70.
“The impact from noise, dust and blasting has been extreme,” she said. “What happens under government processes is we are left to our own devices up against people who have a lot more resources than we have, and the treatment of people over time by this company has been quite disgraceful.”
 A spokeswoman for Peabody Energy said the company had been through a comprehensive process and the case related to the approval process by the state’s Planning Assessment Commission, not the merits of the extension project. She said the mine generated jobs and invested in the Mudgee region, employing 413 people.
 Peabody Energy is also applying for an exploration licence over more than 1,600 hectares of land east of Wollar.
 The case starts in the land and environment court on Thursday. The planning minister, Anthony Roberts, declined to comment while the issue was before the court.
 Separately, Smiles and two others will be in Mudgee local court on Friday facing charges relating to a protest at the mine last April.
While the case is believed to be the first time a mine approval has been been contested over its climate impact under the 2007 NSW law, at least one decision has been challenged on similar grounds under federal legislation. In 2016, the federal court dismissed a case brought by the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF) against the federal government’s approval of Adani’s Carmichael mega-coalmine.
The ACF argued the mine’s approval was inconsistent with the country’s obligations to protect the world heritage values of the Great Barrier Reef. The court found the then environment minister Greg Hunt had considered the impact of the emissions from burning the coal on the reef, and that Australia had latitude under the World Heritage Convention as to how it carried out its obligations.

headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Beaches, wildlife, the Great Barrier Reef, unspoilt natural wilderness and national parks all considered threatened
og_fields.og:title: Tourism is the Australian industry least prepared for climate change, report says
text:
Tourism is Australia’s most vulnerable and least prepared industry to deal with climate change despite the fact it is already feeling its effects, according to an advocacy group report.
 The report by the Climate Council, based on 200 source documents and articles, says while tourism is growing at an extraordinary pace – an 8% jump in visitors last financial year – not enough is being done to prepare for damage to the country’s greatest drawcards.
 The five biggest attractions as reported by Tourism Australia – in order: beaches, wildlife, the Great Barrier Reef, unspoilt natural wilderness, national parks including rainforests and other forests – are all considered threatened by climate change.
 The report says federal and state governments have mostly underplayed or ignored the risk to tourism. The government’s national Tourism 2020 plan makes no mention of the need to cut greenhouse gas emissions or improve sustainability in the industry.
 Last month, the head of Queensland’s Association of Marine Park Tourism Operators, Col McKenzie, called climate scientist Terry Hughes “a dick” and urged the federal government to cut research funding due to his public comments about rising water temperatures harming the reef. McKenzie said it had turned tourists away.
 Ecologist and report co-author Prof Lesley Hughes said it should not be controversial to discuss the threat climate change posed to the industry.
 Beyond the often cited back-to-back years of bleaching on the reef in 2016 and 2017, she cited as examples beach erosion due to rising sea levels and a projected accelerating growth in extremely hot days in the red centre and the Top End across this century.
 “Most government and industry plans on tourism are focused on growth but they don’t also look at the other side of the coin, which is the risks,” she said. “When people come here they might do other things – cultural things such as visiting the Sydney Opera House – but really the overwhelming attractions are natural icons and it’s very clear they are all already being affected.”
 Government data cited in the report underlines the extent of the tourism boom. International visitors spent $40.6bn last financial year and were served by a tourism industry that employs 580,200 people, 5% of the country’s total workforce. The government estimates that, for every dollar generated by the tourism industry, a further 90c is spent elsewhere in the economy.
 New Zealand provided the most visitors, though Austrade expects it will be overtaken by second-placed China this year. Britain, the United States and Singapore round out the top five. Tourism Australia this week launched a major advertising campaign in the US during the Super Bowl based on the Crocodile Dundee movie franchise. Starring actors Chris Hemsworth and Danny McBride, the campaign emphasises Australia’s natural beauty.
 The industry’s growth has made tourism Australia’s second-largest export after iron ore. It is a significantly larger employer than coalmining or oil and gas extraction, which in 2014-15 employed 39,000 and 22,000 people respectively. 
 Hughes said, despite this, the future of fossil fuel industries and jobs received far more attention in the national conversation. “It’s cognitive dissonance at its most extreme,” she said.
 Examples of industries already being affected by global warming include ski tourism, which has seen a trend of increasing reliance on artificial snow as seasons she shortened over the past 25 years.
 “That’s a classic illustration that tourism industries will need to adapt and diversify to find other ways to bring people to those regions,” Hughes said.
 The report highlights some hotels, resorts, airlines and zoos have taken steps to cut pollution but says a national plan is lacking. Hughes called on more tourism operators to lobby governments to help the industry adapt and diversify. 
“I would also like to see operators be part of the lobby for better climate and energy policy,” she said.

description: Slash CEO income, bring more women on board and go low carbon, Church Investors Group tells companies
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Slash CEO income, bring more women on board and go low carbon, Church Investors Group tells companies
og_fields.og:title: Churches warn firms over pay, gender and climate change
text:
The Church Investors Group has warned some of Britain’s biggest companies it intends to take a hard line over failings on executive pay, gender diversity and climate change in the forthcoming annual meeting season.
The group, which represents church organisations with combined investment assets of about £17bn, has told companies listed on the FTSE 350 index it will refuse to re-elect directors at firms failing to make sufficient progress in key areas.
“The best companies contribute to the common good through their products and services and the way they treat their employees,” said the Rev Canon Edward Carter, chair of the CIG.
 “Their directors understand that if they are not doing something about fairness and about the risks facing us today, they are part of the problem and risk losing the confidence of the public and ultimately their licence to operate.”
The group’s members have invested in companies including Tesco, Royal Dutch Shell, AstraZenca and HSBC. It backs investment policies based on Christian ethical principles and represents institutional investors from mainstream Christian church denominations and charities, including the main investment bodies of the Church of England and the Methodist church.
Outlining its new voting policy, the CIG said its members would vote against executive pay packages where pay ratios are not disclosed, excessive pensions for chief executives or where financial services or pharmaceutical companies do not pay the living wage. 
It will also scrutinise a company’s record on gender diversity, voting against the re-election of nomination committee chairs if women make up less than a third of the board. If the proportion of women drops below 25%, CIG members will vote against all directors on the committee.
According to the latest figures published by the government-backed Hampton-Alexander review – which aims to increase the number of women on FTSE boards – there were 301 firms in the FTSE 350 at the end of June 2017 where the proportion of women on the board was less than 33%. 
A total of 170 firms would have failed the CIG’s test of having female board representation equivalent to less than 25%, including BP, Barclays, Prudential and Just Eat.
The proportion of women on boards falls to just 9% at the pub and restaurants group Mitchells & Butlers, and there are no women at all on the board of Sports Direct, the retailer founded and run by Mike Ashley.
Stefan Stern, director of the High Pay Centre, welcomed the new voting policy adopted by the CIG, and said the group was “putting some teeth into the issues, which is necessary”.
Climate change is the third key area for the CIG, which said its members would vote against the re-election of the chair if a company is making little progress on the transition to a low-carbon world.
“Church investors have long sought to address excessive executive pay and encourage the adoption of the living wage,” said Stephen Beer, chief investment officer of the central finance board of the Methodist church. 
“Our new policy will enable us to send a clear signal to companies that we expect them to consider fairness when setting executive pay levels. We encourage the wider investment community to hold directors accountable and ensure more responsible stewardship on this critical subject.”
The 2018 annual meeting season gets into full swing in spring, and last year the CIG did not support 60% of remuneration reports put forward by FTSE 350 companies. It recommended against 37% of nomination committee chairs.

In Hansen's scenario B, the atmospheric CO2 and N2O levels in 2016 were pretty close to the actual 2016 values. But the methane, CFC11 and CFC12 levels were significantly over-estimated.
The result, as Hausfather shows, is that scenario B overestimated the actual radiative forcing to 2016 by about 10%.
So even scenario B was destined to overestimate warming (which it did by about 30%). Yet, you insist on using scenario A! This is clearly inappropriate.
As Hausfather points out, there is another, even more significant reason for the paper's warming overestimation, and that is the 4.2C climate sensitivity figure employed. But the paper made it very clear that there was considerable uncertainty as to the true value.
When adjusted for the actual radiative forcing and the current best estimate for climate sensitivity (3C), Hansen's model is in fact pretty accurate.

BQSTART
Hansen: Some things do change gradually because of the inertia system. The global average temperature, if you average it over several years, is going up pretty smoothly, since the middle 1970s. January/February of this year, global temperature is now 1.3 degrees above the 1950-1980 average, but that was just two months. Averaged over the year, it’s going to be about 0.9 degrees Celsius, and that’s pretty much on this almost linear increase over the last four decades. 
Locally and regionally you get abrupt events, which are the ones that have the biggest impact on people. The frequency and severity of extreme events increase as the planet continues to get warmer. Sea level and ice-sheet disintegration is also a very nonlinear process. It’s going to lead to rapid change within the next several decades. 
BQEND

The subject here is global warming.
Counterintuitively, sea level rise is not uniform globally for many reasons such as land subsidence and lift, ocean currents and winds and even the strong gravitational field of the massive ice sheets.
The gravity from the ice sheet pulls the ocean towards it, as it loses mass the ocean relaxes away, so for example the loss of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet would cause global mean sea level rise of around 3.3m, but over 4m in the North which has a more populated coast.
Parts of the N Atlantic have seen falling sea levels while parts of the W Pacific have seen a rise of ~1.5cm per year, ~5 times the global average, for the last decade, which would be a distinct problem were that to continue for those areas.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518219387000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the loss of the west antarctic ice sheet', u'effect': u'global mean sea level rise of around 3.3 m'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'112037591', u'id': u'112039424', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'hsnriflejkejh', u'text': u'There are plenty of Americans ticked off with this current charade of a government - I wont say administration as administrating for the people appears to be a non-starter these days. The sea level rise talk is moving from mms to cms.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518218925000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14727943', u'in_reply_to': u'112038591', u'id': u'112039209', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'For those who think warming is good consider that the paleoclimate record clearly shows that a temperature rise of just 1.5-2 degrees C above preindustrial temperature commits the system to 6-9m of sea level rise, a large fraction of which could arrive this century.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518209201000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'id': u'112033970', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Klapper', u'text': u'BQSTART
However, a lot of the food made in the world is obviously made by low economic and technological intensity standards.
BQEND
Even areas with low "technological intensity" are improving their yields. From the FAOSTAT crop production database I downloaded data on millet, maize and sorghum from Mali, Senegal and Burkina Faso. Maize yields have gone from around 5000 Hectolitre/Ha in the early 60's to 15K to 20K Hc/Ha in 2014.
All crops in all countries except for maize in Burkina and millet in Burkina and Senegal showed accelerating yield trends when the last 20 year trends was compared to the trends since 1961. Only sorgham in Senegal showed no real yield gain since 1961. Since 1995 the slowest gain in yield was 11%, the highest 107% and the average of all crops in all countries 32% yield increase in the 20 years 1995 to 2014 inclusive or about 1.5% per year.
So even in poor, relatively dry countries in Africa the effect of climate change so far has been either positive or at least not negative.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518209164000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3638543', u'in_reply_to': u'112032040', u'id': u'112033944', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Klapper', u'text': u'BQSTART

So the rising of temperature doesn't seem to be quite in our favor here.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518209146000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'efficiencies in agriculture production', u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'13062454', u'in_reply_to': u'112031773', u'id': u'112033937', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'Hi Kurt. 
First of all - 
BQSTART
7K +/- 2K y ago (or roughly 7,000 BC to 3,000 BC) 
BQEND
You must ponder how to convert BC (or CE) to "Before Present" or "ago" as you call it). This is mathematically not difficult if you think about it. 
Not Even Norway (polar amplification and all that) was 2 degrees warmer for most of the time of the Holocene - and I am sure you have forgotten that the general cooling trend over the Holocene is caused by the same mechanism that cause and end ice-ages. But it is still true. 
CO2 remained nice and stable though - while the orbit of our planet slowly changed. It is important to remember in this context that the orbit of Earth is still changing. The amplitude of these changes are obvious not very striking on decadal time-scales. It is why it is easier to record over thousands of years. 
Secondly, in the times of Brexit - it is worth remembering that even the huge nasty EU cover a not particularly big proportion of the world. 
Now we all know that 70% of the planet is ocean - and Africa is a tiny place - until we think about it: 
https://cdn.static-economist.com/sites/default/files/20101113_WOM943.gif
There is a final interesting question you kind of lob up into the air: 
The greatest civilisations in Northern Europe - are they usually defined as existing between ca 8-5,000 years ago (which is a better definition of the Holocene Optimum) - or are they defined by more recent concepts that involves Vikings, The British empire, some Reich, stuff about a union of Soviet, a bit of Roman things and well - stuff. 
Give me one great invention from the Holocene Optimum from North-western Europe - and use that as a solid argument for why that planetary better was key to our innovation up here. 
I mean you Swiss really needed the little ice age to come up with the Cuckoo clock as a great product. 
And remember dear Ötzi - who got frozen into ice around 4,500 years ago - was his life really that fantastic in your Holocene Optimum? 
Personally - it think that the artwork inside the Lascaux cave is worth more than Mona Lisa. The first is made in a big ice-age - the other is painted in a smaller European ice age. 
You outline a very strange and very Eurocentric point of view - that is hard to follow once one take away the emotional "heat is good" premise.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518208818000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the same mechanism that cause and end ice ages', u'effect': u'the general cooling trend over the holocene'}, {u'cause': u'that', u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'112029189', u'id': u'112033757', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'mountainrunnermum', u'text': u'BQSTART
Crop yields are going up on every continent, and in every crop type,
BQEND
Based on many studies covering a wide range of regions and crops, negative impacts of climate change on crop yields have been more common than positive impacts (high confidence). The smaller number of studies showing positive impacts relate mainly to high-latitude regions, though it is not yet clear whether the balance of impacts has been negative or positive in these regions (high confidence). Climate change has negatively affected wheat and maize yields for many regions and in the global aggregate (medium confidence). Effects on rice and soybean yield have been smaller in major production regions and globally, with a median change of zero across all available data, which are fewer for soy compared to the other crops. Observed impacts relate mainly to production aspects of food security rather than access or other components of food security. See Figure SPM.2C. Since AR4, several periods of rapid food and cereal price increases following climate extremes in key producing regions indicate a sensitivity of current markets to climate extremes among other factors (medium confidence).

They started as an attempt to minimize the effect of tidal flooding over farmland. After that the systems of dykes were moved further seaward to utilize more land. In short they were built to claim land that was under water. As for the impending sea level rise and how it would affect the Dutch system of dykes, 
BQSTART
The Second Delta Committee, or Veerman Committee, officially Staatscommissie voor Duurzame Kustontwikkeling (State Committee for Durable Coast Development) gave its advice in 2008. It expects a sea level rise of 65 to 130 cm by the year 2100. Among its suggestions are: 
- to increase the safety norms tenfold and strengthen dikes accordingly,- to use sand replenishment to broaden the North Sea coast and allow it to grow naturally,- to use the lakes in the southwest river delta as river water retention basins,- to raise the water level in the IJsselmeer to provide freshwater.These measures would cost approximately 1 billion Euro/year.
BQEND
And that is building on a system that already exists and has existed for centuries. Just as his predictions of temperature changes from 1988 have failed to materialize (by a factor of two)
BQEND
From this analysis by Zeke Hausfather:
BQSTART
Hansen et al [1988] presented three different scenarios associated with different future greenhouse gas emissions. Scenario B is shown in the chart below as a thick black line, while scenarios A and C are shown by thin grey lines. Scenario A had exponential growth in emissions, with CO2 and other GHG concentrations considerably higher than today. 
Scenario B assumed a gradual slowdown in CO2 emissions, but had concentrations of 401ppm in 2016 that were pretty close to the 404ppm observed. However, scenario B assumed the continued growth of emissions of various halocarbons that are powerful greenhouse gases, but were subsequently restricted under the Montreal Protocol of 1987. Scenario C had emissions going to near-zero after the year 2000.
Of the three, scenario B was closest to actual radiative forcing, though still about 10% too high. Hansen et al also used a model with a climate sensitivity of 4.2C per doubling CO2 – on the high end of most modern climate models. Due to the combination of these factors, scenario B projected a rate of warming between 1970 and 2016 that was approximately 30% higher than what has been observed.
BQEND

Do you have a guesstimate as to what GMST threshold would be beyond safe?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518206121000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16112781', u'in_reply_to': u'112031541', u'id': u'112032135', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'To start on a positive note - it is great that you acknowledge Global warming and the greenhouse effect. 
Now - what are the potential causes of increased crops?
Well - good temperature and precipitation with the right crop for the conditions of climate and soil is of course the old gold standard. 
However at present, a lot more comes into play with intensive farming. 
Good nutrients and soil management are imperatives. And huge advantages are being made here - with high-science innovations on combining natural nutrients (manure or lifting crops back into the soil) with mineral and artificial nutrients (nitrogen, urea, ammonia chemics for example)
Huge scientific advances has also been made on soil-stress - by resting the soil by use of different crops every few years. 
We must also remember breaking of new land (usually by cutting down forest). 
Pesticides is of course widely used - and GM-crops is of course also becoming more and more important. 
Artificial irrigation is opening for wider crop-intensification - as well as better ploughing techniques to optimise permeability and lower nutrient wash-out - and new technology, including use of helicopters to break inversion layers during odd frost-days are innovations being used. 
Finally - the loss during harvesting - it is going down. These corn-harvesters these days run on effing GPS guiding. 
So - just as tree-ring scientists knew a century ago - sure - temperature is a strong. 
But as farming science has known for centuries - one can fool that climate by being smart. 
Finally - you must take a discussion with your sceptical friends below - because they blame the additional CO2 growth on out-gassing from vegetation. 
So - there is a moral issue to the tecno-optimistic post I just wrote. We all know that high intensity farming is what we in the rich west does best. Farmers are often taking a 5 year master or even PhD over here. So we who are already wealthy - we are good. 
However, a lot of the food made in the world is obviously made by low economic and technological intensity standards. Ideas of helicopter fanning or high end irrigation installations or even getting the expensive YARA-nutrients is not an option.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518205980000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'they blame the additional co2 growth on out gassing', u'effect': u'finally you must take a discussion with your sceptical friends below'}], u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'112029517', u'id': u'112032040', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'When you can't attack the science, you go for the scientist. For those unfamiliar with Hansen and might wonder about KS's smear of an excellent scientist, he is one of the planet's most accomplished climate scientists with a long track record of accurate projections and ran NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies for over 30 years, arguably the planet's premier Earth science organization. 
The following is from a 1981 paper by him that at the time hit the front page of the NY Times, all the projections in it have either come to pass or are well underway. 
BQSTART
Potential effects on climate in the 21st century include the creation of drought-prone regions in North America and central Asia as part of a shifting of climatic zones, erosion of the West Antarctic ice sheet with a consequent worldwide rise in sea level, and opening of the fabled Northwest Passage.

BQSTART
From early on, the significance of Hansen’s insights was recognized by the scientific community. “The work that he did in the seventies, eighties, and nineties was absolutely groundbreaking,” Spencer Weart, a physicist turned historian who has studied the efforts to understand climate change, told me. He added, “It does help to be right.” 
“I have a whole folder in my drawer labelled ‘Canonical Papers, ’ Michael Oppenheimer, a climate scientist at Princeton, said. “About half of them are Jim’s.”

description: EPA administrator says ‘There are assumptions made that because the climate is warming that necessarily is a bad thing’
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: EPA administrator says ‘There are assumptions made that because the climate is warming that necessarily is a bad thing’
og_fields.og:title: EPA head Scott Pruitt says global warming may help 'humans flourish'
text:
Scott Pruitt, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, has suggested that global warming may be beneficial to humans, in his latest departure from mainstream climate science.
Pruitt, who has previously erred by denying that carbon dioxide is a key driver of climate change, has again caused consternation among scientists by suggesting that warming temperatures could benefit civilization.
The EPA administrator said that humans are contributing to climate “to a certain degree”, but added: “We know humans have most flourished during times of warming trends. There are assumptions made that because the climate is warming that necessarily is a bad thing.
“Do we know what the ideal surface temperature should be in the year 2100 or year 2018?” he told a TV station in Nevada. “It’s fairly arrogant for us to think we know exactly what it should be in 2100.”
Pruitt said he wanted an “honest, transparent debate about what we do know and what we don’t know, so the American people can be informed and make decisions on their own”.
Under Pruitt’s leadership, the EPA is mulling whether to stage a televised “red team blue team” debate between climate scientists and those who deny the established science that human activity is warming the planet.
Donald Trump has also repeatedly questioned the science of climate change, tweeting during a cold snap in December that the US “could use a little bit of that good old Global Warming that our Country, but not other countries, was going to pay TRILLIONS OF DOLLARS to protect against”.
The EPA itself is unequivocal that warming temperatures, and resulting environmental changes, are a danger to human health via heatwaves, smoke from increased wildfires, worsening smog, extreme weather events, spread of diseases, water-borne illnesses and food insecurity. 
This array of health-related challenges has prompted the medical journal the Lancet to state that tackling climate change will be “the greatest global health opportunity of the 21st century”.
National security experts, including those at the Pentagon, have also warned that climate change is set to create a sprawling humanitarian challenge, as millions of people look to escape failing crops, inundated land, drought and conflict. 
Research has pointed to some potential benefits in certain areas of the world, such as areas of the Arctic opening up to agriculture and shipping as frozen soils thaw and sea ice recedes. Deaths from severe cold are also expected to drop, albeit offset by rising mortality from heatwaves. 
Human civilization has, until now, developed in a relatively stable climate. Rising temperatures, of around 1C since the industrial revolution, are pushing humanity into an environment it has never previously experienced. The last time sea surface temperatures were as high as now was around 120,000 years ago, when sea levels were up to 9m higher than today’s average.
“As the evidence becomes ever more compelling that climate change is real and human-caused, the forces of denial turn to other specious arguments, like ‘it will be good for us’,” said Michael Mann, a climate scientist at Penn State University. 
“There is no consistency at all to their various arguments other than that we should continue to burn fossil fuels.”
Since being installed by Trump to lead the EPA, Pruitt has overseen the repeal or delay of dozens of environmental rules, including the Obama administration’s clean power plan, which sought to curb greenhouse gas emissions from coal-fired power plants.
“There was a declared war on coal, a war on fossil fuels,” Pruitt said in his Nevada interview. “The EPA was weaponized against certain sectors of our economy and that’s not the role of a regulator. Renewables need to be part of our energy mix, but to think that will be the dominant fuel is simply fanciful.”

[{u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'From Rob DeConto regarding the WAIS, 
BQSTART
The key is it’s retreating on bedrock that, as Jonathan noted in many places, is sloping down into the continent toward the continent, not down toward the ocean. 
It's on what we call a reverse sloped bed, so the grounding line has just gotten thicker, which means it turns out that we can actually start to pump more ice through the grounding line. 
And it's really interesting, the amount of ice that can flow through the grounding line is related to how thick the grounding line is, that's pretty intuitive, but it's an exponential relationship. 
So if the grounding line gets just a little thicker, as it starts to retreat, you start pumping an exponentially greater amount of ice out of the ice sheet, in that as you could see will just lead to a runaway retreat where once that grounding line starts to come back onto that reverse slope bed the system just takes off.
BQEND', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518721175000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'a runaway retreat where once that grounding line starts to come back onto that reverse slope bed the system just takes off'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'112266239', u'id': u'112285871', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'"Once an ice cliff calving retreat begins, a glacier typically accelerates & thins, which can lead to reduced frontal ice height below the critical limit."

Again - important to make clear that the mechanisms involved are still not well understood.
Many of the key processes inherent to the dynamics of retreating marine ice sheets are not well understood, either from lack of basic knowledge, or more commonly, from lack of detailed site-specific data for model calibration and parameterization. These processes include:...(3) ice-cliff processes, including ice cliff strength, fracture processes, the role of surface melt, and mélange processes that may slow the progress of cliff failure; 
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S092181811630491X
The idea of the marine ice-cliff instability is still fairly controversial amongst glaciologists (NOT to be confused with the marine ice sheet instability, which is not controversial and is another reason that West Antarctica is vulnerable to rapid ice loss). A recent paper in Nature3 suggests that there is observational evidence from ancient iceberg tracks, but not all glaciologists are convinced that this new data fully supports the marine ice-cliff instability. Whether the marine ice-cliff instability is something that is likely to occur in Antarctica is still debated amongst scientists.
https://climatefeedback.org/evaluation/antarctica-doomsday-glaciers-could-flood-coastal-cities-grist-eric-holthaus/

This change has been variously discussed e.g. here amongst many others. I see no way that the original title could remain given:
 - The speculative nature of the freshwater injection (amount, rate and method)  - Open questions over interpretation of the supporting observational and in particular palaeo-evidence and its interpretation
 - The non-deterministic nature of the climate system  - The fact that the findings contravene accepted science based upon many decades of research and publications by many respected and established groups and individuals
The title was (and has to be) a reflection upon the paper contents and not on whether 2C does or does not reflect dangerous interference with the climate system. Those who willingly or unwittingly conflate these two issues are falling into a very obvious and dangerous (no pun intended) logic trap. The title should reflect the paper and not be a position statement upon whether some nominal departure from pre-industrial is safe or not. The two are completely seperate issues. To answer the second requires a holistic assessment of the totality of evidence for impacts of various thresholds on subcomponents of the Earth System. For that you want to wade through IPCC WG2 (book a few days out to do so) and not a single paper!

http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2018/02/06/1717312115', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518520393000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'112157981', u'id': u'112164318', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'I've cited that article by Kerry Emanuel myself a few times, but it is nearly 4 years old.
It's specifically about climate sensitivity, and there's a very recent contribution on that.
Very low values of sensitivity (and indeed very high values as well) have been eliminated by this very recent study:
"Emergent constraint on equilibrium climate sensitivity from global temperature variability" - Cox et al, 2018
https://www.nature.com/articles/nature25450

BQSTART
2.2-3.4C, 2.8C with 66% confidence limits
BQEND
Very low values and very high values of equilibrium climate sensitivity are now out of the frame.
The lowest number, 2.2, is not good, of course.
If doubling CO2 from 280 ppm to 560 ppm is going to increase average global temperatures by 2.2 C deg at least, this is certainly worrying
2.8 C deg for a doubling of CO2 is bad news indeed, and up to a possible 3.4 C deg would be very serious.
However, it does mean we need to look again at the graph in Emanuel's article:
http://climatechangenationalforum.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Temperature-rise-probability-distribution-for-a-doubling-of-CO2.-Figure-from-Chris-Hope-University-of-Cambridge.png
Clearly the range has narrowed a lot since that graph was produced.
As a result I'm no longer posting the Kerry Emanuel article.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518519128000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'112153845', u'id': u'112163211', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'quietreason', u'text': u'I'm interested that earlier you talked about the Netherlands' excellent record of flood prevention while parts are as much as 7m below sea level. And then in the same breath about flood plain preservation. But the Netherlands' is rhe estuary for a large European catchment whose flood plains are beyond Dutch borders, while its policy in providing "Room for the Rivers" is about ensuring that floodwaters of the Rhine and Meuse, which it has no power to stop from entering its own territory, can pass speedily and safely out to the N Sea.
Were you as expert in hydrology as you suggest, you would long since have known that the UK and its neighbours are receiving increasingly intense winter rainfalls and that these add to the flood prevention problem. You'd also have known that these deluges are a predicted consequence of global warming and, coupled with accelerating sea level rise (another AGW) consequence will be making hydrologists' lives even more interesting, so you wouldn't be trying to disrupt discussion of an article relating future flooding risks to CO2-induced warming if you were a proper hydrologist.
I do agree that current lax attitudes to the destruction of flood plains and loss of tree cover need urgent attention, but we need science to be investigating and discussing all factors which are steadily impairing our ability to safely conduct all the rain we receive from where it fals and down to the sea.
Right now large UK catchments have no plans for how to drain their more extreme precipitations before they flow damagingly through the lives of people and places, and HMG has no plans to invest to even a fraction of Dutch expenditures to prevent the resulting erosion, wreckage and mayhem, preferring to plan nothing, spend peanuts, impede rational management of rivers large and small and let different communities take the hits as they come.
And none of this justifies your cockeyed attempts to denigrate serious studies of a creeping but clearly accelerating and man-made global warming crisis. BTW, when I say creeping I do so because few can grasp the massive consequences implicit in a 0.5C global mean temperature rise when accustomed to making >2C adjustments to their home thermostats. Wading through a real, actually peer-reviewed, scientific paper can be a little heady.
BQSTART
the calculation of eddy diffusivity Kmeso for GM following Visbeck et al. (1997) was simplified to use a length scale independent of the density structure (J. Marshall, per- sonal communication, 2012): Kmeso = C/[TEady × f (latitude)], (2) where C = (27.9 km)2, Eady growth rate 1/TEady = {|S × N|}, S is the neutral surface slope, N the Brunt–Väisälä Atmos
BQEND
Got that?
So I was pleased to hear the physics of glaciers described in layman's terms (see Richard Alley on any of a number of excellent presentations on YouTube)
Here is all you need to know about the physics of glaciers, (according to Alley anyway) A pile spreads under its own weight. A kilometers thick ice sheet spreads under its own weight, losing mass at the edges, calving ice into the ocean and gaining mass in the middle through snowfall. (Greenland also has surface melt involved)
Like pancake batter it spreads, a bit slower than water does. Pancake batter spreads even slower on a waffle iron than a skillet because of the bumps, like in Greenland's topography.
It also spreads slower if you hold it back with a spatula, the spatula is like the floating ice shelves which slow the spreading of the ice sheets by providing additional friction.
If you speed up the spreading by removing the "spatula" then the mass of the ice sheet shrinks and the ocean rises. My simple question for you is just what would you propose for the UK?
BQEND
1. Accepting that floods have always ocurred and always will
2. Accepting that there is, to date, no evidence of more or greater rainfall events outside normal and natural variability.
3. Recognising that the impacts of flooding have been getting worse over the past 60 years or so, due to manmade causes.
4. Understanding which are the most significant of manmade causes: building on floodplains (which both puts buildings at risk and causes diversion of flood impacts to other places, up and downstream, which were previously at lower risk).
5. Understanding of how land use changes increase the risks of flood impacts: removing vegetation, paving over land, etc
6. Accepting that we can never and will never stop floods causing damange, sometimes seriously, and sometimes causing loss of life.
7. Implementing land use controls to both reverse these changes and to prevent them getting worse. This includes applying the Environment Agency's policy of not allowing new building on flood plains; preventing the new channelling of rivers and streams; reversing the chanelling of rivers and streams to more natural meandering; preventing the removal of essential vegetation; requiring the replanting of such vegetation where feasible; working with farmers to reduce uncontrolled run-off from their fields; encouring infiltration of run-off waters instead of chanelling them via drains to rivers (which then become more inondated and cause more flooding).
Etc, etc.
Such measures and controls are well-understood by hydrologists. Unfortunately, their views have too often been overuled by planners gullible enough to be influenced by developers. Now, they are being undervalued by policymakers more interested in reducing 'carbon footprints' to gain political brownie points.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518561434000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'manmade causes', u'effect': u'recognising that the impacts of flooding have been getting worse over the past 60 years or so'}, {u'cause': u'both', u'effect': u'diversion of flood impacts'}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'loss of life'}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'damange'}, {u'cause': u'which', u'effect': u'more flooding'}], u'author_id': u'2595146', u'in_reply_to': u'112119830', u'id': u'112190015', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'You'll notice that he did not walk back his statement in the conversation with Mann.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518495973000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'112136206', u'id': u'112153068', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Samuel', u'text': u'Creationist blogger publishes un-peer-reviewed errors. This research was discussed in an article:
https://insideclimatenews.org/news/04122015/medieval
BQSTART
"The Medieval Warm Period was certainly not a global event and probably didn't even span the entire North Atlantic region," said Nicolás Young, a glacial geologist at Columbia University who was the lead author of the study, in an interview about that research. 
"These glaciers were almost just as big during the Medieval Warm Period as they were during the Little Ice Age in the Baffin Bay and Labrador Sea region," Young said. "It probably wasn't all that warm during the Medieval Warm Period."
BQEND
The Medieval Warm Period and the Little Ice Age were concepts introduced about 50 years ago by early climate researchers, particularly Hubert Lamb, based on evidence available at that time, but the more they are investigated the more ephemeral they become.
Various sources give different dates for the start and end of the LIA, for example, and it's increasingly disputed that it was a global event.
Many researchers now think the whole concept of the 'Little Ice Age' is misleading as the changes were small-scale and seasonal.
For example, true ice ages involve snow remaining throughout summers across large areas, which didn't happen during the so-called Little Ice Age.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518551302000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'112065149', u'id': u'112185566', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'The oldest object I've ever held was a decent piece of iron meteorite.
It was one of the multi-thousand pieces from the strewn field of the Gibeon meteorite found in Namibia.
We bought it for science lessons long ago - it cost about £25. Unlike the rest of the collection of rocks and fossils, it was kept in the prep room safe.
The oldest fossils I've got at home are graptolites, which I collected from a beach in Pembrokeshire. They are about half a billion years old.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518551002000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'112184790', u'id': u'112185455', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'mountainrunnermum', u'text': u'BQSTART

description: John Abraham: A new study finds strong agreement that flood risks in central and western Europe are rising due to global warming.
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: John Abraham: A new study finds strong agreement that flood risks in central and western Europe are rising due to global warming.
og_fields.og:title: Climate change is increasing flood risks in Europe | John Abraham
text:
As humans continue to emit greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide, the world continues to warm. We see that warming everywhere – in the atmosphere, in the oceans, with rising sea levels, and melting ice. But while we know conclusively that humans are causing the warming, an equally important question is, “so what?” Really, we want to know the consequences of warming so that we can make informed decisions about what to do about it. We really have only three choices: mitigate, adapt, or ignore and suffer the consequences.
A very new study was just published that helps answer this question of “so what?” The research was conducted by lead author Lorenzo Alfieri (European Commission – Joint Research Centre, Italy), Richard Betts (University of Exeter and Met Office, UK), and their colleagues.
In the study, the authors used what are called Impact Models to assess the risks of large-scale flooding. They focused their attention on Europe partly because there is a lot of hydrological information there, flood reporting is easily available, and predictions of future climate there are plentiful. The authors compared estimates of flood risk in Europe from three recent case studies; their comparison incorporated changes to future climate, expected damage, and population that will be affected in the flooding zones. 
I think of this as a three-part study. First, the authors obtained climate projections for Europe using state-of-the-art climate models. Next, they input the future climate into calculations that quantify flood risk and the impacts. Last, they compared the results that they obtained from their different damage calculation algorithms. The authors looked for areas where the calculations agreed or disagreed with each other. At the end of the day, they wanted to answer two key questions:
1. Is it possible to identify trends that are consistent among the models to help Europe prepare for changes to flood risk?
2. Are there differences in the models and if so, why?
I communicated with Professor Betts who told me:
Our results give the clearest picture yet of climate change increasing the risk of flooding. We did two new sets of model calculations and compared them with a third set from previous work. With all three methods, the result is higher flood risk in Western and Central Europe under a warmer climate, even at just 1.5 degrees C global warming. 
Lead author, Lorenzo added, 
In support to Richard’s statements, the strength of our results comes from the variety of climate projections, methods and models included in this comparison work. The three studies we have considered cover a wide range of variability in projections of flood impacts, thanks to the use of 11 independent climate scenarios, 11 hydrological models, 3 inundation models and 2 impact models. Nevertheless, they all agree on a significant increase in flood risk in most European countries, at all global warming levels. 
So where did the models agree and where did they disagree? The answer is shown in the figure below from the paper. Red colors signify agreement between the models on an increasing flood risk, and green indicates agreement on a reduction of flood risk. Light colors and white indicate disagreement on future projections. The left-most column corresponds to temperature increases of 1.5°C, the middle column is for 2°C temperature increases, and the right is for 3°C increases. In summary, the models all agree that flood risk is increasing and will increase for Western and Central Europe. 
This means the researchers are quite certain regarding increased risks in the central and western parts of Europe but less certain about what will happen in the east. But the authors went a step further; they calculated the expected economic damage from future flooding for the three different temperature increases. They found that regardless of which model was used, there will be significant economic damage (in the range of tens to hundreds of billions of Euros per year) in the warming future. They also showed that the population affected in Europe by future flooding will grow significantly in the future. Roughly estimated, 500,000 to 1 million people are expected to be affected by flooding in the future climate.
What I like about this study is it tries to tackle the problem of quantifying a cost of climate change. We know humans are warming the planet. What we really want to know is what the effect is. Only by comparing costs of action to costs of inaction can we make wise decisions. So far, the research is telling us that it is much wiser to take action now to reduce warming (mitigation) than just ignore greenhouse gases and try to adapt to a harsh future climate. 
Studies like this give lie to people who claim that it is too expensive to take action on climate change. What this study shows is it may be too expensive to do nothing.

I’d suggest there are many legitimate reasons to stop Adani, but sticking a toddler in a car for eleven hours ain’t one of them.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518141987000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10052803', u'id': u'111996030', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Nick3000', u'text': u'Marnie,Your sentiments are doubtless sincere, but stopping Adani is not necessarily the best way to address the concerns you have. Burning coal is not as dangerous for the barrier reef as the direct threat of farming runoff and starfish invasion - the reef would benefit from action on those fronts much more than pretty much anything else. Stopping Adani per se will not stop coal from being burned, it will stop Adani coal from being burned, which could be even more harmful for the environment. Even within the narrow view of climate change mitigation it could be argued that mining and burning high quality coal is a kind of least-worst option in the competing priorities of economic prosperity, energy security and environmental responsibility. To pursue only one priority without recognising the others is naive and selfish. You may not care whether jobs come to the Galilee or power is reticulated in India, but that is because you are wealthy, live in a wealthy nation and enjoy the fruits of the labour of many others, including the production of coal as a major export revenue earner. What we don't have is a comprehensive plan to get through all of those problems with the least compromises. I don't see our political leaders talking about the greatest threat to the planet, namely the growth in population which currently runs at a net gain of 2 million people per week. That massive steam train is primarily driven by the education level of women. If you want to make the best possible contribution get behind that real problem.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518146429000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'you are wealthy live in a wealthy nation and enjoy the fruits of the labour of many others', u'effect': u'that is'}], u'author_id': u'15089024', u'id': u'111996790', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'00Lexx', u'text': u'The full video can be found online - there is no "full statement" except in after-the-fact Gillard apologist propaganda.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518146198000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16507314', u'in_reply_to': u'111996545', u'id': u'111996762', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ClHawk', u'text': u'Thanks Marnie. description: Having children made me realise the urgency of climate change action. Why can’t politicians see it?
og_fields.og:description: Having children made me realise the urgency of climate change action. Why can’t politicians see it?
og_fields.og:title: I travelled 11 hours with my two-year-old to tell our leaders: stop Adani | Marnie Cotton
text:
My little girl was born over seven years ago. Two weeks into her life the Brisbane floods arrived. It was a gut-wrenching slap in the face for me. Not because we were terribly affected but because it was the compounding evidence I needed to understand what climate change would mean for my beautiful fragile newborn.
Before having her, I understood that climate change was real and extreme weather events were only going to get worse and occur more often as the global temperature increased. With an extraordinary deluge of water falling from the sky, holding my newborn, I realised that my daughter was in the firing line and climate reality struck. 
Seven years on, with my second child in tow, politicians continue to fail us. The notion that our government supports opening up the largest coal basin in the southern hemisphere is dumbfounding. That opposition leader Bill Shorten is still unable to take a stand against this dangerous project is also shocking. 
So on Sunday night, I travelled down to Canberra on a very packed bus with my two-year-old from the mid-north coast of New South Wales. An incredible bunch of newly met “climate protectors” travelled with me on this mad rush to Canberra, determined to gather on the first sitting day of parliament to demand our government #StopAdani. 
We travelled for 11 sleep-deprived hours, arriving 15 minutes before the start. It was wonderful to see the passionate people calling for leadership, but our leaders weren’t there to address the crowd.
Our parliament, elected by the people of Australia, hardly listens to the will of the Australian people. Two-thirds of Australians want to stop Adani’s coalmine. Do politicians believe they are immune to climate change? That this is a great big hoax, one to be turned into light comic relief in parliament? 
A year ago today Scott Morrison brought a lump of coal into the chamber, shouting “this is coal, don’t be afraid” to overzealous eruptions of laughter. Other politicians see fit to laugh about sea level rise occurring to Pacific neighbours or at the notion of coral reef scientist crying in despair at the death of our precious reef. 
And where is the opposition? Bill Shorten stands idle, sitting on the fence. An opposition party must give voters a different option. 
If you would like to be the next leader Bill, then you must lead now. You must tell the people about the true threats we are facing. You should visit those being directly effected. You must talk about the future that could be. That you want every coalminer to be supported and retrained so they can build the energy future we so desperately need. That you will carry them into the just transition. 
After half a day of Canberra madness on parliament’s lawn, we all crammed back on that bus and spent another 11 hours driving home. My two-year-old had a wild ride with these wonderful people who showed so much passion and love for a child they had only just met. They were standing up for her future. And I know they will continue to turn up because once you understand what we are facing, you can’t not act. 
As the years go on, every extreme weather event, dire coral bleaching event, kelp forest die-off, mangrove die-off, extreme catastrophic fire, flood, storm, will exacerbate my fear for my daughters’ future. What will we leave our children? How will they survive and thrive as the extremes play out? Will life be only about surviving?
Our children deserve a safe climate. They deserve to see the beauty of the natural world as we do today. They deserve to thrive and survive. They deserve better. That is why we must Stop Adani. Are you listening, Bill?

That's why SpaceX launched the car.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518361006000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1626910', u'in_reply_to': u'112076544', u'id': u'112083754', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Henk Plaggemars', u'text': u'Are we so limited as a species that we can't do both (clean up the oceans as well as explore space)?

While I laud the attention this article gives to our despoilment of the natural environment, an issue close to this individual's heart. I also seek progress in us as a species to look beyond and see what is across that vast ocean.
The juxtaposition of a desirable sports car with, importantly, a human figure at the wheel and reference to some popular culture with the "Don't Panic" sign on a trip into space along with appropriate music...well what better way to burn into this and upcoming generation's minds the allure of space and the promise that it offers.

But if hypersonic stratospheric planes or suborbital rockets become a popular form of travel, replacing a significant portion of the current airline travel, this would likely have a large impact on the stratosphere, ozone levels, and global warming.', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518360392000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4335870', u'id': u'112083465', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bernie Masters', u'text': u'The 'trash' you refer to in the oceans affects at worst a few percent of the surface of the marine environment and virtually none of the water lying even just a few cm beneath the surface and extending down to the seafloor. It's extreme exaggeration to claim the oceans have been trashed so I disagree with the premise on which this story is based.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518359809000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13045006', u'id': u'112083183', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ehywhat', u'text': u'Just a giant garbage dump that doesn't even rust away in time, then?', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518359777000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4365488', u'in_reply_to': u'112082669', u'id': u'112083169', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mardak', u'text': u'Funny how the reaction of the space wannabes to any criticism os to dismiss the critic as a luddite. It couldn't be that recycling German WWII tech to set up a payload to space transportation business for profit may be questionable in the face of other earthly priorities. It must be some great wisdom about barely pissing around in near orbit amd calling it space that the rest of us just don't grasp.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518359613000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15273043', u'in_reply_to': u'112073503', u'id': u'112083087', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Art Glick', u'text': u'Let's not forget everything from integrated circuits to LEDs. I can tell you that were it to be viable to send a breeding colony into space and found another human civilisation on Mars none of the likes of us will be invited to participate. The human race will consist of Musk Branson and Trump clones. I'd prefer extinction.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518357306000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17941076', u'in_reply_to': u'112080698', u'id': u'112081938', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Tom Franken', u'text': u'This is the most uninformormed editorial I have seen from The Gaurdian. First, Musk's launch was a test and needed a disposable payload. Second, rust requires iron, oxygen, and water which are hard to come by out of the atmosphere. Third, communications travel at best the speed of light. The closest planet in a potentially habitable orbit is 12 light-years away from us. The whole concept of alien life checking in on us is just stupid.
If you're worried about the environmental impacts of rockets, push for a new way to launch satellites. The space shuttle had a 1-in-67 failure rate. How many millionaires are going on a vacation with that level of risk?', u'recommendation_count': u'36', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518359127000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16597448', u'id': u'112082844', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Miseribleoldbloke', u'text': u'He did write that he didn’t understand the science. Which makes this a curious piece to write in a national newspaper.', u'recommendation_count': u'27', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518359062000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13013065', u'in_reply_to': u'112082669', u'id': u'112082810', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'amberjack', u'text': u'BQSTART
because the only way for the human race to survive is to leave the planet

Why waste time worrying about something you have no power to change?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518357272000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15223886', u'id': u'112081917', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Steve__M', u'text': u'He's just wrong to assume Elon Musk's rocket is a billionaire's plaything. Space exploration is a serious endeavour that has hugely contributed to our knowledge of Earth and its fragility. 
The car was necessary ballast which has a one in a zillion chance of doing anything except collide with the Sun during the next billion years.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518359061000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18247935', u'in_reply_to': u'112080326', u'id': u'112082808', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'NickStanford', u'text': u'"If the moon was a habitable planet we would have started destroying it 50 years ago"
Me: 2004', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518359003000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15223886', u'id': u'112082783', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rosslosangeles', u'text': u'Dear Mr. McKenna,
The trash that we have dumped into the oceans or that has separated from various satellites in orbit are important problems. Emissions from planes and rockets into the atmosphere are also serious problems. I do not minimize these problems in any way.
But our knowledge of these problems as well as potential solutions for them require the information, perspective, and data that can only be obtained from satellites in space. As I have stated in previous comments, the SpaceX launch this week was the first test of a new rocket system that reuses components instead of trashing them. SpaceX had estimated a 50% possibility of failure for this first test and could not risk the enormous costs of a destroyed satellite or much worse, the lives of astronauts if the launch failed. The car was an advertising opportunity that was irrelevant to the primary purpose of the first test of the new rocket.
I understand that many people view this event as a selfish and wasteful vanity project. I see work that is as essential as it is unprecedented: reusable rockets that return to a launch pad, electric vehicles with an with an EPA-rated range of 335 miles on a single charge, a mega-battery that can store solar or wind energy and protect the power grid in South Australia. The price for moving from fossil fuels to renewable resources is not trivial as demonstrated by the unprecedented loss that Tesla also announced this week.
I also believe that posing a false dichotomy between investments in new technology and investments in remediation of existing problems will not help anyone. Both are necessary and are often interdependent. People who opposed funding for NASA in the 1960’s could not imagine the discoveries, inventions, or the interconnected world that funding made possible. You and I and every human being alive are the direct beneficiaries from millenia of what you devalue as a “fetish” to discover, explore, and understand the universe in which we live.
How can we determine the environmental consequences of anything if we examine only discrete elements or events but not the systems or processes within which they occur? Acknowledging pollution from ground, air, and space vehicles is honest; pretending that everyone can return to pre-industrial modes of transport and life is not. Electric cars and reusable rockets are each steps on the long journey to sustainable transportation and a more sustainable world. I applaud Mr. Musk for his many accomplishments and hope that the global publicity from the successful launch of the Falcon Heavy helps to secure more funds that allow SpaceX and Tesla to continue their extraordinary work.', u'recommendation_count': u'20', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518356916000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3837803', u'id': u'112081731', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Miseribleoldbloke', u'text': u'“Musk won’t be getting invited to address an environmental summit in the near future.“
Assuming you want satellites for communication and GPS and weather forecasting we’ll need rockets. SpaceX rockets are designed to return to base and be re-used. 
Musk also pioneers electric cars and solar panels. 
So maybe being invited to an environmental conference isn’t that unlikely.', u'recommendation_count': u'39', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518358989000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13013065', u'id': u'112082775', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'redwhine', u'text': u'SpaceX would have had to send a dummy payload of roughly the same weight to test its rockets, instead they sent a Tesla car for publicity purposes. Had they just sent a metal box as is normal, nobody would have noticed. But nobody would have weather satellites, satellite navigation, mobile phone/data service, and any number of other things were if rockets couldn’t be tested in this manner.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518358921000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3862005', u'id': u'112082742', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MieGoreng', u'text': u'When Darwin and the Beagle were underway, Where do you think they threw the ship's waste. And yet some good came of that.The sports car in space could have been an inert lump of concrete. Would that make the joyless reporter happy? The electric car in space is also about PR to help the prospects of a car company that might, if it survives, help slow CO2 emissions from personal transport.', u'recommendation_count': u'15', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518356571000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4019546', u'id': u'112081554', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Citizen_Gav', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our
community standards.
