CCS is one of the key engineered solutions for this. Reforestization works great where there is enough precipitation, and where food production is already sufficient. Unfortunately a growing potion of the warming world is experiencing more drought and more land is needed for growing food.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518959270000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14086929', u'id': u'112396589', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Shanesw', u'text': u'Simon your article, like many on the Guardian now, seem to simply be written for the purpose of inflaming political bias rather than report fact; no political party anywhere has any idea nor intent to tackle the mitigation now needed for a safe climate. Public ignorance ensures their tenure, supported by the media's failings.
Far more worryingly the following you have written is incorrect:"CCS is a basket of technologies, some of which are likely to be important in the future as we work to decarbonise a range of industries with stubborn emissions, such as steelmaking and cement production."
Negative Emission Technologies (NETs) are now mandatory for a safe climate, not "likely to be important" as you stated. Hansen has published calculations that show emission reductions have been left so late that now for a safe climate, emission reductions alone will be inadequate and must now be combined with massive carbon sequestration this century. 
A safe climate for us is one in which global temperature is returned to the Holocene range. Fig 12 of Hansen's Young People's Burden paper shows that this is achieved by emission reductions of -3%/yr starting in 2020 AND sequestering 237PgC this century. 237PgC = 237GtC = 237*44/12GtCO2 = 869GtCO2 = 87 years worth of carbon sunk by the global ocean over the next 82 years (or -6%/yr and 58 years worth of ocean carbon sink).
Regarding rates of emission reductions, CSIRO stated in CAWCR Technical Report No. 042:"A global mitigation rate of 5%/yr, sustained for many decades, is greater than almost all observed regional emissions reduction rates for energy transitions over the last several decades. These include the managed energy decarbonisations in Sweden and France in the early 1980s (reductions of 4 to 5% per year for a few years) and the collapse of the former Soviet Union in the 1990s (reductions of around 7% per year for a few years, accompanied by widespread hardship). However, these examples have always involved regional decarbonisation as a side effect of some other event or process, not an intentional policy goal."
Ignorance to these matters is astonishing, as stated in the World's Biggest Gamble:"The scale of the decarbonisation challenge to meet the Paris Agreement is underplayed in the public arena. It will require precipitous emissions reductions within 40 years and a new carbon sink on the scale of the ocean sink. Even then, the world is extremely likely to overshoot. A catastrophic failure of policy, for example, waiting another decade for transformative policy and full commitments to fossil-free economies, will have irreversible and deleterious repercussions for humanity’s remaining time on Earth. Only a global zero carbon roadmap will put the world on a course to phase-out greenhouse gas emissions and create the essential carbon sinks for Earth-system stability, without which, world prosperity is not possible."
Our predicament is dire and you have understated this. Thank you and thank you Guardian.

Everybody is savaging me but not a soul can tell me the answer.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518889396000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12475077', u'in_reply_to': u'112348961', u'id': u'112362804', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SoloLoMejor', u'text': u'What is the value in degrees Celsius of Australia's commitment as a proportion of the resulting global temperature reduction by 2100?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518889350000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12475077', u'in_reply_to': u'112357356', u'id': u'112362764', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SoloLoMejor', u'text': u'James, very funny but the science is not as settled as is being made out, nor is the consensus. I'm left wing in my political views. The IPCC is not a science body it's a political body and plenty of internationally renowned climate experts have resigned from it in disgust at the political manipulation of it's reports and accords. You seem to think that scientists just organically decide to do their studies with an open mind and hey ho it's all co2. Well it doesn't work like that. Scientists who don't accept the dogma cannot get funding because the science is "settled" which creates a vicious cycle of these meaningless heath Robinson exercises which are an utterly ridiculous waste of finance and resource. The last time science was this settled was when the Catholic church insisted the sun revolves around the earth.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518889102000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the science is settled', u'effect': u"scientists who do n't accept the dogma can not get funding which creates"}], u'author_id': u'12475077', u'in_reply_to': u'112359196', u'id': u'112362542', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'To me, CCS is equal to hydrogen fuel cell technology when it comes to energy. 
To make energy with the thermal efficiency of combustion (not great) is one thing - and even less great when adding the energy needed for capture and storage and actual storage. The numbers does not even make sense with a massive carbon tax. 
Similar with clean hydrogen - first one use clean energy to make hydrogen - then one use energy to compress and store and liquefy and cool it. Then one make it into energy again - with substantial loss of energy in every step. 
It simply does not compute for most use in terms of primary energy production. 
These techs do have important potential in other sectors though. Lots of non-energy production has lots of spot emissions (like steel - or agricultural nutrients or....). Fuel-cell/battery hybrid ferries are coming online. Even fuel-cell generators are starting to do good work for many purposes - even with the cost involved. 
But for energy generation - well - the fuel-cell is not even on topic - and for CCS - it simply makes no sense when coupled to energy production - especially as the price of a watt reach nuclear cost-levels. 
To combust carbon just to use the output to catch CO2 is kind of an inverse perpetuum mobile idea. Or a "use a leaf-blower inside the house instead of a vacuum cleaner to get dust off the floor" idea. You may move the problem a bit maybe - but you clearly do not solve it. 
A huge amount of governments have thrown tax-payer money at the fossil industry to develop industrial scale CCS. Norway has. UK. Canada. US. And they are all pretty much shite - though with great scientific value to ponder. 
I would say "stop that" - and throw the billions at energy storage systems. 
Remember - hominids have made energy for millions of years. After a swim in cold water we soak the sun, we dry clothes by wind-power, we light a fire, we make haystacks (yes wind-power again)
We are not in lack of harvesting energy. But when it comes to storage energy we are kind of stupid. The only good large-scale storage system we have made is to dam water. And that is not exactly a new invention. 
So research CCS - but not for fossils - and put the rest of the research grants into storage technology. That involves highly effective grid-sharing. 
At the moment - all the great storage systems we have are pretty much kinetic in nature. Hydro is - so is flywheels. Though chemical storage (batteries) is making really good strides both on density and cost (though density is not so important for land-storage). 
Also thermal storage is moving along fast and needs research money - as they are approaching 24/7 delivery even with current tech. (thermal energy-storage has also been well known technology for tens of thousands of years - along with solar and wind - as everyone having been in a tent-sauna with heated rocks will know - an early viking viking technology that everyone who ever experienced a hot water bottle in bed is aware of)
It is all about learning physics. 
We know how to make useful energy from wind, flowing water, the sun, atoms, tides, burning twigs and fossil twigs (coal and gasses and liquids) on industrial scales for hundreds and millions of years. Energy generation capacity was rarely our limitation. 
Storage is the thing we have to learn to do. As evolutionary harvesters - store a volt instead of a nut. Hey - a squirrel.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518888448000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4706143', u'id': u'112362055', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DavidJHursty', u'text': u'Um, from my point of view - 'tis not about CO2 ... but OXYGEN.How many people really know where Oxygen comes from??Try holding yer breath. 10 seconds; 39 seconds - one minute? ten minutes?

u'112337205', u'id': u'112347992', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Lagado', u'text': u'It's not quite in the same realm of technofantasist crazy as colonizing Mars, but it's close.
"The unquestioned reliance on negative emission technologies to deliver on the Paris goals is the greatest threat to the Agreement. Yet BECCS, or even negative emission technologies, received no direct reference throughout the thirty-two-page Paris Agreement. Despite this, the framing of the 2°C and (even more) the 1.5°C, goals, is fundamentally premised on the massive uptake of BECCS sometime in the latter half of the century. Disturbingly, this reliance on BECCS is also the case for most of the temperature estimates (e.g. 2.7°C) ascribed to the national pledges (INDCs) prior to the Paris COP.
The sheer scale of the BECCS assumption underpinning the Agreement is breath taking – decades of ongoing planting and harvesting of energy crops over an area the size of one to three times that of India. At the same time the aviation industry anticipates fuelling its planes with bio-fuel, the shipping industry is seriously considering biomass to power its ships and the chemical sector sees biomass as a potential feedstock. And then there are 9 billion or so human mouths to feed. Surely this critical assumption deserved serious attention within the Agreement?"
The hidden agenda: how veiled techno-utopias shore up the Paris Agreement - Kevin Anderson.

Be careful what you wish for Griff.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518865816000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14842422', u'in_reply_to': u'112329821', u'id': u'112347311', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SFromNl', u'text': u'Good luck staying cost competative against renewables providing CCS, the fossil industry is struggling even without it.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1518865573000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17048054', u'id': u'112347147', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ComfortablyPlumb', u'text': u'The IPCC Fifth Assessment Synthesis Report estimated that without CCS the cost of climate mitigation would increase by 138%.
In pejoratively fixating on coal this article avoids mentioning that CCS isn't simply for coal - or even electricity.Far from it.
It is also for industry, such as cement manufacture (alone more carbon emissions than all global aviation), Steel, fertiliser, hydrogen production - and yes, gas plants to balance intermittent renewables/or/baseload.All emit large quantities of CO₂
As to coal, what of countries who cannot afford the electrical system transition to renewables/nuclear etc?CCS, once developed, could be useful as a bridge there - not ideal, but then not everyone will be able to afford 'ideal'
Or even countries like Germany who are just plain obstinate and open new lignite coal plants to balance their new renewables whilst they close their nuclear plants.A carbon tax could (and would have) forced them to clean up their act and actually cut emissions by adding CCS.

What is the difference between concrete/steel applications and a power station application of the technology?
BQENDIf you want the science, then it's the partial pressure of the CO₂ -the greater the pp the easier it is to capture the CO₂.
If you read up on the subject then I'm sure you'll understand that.
And not just steel and cement - they were just examples.Fertiliser too - and hydrogen production (95% of our hydrogen comes from Natural Gas) - a lot of CO₂ is liberated in the process (we already use that waste for things like fire extinguishers/food storage and other industrial uses.
BQSTART
Most of the publications focus on the immediate energy penalty of the plant.
BQENDThat's the big issue.
How about a comparison of energy penalty and cost:If you are genuinely prepared to read up on it as you say, you could tot up the numbers to compare the losses, par exemplar, of adding the carbon and financial cost of a battery to a wind farm or solar plant.The same with pumped storage - although they are only 75% efficient..a huge loss.
The thing people forget is that a battery does not produce power - it is a hugely expensive net loss of minerals and energy, the sole purpose of which is arbitrage/EFR to make the supply more adaptable to help bridge the (smaller) gaps when the supply drops off.
Now we accept the loses and costs as a necessary trade off as an integral and expensive part of the low carbon system we need to address AGW.
Nobody (who knew what they were talking about) ever claimed that addressing AGW would be cheap.
It's worth baring in mind that the people who know this stuff at the IPCC say addressing AGW without CCS is 138% more expensive.

description: Josh Frydenberg talks up carbon capture and storage not because it’s effective but because it’s a point of political difference
og_fields.og:description: Josh Frydenberg talks up carbon capture and storage not because it’s effective but because it’s a point of political difference
og_fields.og:title: It'd be wonderful if the claims made about carbon capture were true | Simon Holmes à Court
text:
The International Energy Agency warned this week that, under current energy policies, Australia is unlikely to meet its 2030 climate commitments.
While the agency had lots to say about the plunging costs of renewables and the need for strong market signals to encourage the retirement of old and inefficient coal generation, Josh Frydenberg, the federal environment and energy minister, seized on the agency’s support for carbon capture and storage (CCS) – despite the technology’s long history of big promises and meagre results.
Last April, Frydenberg visited the newly opened Petra Nova CCS project in Texas. In a video posted to social media the minister, decked out in the obligatory hi-vis vest and hard hat, yells above the noise that the $1bn project is “helping to reduce the carbon footprint by some 40%”.
It’d be wonderful if it were true.
An estimated 6.2% of the Petra Nova power station’s emissions are captured, compressed and then piped 130km to help extract stubborn oil out of a depleted oil field. In the process, an estimated 30% of the carbon dioxide leaks back into the atmosphere, not to mention the emissions that will ultimately be released when the extracted oil is consumed.
Last month, the Minerals Council of Australia was spruiking the “21 large-scale CCS facilities in operation or under construction around the world including in Canada and Texas”.
Sounds impressive, if you still trust the MCA’s spin. You shouldn’t – 19 of the 21 projects have nothing to do with coal; there are exactly two “large scale” coal CCS projects globally. And, no, they’re not large.
The Canadian project, Boundary Dam, has averaged only 0.591 million tonnes of carbon dioxide over each of its first three years. The $1.5bn project would need to be scaled up 31 times to capture the emissions of New South Wales’s Bayswater power station – an inconceivable investment.
The only way CCS on coal will ever be built at scale is with a carbon price so high it’d kill the rest of the coal sector.
Petra Nova and Boundary Dam were built as demonstration projects, funded in an era when optimism for CCS was high and renewables costs were two-to-three times dearer than now. The owners of both projects have declined to invest further in the technology, having learnt the hard way that CCS doubles a coal power station’s capital and operating costs and is an outrageously expensive way to cut carbon pollution.
They’re not alone – data from the Australian headquartered Global CCS Institute shows there’s not a single large-scale CCS project under construction anywhere.
Over recent weeks we’ve seen the Minerals Council of Australia, the federal government and the International Energy Agency each make an effort to put CCS back on the agenda.
The MCA’s motivation is the easiest to understand. CCS provides a fig leaf useful for the “clean coal” campaign the MCA has been running, much to the chagrin of its largest funder BHP, in a desperate attempt to arrest coal’s flagging social license.
The only way CCS on coal will ever be built at scale is with a carbon price so high it’d kill the rest of the coal sector. Despite a tweet from the MCA on Thursday that it supported a “market based approach to low-emissions technology”, the MCA has form – it would use its dying breath to undermine any real or de facto carbon price. The MCA’s support for CCS rings hollow.
The rest of the coal industry doesn’t believe in CCS either. In 2006 the sector proudly announced Coal21, a commitment to invest $1bn over a decade on low emissions technologies. Ten years on, the industry has come through with less than a third of the promised funding. The only new spending in recent years from a fund designed to “support the pre-commercial demonstration of low emissions coal technologies” has been a series of pro-coal propaganda, including the “Coal – It’s an amazing thing” TV ads.
The federal government’s support is partly just an echo of the MCA’s talking points – a depressingly common pattern. Beyond that, the Coalition clearly believes that their pro-coal, anti-renewables position is a valuable point of political difference.
Despite the talk, the government is not gung-ho on CCS. Tony Abbott’s 2014 budget ripped $460m out of the CCS Flagships program, and the once ambitious project launched by Kevin Rudd has been on starvation rations since.
As for the IEA, their actual comments in support of CCS were pretty weak – executive director Fatih Birol did little more than endorse Frydenberg’s stalled plan from last May to lift the ban on the Clean Energy Finance Corporation (CEFC) providing loans to CCS projects.
But while the coal-boosters sully the brand, it should be remembered that CCS is not “bad” per se. CCS is a basket of technologies, some of which are likely to be important in the future as we work to decarbonise a range of industries with stubborn emissions, such as steelmaking and cement production.
It’s inconceivable that a CCS plus coal project could pass the CEFC’s rigorous investment criteria. As such it probably doesn’t matter whether or not the CCS prohibition is removed from the CEFC legislation. It’s just politics.
A total of 13 power stations have closed in Australia over the past five years, keeping tens of millions of tonnes of carbon dioxide and other pollutants out of our atmosphere. As AGL demonstrated this week, the economics are such that hard-nosed power companies are choosing renewables over coal every time.
One way to reduce coal’s impact is to capture, compress and bury its emissions – but it’s much simpler, cheaper and safer to simply leave the coal in the ground.

description: Australia sells South Korea $6bn of coal a year, so Canberra unease over the governor’s anti-coal message is unsurprising
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Australia sells South Korea $6bn of coal a year, so Canberra unease over the governor’s anti-coal message is unsurprising
og_fields.og:title: South Korea's Ahn Hee-Jung on coal trade: after Paris 'everything should change'
text:
For a South Korean presidential hopeful, Ahn Hee-Jung is not what you would expect.
He appears younger than his age of 52 years would suggest – an age that already makes him positively youthful by Korean political standards.
He has a casual demeanour, and before sitting down with the Guardian in the lobby of a hotel in Sydney, Australia, he is stopped by Korean tourists desperate to get a selfie with him – something he appears to enjoy but his minder says regularly delays him for meetings.
And for a governor of a province – South Chungcheong – that hosts the majority of South Korea’s coal power, with 29 massive coal power stations including the biggest in the world, he’s not who you would expect to be spearheading a “coal phase-out alliance” and declaring his province “post-coal”. But that’s exactly what he’s done.
On his visit to Australia, which sells more than $6bn worth of coal to South Korea each year, he has a message for the country and its precious coal exports: the world is changing and coal will soon be history.
“After the Paris agreement in 2015, I think everything should change,” he says. “Because after all, that is the global consensus, and that is the global commitment that involved countries have made.”
During South Korea’s Democratic party primary contest in 2017, Ahn took full advantage of his relative youth, and the exploding appetite for change in Korea.
Following the scandal that led to the impeachment of President Park, and the revelations she was allowing business conglomerates (known as “chaebols” – huge family-run conglomerates such as Samsung) to meddle in state affairs, his approach struck a nerve.
“Let’s change the world together with a young president, Ahn Hee-Jung!” the Korean press reported him saying at the launch of his presidential primary campaign. “We need a young leader who can create a new world with his mind, body and actions, not just someone who talks about new things. This the beginning of a shift into a new era.”
Ahn lost by a significant margin to Moon Jae-in, who went on to win the presidency, but through the contest Ahn became famed for his Obamaesque messages and his youthful demeanour.
Ahn’s distaste for coal appears shared by his party, and by President Moon. Since winning the presidency, the Moon administration has committed to building no new coal power stations, has been looking at how to halt the construction of partially built ones, and is expanding the country’s production of wind and solar.
Beyond the moves that South Korea is taking at a national level under the leadership of Moon, Ahn has personally spearheaded a regional network of sub-national governments that is aiming to make coal a thing of the past. 
At a forum of local governments his province hosted last year, Ahn launched what he describes as a “vision” for phasing out coal throughout East Asia.
He said he was committed to creating the “East Asia Coal Phase Out Alliance,” which would be a network of sub-national governments committed to phasing out coal.
Describing the group, Ahn refers to other moves around the world to achieve similar goals. He points to the “Powering Past Coal Alliance,” which aims to phase out reliance on coal power by 2030, and includes both national governments and subnational governments including Washington and Oregon in the US.
Ahn also refers to the Under2 Coalition, which includes a large range of subnational governments who have signed an agreement aiming to radically lower emissions in line with keeping global warming below 2C by 2100.
East Asian governments are under-represented in the Under2 Coalition, and a locally organised alliance could shift the balance.
Before interviewing Ahn, the Guardian was told by an officer at the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade that there was some concern there that the topic of the interview was coal.
Unease in Australian government circles about Ahn’s attitude to coal is not surprising.
Australia depends heavily on its thermal coal exports. It is the world’s second-biggest exporter of coal used for generating electricity (following Indonesia) and its exports primarily go to China, Japan and South Korea – with South Korea taking more than $6bn worth of coal each year.
But recent Australian government forecasts of increasing coal demand from South Korea have been brought into question following Korea’s anti-coal moves, and the more radical those moves, the faster Australian coal exports will decline.
Coal was no doubt among the issues Australian diplomats wanted to speak with Ahn about when they invited him. His visit was part of the “special visits program”, which the government says is targeted at “influential foreign officials … who are likely to be in positions which deal with issues of direct relevance to Australia’s foreign and trade policy interests.”
Meeting South Korea's Governor An Hee-jung to discuss working together to meet regional challenges & #WinterOlympics2018 ~🏂❄️🇰🇷🇦🇺 pic.twitter.com/nnGrchOsSo
Regardless, Ahn’s message remains clear while speaking with the Guardian. Asked whether Australia should prepare for a declining market for coal, Ahn encourages Australia to take action to implement the Paris agreement.
“Australia is also signed onto the Paris agreement, so under this agreement, I’m sure the Australian government and citizens of Australia are well aware of the commitment they made, and ... will be doing their part in order to implement [this] agreement into action,” Ahn says.
“I’m also a firm believer that this kind of energy transition will bring both crisis as well as opportunities. Crisis of course for the existing coal industries, but opportunities for everyone involved in the new renewable industry, as well as citizens around the globe as well.”
Ahn calls on Australia and South Korea to stand together and take leadership in the transition away from coal.
“I think it’s clear that by leading this kind of energy transition, those countries will be able to increase more jobs and create more added value,” he says.
“So as part of the Paris agreement, I think Australia and the Republic of Korea should stand next to each other and move forward together.”

description: Exclusive: Nearly 60 industrial sites get green light to increase emissions, cancelling out cuts paid for by Coalition using public money
og_fields.og:description: Exclusive: Nearly 60 industrial sites get green light to increase emissions, cancelling out cuts paid for by Coalition using public money
og_fields.og:title: Emissions increases approved by regulator may wipe out $260m of Direct Action cuts
text:
Nearly 60 Australian industrial sites have been given the green light to increase greenhouse gas pollution, potentially cancelling out hundreds of millions of dollars of public spending on emissions cuts under the Coalition’s Direct Action climate policy.
The increases have been quietly approved under the “safeguard mechanism”, which was introduced as part of Direct Action to ensure cuts paid for using the main part of the policy – the emission reduction fund – were not undone by emissions increasing in other parts of the economy.
Under the safeguard mechanism, government agency the Clean Energy Regulator sets an emissions limit for each large industrial site based on its highest level of emissions over the previous five years. But companies can apply to have the limit recalculated.
The regulator has signed contracts worth $2.25bn under the emissions fund, mostly with businesses that plan to plant trees and repair degraded habitat over the next decade. The idea is the vegetation will store carbon dioxide drawn from the atmosphere.
But an analysis of data on the regulator’s website by consultants RepuTex Carbon found the regulator had simultaneously allowed 57 industrial sites to increase emissions above their previous highest level.
If all sites emitted to their newly approved level, it could add up to 22m tonnes of carbon dioxide to the atmosphere each year – 4% of Australia’s annual emissions.
Based on the average price paid by the government – $11.90 per tonne of carbon dioxide – it would effectively cancel out up to $261.8m of emissions cuts a year.
Emissions growth is outpacing the abatement from the emissions reduction fund, so what has been the point?
This has prompted fresh accusations that Direct Action is doing little to curtail Australia’s emissions, which were already rising before a round of 44 industrial facilities had their emissions increases approved on 25 January.
The RepuTex executive director, Hugh Grossman, said it showed the safeguard mechanism was ineffective.
“It’s a safeguard in name only. There is no doubt emissions growth is outpacing the abatement from the emissions reduction fund, so what has been the point?” he said.
RepuTex found that by 2030, emissions from large industrial sites were projected to be 30% higher than in 2005, and 16% higher than when the safeguard mechanism was announced four years ago.
They are expected to grow to be the biggest source of Australia’s emissions, surpassing those from burning coal and gas for electricity. 
The biggest increases allowed under the safeguard mechanism have been for coalmining operations, including Whitehaven’s Maules Creek open cut mine in New South Wales, BM Alliance’s Broadmeadow mine in Queensland and Citic Pacific’s Sino Iron project in the Pilbara. Liquefied natural gas plants such as the projects of Chevron at Gorgon and Santos at Curtis Island have opened with approved emissions limits that are not offset elsewhere. 
Grossman said the industrial sector now posed a larger problem than electricity emissions, which had started to decline, though not quickly enough.
“It’s black and white – if industrial emissions are not resolved, we won’t meet our Paris commitments,” he said.
Under the 2015 Paris deal, Australia pledged to cut emissions by between 26% and 28% below 2005 levels by 2030.
The growth in industrial emissions suggests deeper cuts would be needed in other parts of the economy for that commitment to be met. But the government is not proposing deeper cuts in the electricity sector, currently the biggest emissions source. Under the national energy guarantee, it proposes to cut pollution from generators by 26% and is considering allowing electricity retailers to defer some cuts.
It is also considering making the safeguard mechanism less stringent. A Turnbull government climate policy review released in December suggested emissions limits could be loosened so they “increase with production, supporting business growth”.
The environment and energy minister, Josh Frydenberg, said the safeguard mechanism was operating in accordance with legislation, rules and regulations.
A spokeswoman for the Clean Energy Regulator said they included allowing reappraisal of how much a facility could emit if there was not enough historic data over the previous five years, or if the data did not accurately represent activity at the industrial site now. She said the safeguard mechanism was meant to make sure cuts paid for using the emissions reduction fund were not offset by “significant increases above business-as-usual levels”, but also to accommodate economic growth.
The Australian National University economist Paul Burke said the safeguard mechanism had been designed to be loose and flexible. “It is a complicated and inefficient way to approach the goal of reducing emissions,” he said.
Frydenberg said the mechanism was part of a suite of policies, including the successful emissions reduction fund, the renewable energy target and a national energy productivity plan, the details of which are yet to be released. He said contracts had been signed to cut emissions by 191m tonnes over the coming years, and the Climate Change Authority, a government agency, had found the fund was performing well.
The minister said Australia was on track to comfortably beat its 2020 target of a 5% cut below 2000 levels. He did not mention the 2030 target.
Environment department data released in December showed national emissions have increased each year since 2014, when the carbon price scheme that put a charge on greenhouse pollution was repealed. They rose 0.7% last financial year.
The department projects its current trajectory emissions will be about 2% higher in 2030 than in 2005.
RepuTex projects Australia will also fall short of its 2020 target of a 5% cut in absolute terms, with emissions expected to be at the same level as in 2000. But the country will meet its target under United Nations greenhouse accounting rules by using credits carried over from the previous target period, when Australia’s target was an 8% emissions increase between 1990 and 2012.

She has already been thoroughly excoriated in the comments in her earlier article on this subject. Is this an attempt at redemption? I repeat my comment in that earlier article:
"I did not hear Shorten's statement, but I gather that cherry picking just these couple of comments about Adani is hardly "fair and honest reporting". That is not what one expects of The Guardian.
The Carmicheal mine proposal is not " just another project" - providing the rail link opens up the whole of the Galilee Basin to mining which could result in devastating effects for our future climate. Yes, there is a future for coal for many years yet, but that future will be for the higher quality coking coal for which the Bowen Basin in Queensland is renowned. It is not for lower quality thermal coal. There are many large scale renewable projects planned for Queensland, so both Federal and State Labor would be well advised to start training the workforce for those jobs rather than propping up coal mining jobs. It is a pity that the CFMEU do not see this and start guiding their members into retraining for jobs in the renewable energy sector. This is the way to secure those crucial seats in Queensland, but there is some urgency required before the next Federal election".
And I stand by those comments. And remember, there are no jobs on a dead planet.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519036032000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12114642', u'id': u'112427280', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Michael Wilbur-Ham', u'text': u'As I said, I think that if all you can come up with to criticise the Greens is whaling, then that pretty much proves my point. 
I also note that you keep ignoring the ALPs long term support for increasing coal exports, their failure to take real action to prevent runoff killing the GBR, their failure to take real action to reduce carbon emissions, their failure to protect our farming land and forests and to reduce land clearing, and I could go on.

description: Mark Butler says development of Galilee basin is not in Australia’s national interests
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Mark Butler says development of Galilee basin is not in Australia’s national interests
og_fields.og:title: Labor MP says Adani mine would displace jobs and sabotage Paris targets
text:
The shadow climate change minister, Mark Butler, has warned the development of the Galilee basin is not in Australia’s national interest, because it would displace mining and jobs in existing coal regions, and would not help the world meet its obligations under the Paris climate agreement.
Butler has used a speech to the Sydney Institute to argue the controversial Adani coal project is “utterly exceptional” because it is the only significant export-oriented greenfields mine opening up “on the face of the planet”.
He said developing the Carmichael mine would fly in the face of current market trends, where export volumes for thermal coal had been flat for several years, and would also be inconsistent with the International Energy Agency’s advice “on what the world needs to do … to keep global warming well below two degrees”.
Butler said it was possible the Adani project “might notionally go ahead if the Turnbull government finds some way of throwing a heap of taxpayer money at it” but he argues the industry is clear Adani would have a zero sum effect, displacing “coal and jobs in existing coal regions, like the Hunter Valley”.
“For the life of me, I can’t see how that prospect is in the national interest.”
Butler’s Sydney Institute speech on Monday night addressed broad-ranging questions associated with managing climate change-related financial risk – including the impact of climate change on balance sheets, on the insurance industry and the potential for future litigation to “recover damages for losses incurred as a result of climate change from people who should have prevented those losses from occurring”.
But his public intervention comes at a time when federal Labor is mulling specific policy options on the Adani project. The Labor leader, Bill Shorten, has been signalling since late January that the ALP is inclined to toughen its stance on the Adani project.
While parliamentarians in Canberra have been telegraphing a shift, last week the powerful mining union said that adopting a hardline stance on Adani would damage Labor’s political fortunes in Queensland and also trigger a divisive debate within the ALP about the future of coal.
Shorten will spend the week in marginal Queensland coastal electorates, highlighting local infrastructure commitments and what he characterised on Monday as “real blue-collar jobs” and the next “pipeline of work”.
Before Butler’s speech on Monday evening, Shorten told reporters in Townsville there was a role for mining in Australia, and “there is a role for coal in Australia, and he echoed CFMEU national president Tony Maher’s description of Adani last week as just “another project”.
Labor’s positioning on Adani is under way as a critical byelection looms in Melbourne’s northern suburbs. The 17 March contest in Batman is a head-to-head between Labor and the Greens. The Greens have been running an anti-Adani campaign against Labor within the Batman boundaries for months, amplified by activist groups.
Butler has been pushing for federal Labor to adopt a tougher line on the Adani project for the best part of 12 months. In an interview last June with Guardian Australia’s politics live podcast, he declared it would “not be a positive thing for Australia for the Adani mine to go ahead”.
He dug in behind those arguments on Monday night. “In all of the many discussions I’ve had over recent years with different interests about the Galilee basin projects, a consensus view has been put that they are simply not financially viable – that the cost of developing the new mines cannot be recouped from a declining market with a thermal coal price projected to be in the doldrums for years.”
Butler acknowledged that jobs was a major political issue in Queensland. “There’s clearly a great deal of frustration in Queensland about the constant delays and debate about the Adani project, and whether the promised jobs will ever really happen,” he said.
“In a region that’s been hit hard by the end of the mining boom, job opportunities are crucially important.”
Butler said Shorten was not willing “to wait on Adani’s continual delays with this project – delays that will likely come to nought anyway”.
“He’s busy talking to the Queensland government and local communities about other job plans,” Butler said. “And he’s putting concrete announcements before the people of central and north Queensland as we speak – jobs that we guarantee will happen.”
On the more broadranging topic of managing climate change risk, Butler used the speech to warn that “one-eyed reliance on scenarios that pretend that the world is not changing is simply unsustainable and, potentially, legally negligent”.
“Investors are already voicing their expectations that companies do better in this area. But government and regulators clearly have a role to play in improving standards as well.”

article_tags: [Climate change, Air transport, Environment]
description: From rising temperatures preventing take-off to rising seas flooding runways, aviation needs to adapt to changes already grounding flights around the world
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: From rising temperatures preventing take-off to rising seas flooding runways, aviation needs to adapt to changes already grounding flights around the world
og_fields.og:title: Climate change spells turbulent times ahead for air travel
text:
Phoenix gets hot. But not usually as hot as last June, when the mercury at the airport one day soared above 48C. That exceeded the maximum operating temperature for several aircraft ready for take-off. They didn’t fly. More than 50 flights were cancelled or rerouted.
Thanks to climate change, soon 48C may not seem so unusual. Welcome to the precarious future of aviation in a changing climate. As the world warms and weather becomes more extreme, aircraft designers, airport planners and pilots must all respond, both in the air and on the ground. With about 100,000 flights worldwide carrying eight million passengers every day, this is a big deal.
Why is heat a problem for planes? In a word: lift.
Lift is the upward force created by diverting air around wings as an aircraft moves down the runway. It is harder to achieve when the air is scorching hot, because hot air is thinner than cold air. The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) warned in 2016 that as a result, higher temperatures “could have severe consequences for aircraft take-off performance.”
Aircraft will need to jettison passengers, cargo or fuel to get the same lift on a hot day, raising costs and requiring more flights.
“Weight restrictions are likely to have the most effect on long-haul flights, which often take off near the airplane’s maximum weight,” says Ethan Coffel, an atmospheric scientist at Columbia University. “Possible adaptations include rescheduling flights to cooler times of the day or lengthening runways.”
Daytime heat is why long-distance flights out of the Middle East already regularly take off in the cool of the night. But the same will soon apply in the US and southern Europe. That will create problems in places where night and early-morning flights are restricted to help people on the ground sleep.
Future lighter and more fuel-efficient planes will help, says Coffel. But it means the anticipated economic and environmental gains from such advances may be largely offset by coping with warmer air.
Once in the air, flying will feel different too, especially in and around the jet stream, for instance when crossing the Atlantic.
“At cruising altitudes, the north-south temperature difference that drives the jet stream is increasing,” says Paul Williams, a professor of atmospheric science at the University of Reading in the UK. Flying east is becoming quicker in the stronger winds that result, but flying west will be slower. Airline schedulers will need to take the altered flight times into consideration in the future – and flyers may need to be prepared for more frustrating airport announcements of delayed incoming flights.
Flights will also be bumpier, says Williams. “Stronger winds will increase the amount of shear in the jet stream,” he says. Shear creates turbulence – particularly what is called “clear-air turbulence,” which occurs away from storm clouds and is hard for pilots to spot and fly round. “The increase in clean-air turbulence has the potential to be quite disruptive,” says Williams. In other words, get used to keeping your seatbelts fastened.
Climate change will also increase the number and intensity of thunderstorms, and push them upward into cruising altitudes. That will make flying trickier and could dramatically increase the risk of one of the most worrying upper-air phenomena for pilots: high-altitude icing.
High-altitude ice is a feature of thunderstorms, and it is dangerous. The infiltration of tiny particles of ice into turbofan engines has been blamed for more than 100 engine failures in recent years.
In the most notorious high-altitude icing accident, an Air France flight from Rio de Janeiro to Paris in 2009 crashed, killing all aboard, when it stalled after the autopilot disconnected when ice crystals disabled its speed sensors.
Officials of the European Aviation Safety Agency have blamed climate change – along with the failure of aircraft designers to reassess the risks – for the growing frequency of engine failures and other faults due to high-altitude icing. Worryingly, modern energy-efficient lean-burn engines may be more susceptible, Herbert Puempel, an aviation expert at the World Meteorological Organization, warned in the group’s journal.
Some of the most expensive climate-change problems for the aviation industry will be on the ground. That’s because many runways are in places they really shouldn’t be.
Take Iqaluit airport in northern Canada. The permafrost on which it was built is melting. The runway and taxiway have had to be resurfaced as a result. And the melting is deepening.
There will be other such cases. But a more frequent problem is likely to be flooding. Many airports are built on flat, low-lying land, by the ocean or in drained swamps. Such places can be hard to drain and vulnerable to rising sea levels and more intense storms.
When Superstorm Sandy hit New York City in 2012, a storm surge 12ft high inundated the runways of LaGuardia, closing the airport for three days. A tropical storm hitting so far north is widely regarded as an effect of climate change. So expect more such extreme weather.
LaGuardia certainly is. Two-and-a-half years after Sandy struck, New York governor Andrew Cuomo put aside $28m to install new flood barriers and drains at the airport.
Sandy was a wake-up call. A federal climate assessment subsequently found 13 major US airports at similar risk, from Honolulu to Miami. Included in the list are San Francisco and Oakland airports, both built on low-lying reclaimed land along the shore of San Francisco Bay.
Civilian airport authorities have been slow to address the issue, but the US military is more proactive. A Pentagon analysis of climate-related risk to military infrastructure, published in January this year, gave pride of place to threats to airfields from sea level rise, storms and high temperatures.
Internationally, there is also rising concern. The scientific consensus is that sea level rise probably won’t be more than one metre this century. But airport authorities believe that they must adapt to much higher waters during storm surges such as that experienced at LaGuardia.
Singapore’s Changi airport, one of the world’s busiest, is raising its new passenger terminal 5.5m above sea level as a precaution against future storm tides. Hong Kong is constructing a wall, eight miles (13km) long, around a new runway.
By those standards, dozens of the world’s great airports should be thinking about runway protection. Bangkok, Schiphol in the Netherlands, Sydney, both airports in Shanghai, London City airport and Kansai near Osaka all fall short.
Maybe more radical solutions are required. Back in the 1990s, Japan built a 1km floating airstrip in Tokyo Bay as a “scale model” for a full-size floating airport that could rise with the tides.
Whether the threat is too much heat for take-off, too much ice to stay in the air or too much water to land, most airports and airlines are approaching climate change as a problem they will address as it arises. But the stark truth, says Coffel, is that the future is now.

Perhaps he's trying to reply to TT, in the manner "so (you think) that this .... is mere catechism, do you?" for example.
I did learn something about the concept "triple point" which I am still figuring out, Triple point has been described as the combination of atmospheres and temperature which governs the changes of state in elements and compounds. Atmospheric pressure in the case of the phase change from liquid to gas for example seems to apply to the distinction between CO2 as gas and as vapour. This may also be related in some way to the loss of ice where it seems ice can transform from solid to water vapour at low temperatures.

As for literature i havent got any references handy but surely easy to find via google scholar', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519553051000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17722198', u'in_reply_to': u'112681694', u'id': u'112685122', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'paulchevin', u'text': u'I have spent a little more time this morning looking through the emails from the authors of the Gergis et al paper that McIntyre posted links to on his blog Climate Audit.
I think perhaps the most telling was some advice that Michael Mann gave David Karoly when it became obvious that there was a problem with the paper. He said of McIntyre:
"I probably don't have to tell you this, but don't trust him to behave ethically or honestly here, and assume that anything you tell him will be cherry-picked in a way that maximally discredits the study and will be leaked as suits his purposes."
..... and that appears to be precisely the way things played out. 
What the emails show is scientists trying to do their job, who found a mistake in their work and asked for the paper to be put on hold. Indeed, as Karoly said several times in emails, the fact that they put the paper on hold is "a demonstration that science works".
There is nothing in the emails (which were a private and frank exchange of views) to suggest that the scientists knew of the issue via Climate Audit before they found it themselves, yet McIntyre (and hence Klapper) has found a way to make it appear otherwise on his blog. What stands out for me in this is that McIntyre only referred in passing to probably the most significant email of all that was buried 77 pages into a long pdf document: an email that he must have known would undermine his narrative..... and there were others that did too.
As far as I'm concerned, McIntyre's behaviour here was inexcusable, but sadly it only reinforces my previous experience of his blog. Equally sadly, it is entirely typical of the oil-funded climate science denial movement more generally; they ought to be ashamed of themselves.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519551788000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16473314', u'in_reply_to': u'112669974', u'id': u'112683930', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID2310987', u'text': u'You didn't actually present any evidence. "I don't even know why I continue to argue with you about this, since in this application the detrended method is so obviously the right choice (and the one that Gergis et al started with)."
Exactly....... and I wasn't arguing with you over it either! Clearly, even Neukom thought that was what they were doing when the paper was first approved in 2012. The point I was making, which I think you missed, is that the hockey stick shape actually exists because of the large increase in temperature during the instrumental period.
"We shouldn't question the competence and integrity of scientists?"
Certainly not based on an inadequate knowledge, no! For the record, a lot of the scientific community have profound concerns about Judith Curry, because it's clear even to me that a lot of what she says lacks the scientific insight and objectivity that could reasonably be expected of someone with her experience.

I'm not interested in your hurt feelings. I simply don't care what other people think of me. That's one reason I don't hide behind a fake name.
I once demanded to know when Prof Bob Carter would admit he was wrong; he had a heart attack a few weeks later and died. A few weeks later I had an argument with my best mate. Sadly he died in his sleep a week later. That was tough. I have cut myself off from friends I've known most of my life. Man faces an existential threat; I may not be able to do much but I won't tolerate bullsh1t from anyone anymore.
So let's try again. Your pride is more important than your grandchildren's lives. The notion you are correct and science is wrong is preposterous but you can't admit it such is your arrogance. It's not as if you understand the science. You just pick at loose threads, but the rich tapestry won't unwind.
You are just wrong and too stubborn to admit it.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519505847000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4446531', u'in_reply_to': u'112659215', u'id': u'112665580', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DennisHorne', u'text': u'I don't claim to know much science but I know what it looks like and where to find it. I also know a bit about the history of climate science, and about the tobacco-industry playbook the fossil fuel industry used to bamboozle the public.
I know about this because I used to be a denier. My position was reinforced by knowing Prof Bob Carter and other PhDs from Cambridge U who were deniers. It was only when I started looking at the science myself, and fairly recently, I realised, to my horror, shame and embarrassment I had been conned. Me, a pragmatic dentist priding himself on his rationality, with an MSc even, had been totally and absolutely, humiliatingly wrong. Worse, because I had been busy trying to understand theoretical physics, I had avoided looking at climate science, because, even though I am a pilot and NZ has rapidly changing and unpredictable weather that catches a lot of pilots, I had zero interest in the subject.
The RS, NAS, AAAS, APS, ACS, ASA etc etc etc endorse the science. I know enough to see why. It is correct. The theory AGW has more scrutinised than any science we now call "Scientific Knowledge". It is as much a fact as plate tectonics and evolution. 
Fiddle all you like, but at end of the day you need to learn, because you are not an expert and only an expert is in any position to challenge the experts.
Just to be clear, I started doing science when I was about 9. I walked down the bottom of our garden, out the gate, across a field to my father's laboratory. I remember the day my father welcomed me, beaming, and mixed chemicals that changed colour. The assistant who taught me how to blow glass. My father proudly telling me the upper sixth chemistry teacher, himself a former scientist, had told him I was the only one in the class who really understood chemistry. The idea that people will be willing to "suffer" through the 99 times out of 100 that "the experts" are actually correct just for the satisfaction felt the 1 time that you realise at the end "Holy shit ! I was right and they were wrong !?!", even if it's over an incredibly minor point like a wrong reference, may be completely alien to your way of thinking but it isn't to mine (and, I believe, to many others).
Going through the process from "That CAN'T be right !" to "Can I reproduce their results ?" to "Oh ! So that's what actually happened !" almost always results in me learning something, even in the 99 times out of 100 when the "something" turns out to be "The experts were right, yet again" (which will modulate my future "That can't be right !" exclamations, at the very least).
I repeat, it's called "curiosity". The "Jean S" post on the Climate Audit "Name and Shame" thread was at 4:42PM EDT, or 10:42 PM Swiss time. My guess is Neukom saw the Jean S post late in the evening while checking on the latest on this ClimateAudit thread (for sure the team were following ClimateAudit and this thread in particular as of a few days earlier). Yes I do realize that. They didn't calibrate properly, so I suppose my statement should have read: "failure to properly calibrate" . In the 2016 version of the Gergis et al they resorted to some ad hoc rules, whereby the calibration procedure was not necessarily the same for all series, which goes to the whole issue of Steve McIntyre calls "ex post data selection". 
What they should have done, and what the journal asked them to do was re-submit a paper with the original intent (detrending prior to the selection filtering), but I think that gave them a non-hockey stick climate history for Australia/NZ, which they didn't want to show, so they made a complex new series selection rule set, something to the effect of choosing any positive result from the 8 or 6 nearest instrumental data grid cells (as opposed to just the nearest cell), but even then not all series were selected by these new rules.
What McIntrye is saying in his "ex post screening" comments, is that scientists should make the rules for input data filtering before looking at the data, let your algorithm select the data, process, and present the results. Of course this "blind" method of analyzing data shouldn't just apply to paleoclimate studies but medicine, sociology etc., hence his quote from scientists in another field at the top of the post I gave you the link to.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519480386000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3638543', u'in_reply_to': u'112652003', u'id': u'112657046', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'James Holland', u'text': u'Which is, of course, rather silly because his standard whinge is that the silly cif-ers exaggerate, mis-use or ignore the orthodox scientific position.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519480263000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'his standard whinge is that the silly cif ers exaggerate use', u'effect': u'which is of course rather silly'}], u'author_id': u'18387395', u'in_reply_to': u'112656911', u'id': u'112656994', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BuzzBloodOhio space', u'text': u'"No one is going to stake their reputation on an edifice of stinking fish."

Well here's just a small taster for this salesman:Just some of his green agenda money making...http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/earth/environment/climatechange/6496196/Al-Gore-profiting-from-climate-change-agenda.htmlHis own carbon footprint...https://youtu.be/h9R0JVCy578', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519399778000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12475077', u'in_reply_to': u'112615854', u'id': u'112629380', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'paulchevin', u'text': u'Right! I have found this email from Neukom to Gergis and Karoly, dated 6th June 2012 at 09.46:
"Hi Joelle and David ,As just discussed with joelle on skype , I found a mistake in our paper in journal of climate today. It is related to the proxy screening, so it is a delicate issue. In thepaper we write that we do the correlation analysis for the screening based on detrended (instrumental and proxy) data, but in reality we did not use detrended data.The origin of the mistake is that at the stage when we were writing the paper my approaches have already evolved and I had made the proxy selection for the SB reconstruction based on detrended data . I therefore had in my mind that we had done the same for Australasia months ago and was very negligent not to check this carefully.Using detrended data would only select very few proxy records that would not allow a reasonable reconstruction. I think it is basically justifiable to do the screening without detrending but changing these words may cause troubles.Fortunately we have not received the proofs yet. So my suggestion is to write to the editor, explain the mistake and ask for permission to correct the error, if necessary via sending it out to review again . I apologize for the mistake and the troubles it may cause and hope thatwe can find a good way to correct it."
So it is clear that the mistake was Neukom's and that it was entirely innocent. It is also clear that the intention was to contact the editor to change the paper rather than simply change a few words. Also, although Neukom may have spotted the issue after the problem was found by someone at Climate Audit, it would only have been by a few hours at most, given the time difference. So it is very unlikely that the scientists would have known the blogosphere had spotted the problem at that time.
So, did McIntyre post this highly significant email..... and if not why not?', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519470567000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'i', u'effect': u'troubles'}, {u'cause': u'it', u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'16473314', u'in_reply_to': u'112647846', u'id': u'112653463', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID2310987', u'text': u'Admit you either made something up or were gullibly passing on something you read on a denier site. Then we can move on.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519420352000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2515806', u'in_reply_to': u'112641606', u'id': u'112642024', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SoloLoMejor', u'text': u'Do you denounce him, let's see where you're coming from on Al Gore.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519419594000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12475077', u'in_reply_to': u'112641355', u'id': u'112641606', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'Among the many practical solutions to the world's dependence on fossil fuels to generate energy and for transport would be changes to tax structure and restrictions on CO2 emissions. Oil and gas producers are also subsidized by tax regimes that allow them to write off equipment costs as "investment" and there is that old favorite "oil depletion" allowance. Why should this industry be pampered? It's a big boy now.
Since you want to talk about divinity, what was your religion again, Orthodox Consumerism?', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519395749000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'112552132', u'id': u'112626385', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DennisHorne', u'text': u'Twinkle twinkle little star', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519394562000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4446531', u'in_reply_to': u'112617443', u'id': u'112625416', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'paulchevin', u'text': u'I haven't had time to go through everything yet, but there are a few points that need to be considered:
Gergis is based in Victoria, Australia, around 18 hours ahead of North America, where Climate Audit is based.
When writing scientific papers, much of the work is done by the lead author and some authors listed on the paper may not have as much input during preparation as you might imagine. It is entirely possible that one member of the team (probably Karoly) had a different understanding of what had been done and only realised this after publication. Scientists are not automatons; they are humans with all their failings (and internal politics!).
Scientists do have different opinions too...... eg. over whether detrending is better. Just because one member of the team agrees with McIntyre that detrending is better it doesn't mean that they all do. As Dennis pointed out, it actually made very little difference.
Considered in the context of the above, the account given by Gergis at the conversation could well be correct. Clearly, it isn't a complete account, but she is under no obligation to tell the whole story. So for me the real story here, once again, is the way denialist blogs have chosen to portray what happened as an attempt to deceive rather than considering the far greater probability that it was what Gergis said it was: a simple mistake (or maybe a misunderstanding).
Finally, I would point at that you accused Gergis et al of "failure to calibrate", but you must surely know that they couldn't have produced a reconstruction at all without doing so.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519467143000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'just one member of the team agrees with mcintyre that detrending is better', u'effect': u"it does n't mean that they all do"}], u'author_id': u'16473314', u'in_reply_to': u'112647846', u'id': u'112652003', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SoloLoMejor', u'text': u'Nothing wrong with all that Chris except the rich will keep on doing it while the rest of us mugs have to factor in our energy usage into our everyday lives. There's a carbon trading market developing (Gore is in the front line for this bonanza), carbon futures, and a shift of economic production to the east. What they don't do is come up with a per human carbon allowance, which gives the peoples of the developing world the right to the same energy consumption we enjoy. In fact some of the leading oligarchs who own our governments are into outright eugenics who want the world population reduced because human beings are now seen as polluters. How quaint.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519394206000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'112610536', u'id': u'112625147', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'paulchevin', u'text': u'I will try to take a longer look at this later today if I get time. For now, all I will say is this:
A number of years ago I had reason to go through a whole series of blog posts at Climate Audit with a fine tooth comb. In each case I eventually found a fatal flaw that totally undermined the entire argument; the flaws were generally well hidden, but they were always there. Given that McIntyre was a reader of the George C Marshall Institute, which was deeply involved in climate science misinformation, this came as no surprise at all. So you will perhaps forgive me for not trusting the information that McIntyre has posted in this case either and we have no way of knowing for sure whether the information is even complete.
However, what I find most disturbing and distasteful is the attitude that the blog has. There is always an implicit assumption that scientists are being nefarious or deliberately hiding something rather than pursuing the respectful approach that ought to prevail. The cynic in me can't help but wonder whether this is a deliberate attempt to intimidate scientists and illicit an emotional response that can then be exploited. I note that Gergis contacted Gavin Schmidt for advice..... and frankly I don't blame her. Dennis is correct; if scientists had reason to think that McIntyre's interventions were a sincere attempt to make the science better, they would be only too happy to cooperate with him.
Ultimately what matters, of course, is that the paper was published and found much the same as it had before.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519462877000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16473314', u'in_reply_to': u'112647846', u'id': u'112650198', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DennisHorne', u'text': u'BQSTART

That's what happens when you get your information from dodgy blogs and YouTube. Gore's California home is 1504 east mountain drive. The clue to where that is relative to the beach is the address. I couldn't give a toss about Gore. He's just an American politician who has IMHO been a polarising influence on this debate. But I do care about the truth.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519418228000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2515806', u'in_reply_to': u'112640449', u'id': u'112640826', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'James Holland', u'text': u'No. But you knew that.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519392375000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18387395', u'in_reply_to': u'112613852', u'id': u'112623605', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DennisHorne', u'text': u'If climate scientists were dealing with other scientists trying to get to the truth instead of people whose sole purpose is to feed the liar-denier campaign of misinformation none of this would have happened.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519451666000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4446531', u'in_reply_to': u'112647846', u'id': u'112648160', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'I agree there is a difference between orthodoxy in the practice of an applied science like the medical treatment of stomach ulcers by general practitioners and an the state of knowledge within a field of scientific research such as climatology. description: John Abraham: Current temperatures are hotter than at any time in the history of human civilization
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: John Abraham: Current temperatures are hotter than at any time in the history of human civilization
og_fields.og:title: Pollen data shows humans reversed natural global cooling | John Abraham
text:
In order to understand today’s global warming, we need to understand how Earth’s temperatures varied in the past. How does the rapid warming we see now compare with past natural climate changes? Also, how long have humans been having an impact on the climate? These are some questions that can be answered through paleoclimate studies. Paleoclimate research uses natural measurements of the Earth’s temperature. Clever scientists are able to estimate how warm or cold the Earth was far back in time, way before we had thermometers. 
Readers of this column are probably familiar with some of these paleoclimate techniques that may use ice cores or tree rings to infer temperature variations. A different method that uses plant distribution was a technique used in a very recent study published in Nature. That technique used pollen distribution to get an understanding of where plant species thrived in the past. Those distributions gave them insights about the temperatures. On the surface, it’s pretty straightforward. Tropical plants differ in major ways from plants that live in, say, the tundra. In fact, plants that thrive where I live (Northern USA) differ from plants that populate landscapes further south.
The authors used the pollen of various plants to help determine where they thrived in the deep past. I communicated with Dr. Bryan Shuman, from the University of Wyoming and I asked him why they used pollen. He responded: 
Pollen works well as a temperature recorder because plants have specific temperature ranges that they can tolerate. By combining the temperature requirements for dozens of different plants that we can recognize from their pollen, we are able to narrow down the possible temperatures at the location where the pollen was collected. 
We use pollen rather than other plant fossils because pollen is widespread each spring and settles to the lake bottom where it is surprisingly resistant to degradation. We wash the samples of lake bottom mud with acids that can dissolve minerals, but the pollen can tolerate it. It lasts up to millions of years with degrading.
What the authors found was very interesting. Using data from 642 sites across North America and Europe, the temperatures they found closely matched those expected from computer simulations. They found that throughout most of the Holocene period (the last ~11,000 years), the Earth was warming very slightly. Only in the last ~2000 years has the Earth been in a cooling period (which probably would have continued except that human emissions of greenhouse gases have now reversed the cooling). 
The authors attempted to put the recent warming (last century or so) into context. They found that the recent temperatures are much higher than temperatures over the past 11,000 years. In fact, according to their calculations, 2016 was warmer than 99.41% of all simulated Holocene years. 
This finding is profound. First of all, it means that human greenhouse gas emissions were easily able to overturn what should be a natural cooling trend. Second, the warming we have caused is far outside of the natural range. According to Dr. Shuman: 
The major significance here is temperature across two continents over the last 11,000 years. The paper provides a geologically long-term perspective on recent temperature changes in the Northern Hemisphere and the ability of climate models, such as the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration and National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) models used in the study, to predict the changes. Climate simulations do a strikingly good job of forecasting the changes.
I would say it is significant that temperatures of the most recent decade exceed the warmest temperatures of our reconstruction by 0.5 degrees Fahrenheit, having few -- if any -- precedents over the last 11,000 years. Additionally, we learned that the climate fluctuates naturally over the last 11,000 years and would have led to cooling today in the absence of human activity.
People who deny or try to minimize the importance of human-caused climate change will often argue that climate changed naturally in the past. And while that’s true, we know the climate change is now being dominated by what humans are doing. That’s one clear result of this new paper. 
We have now pushed the Earth’s environment outside of where it should be. There are consequences for this disruption. Those consequences will include significant sea level rise, changes to rain/drought patterns, acidification of ocean waters, and a warmer atmosphere and ocean. There is still time to stop some of the coming climate change, but we are rapidly running out of time. The longer we delay, the worse things will get.

From light clothes in medieval times to fur in the 1500s, fashion reveals how climate has changed
The reality

Stop the pie in the sky, lets get real. I've been real.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519301890000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'112574183', u'id': u'112577367', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'My solutions are not pie in the sky because they work and allow myself and my to lead a comfortable and enjoyable life. I was one of many Australians who played a role in the 1980s of assisting the worlds largest country which had contained hundreds of millions of people in abject poverty make the necessary preparations to develop its economy. That was not just about access to energy, though that was what I was involved in. I remember hearing another public health endocrinology expert talk about the scale of thyroid malfunction and consequent cretinism in rural China - whole villages full of cretins. This bloke after many years of traveling to China finally a chance to speak to someone high in Politbureau with the result that a central government edict stipulated that the several thousand salt producers in that large country would add sodium iodide to their salt eliminating thyroid disorders and cretinism on a massive scale. A case of the command economy working. For economic success you need a healthy and well educated population as well as access to energy. As the Chinese are showing not all that energy need produce net CO2 emissions. We helped that country get the things that we've. Now days they come to our country in large numbers as tourist and a large percentage of our population are from the Chinese mainland or from nearby culturally Chinese countries and populations. Chinese per capita emissions are similar to those of the European Union or about half those of the US. Indian per capita emissions are one eight those of the US. India is also experiencing rapid economic growth and increasing its use of renewable energy particularly solar based but also hydro in the mountainous far north. Like much of Australia they have little need for heating over much of the country. The globally fair and realistic solution is for high per capita Co2 emitters such as the US and Australia to reduce their emissions at least to the level of the EU and China while lower emitters such as India who are experiencing economic growth increase theirs until we meet in the middle and come down to together. In China economic growth and CO2 emissions have been decoupled.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519301706000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'they work and allow myself and my to lead a comfortable and enjoyable life', u'effect': u'my solutions are not pie in the sky'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'112573874', u'id': u'112577191', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SoloLoMejor', u'text': u'Great posts Anthony. I think the more serious and sensible of the AGW co2 lobby cringe at Al Gore's absurd and proven-wrong projections, not to mention the hypocrisy of his massive personal carbon footprint and business dealings.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519299071000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12475077', u'in_reply_to': u'112571110', u'id': u'112574718', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SoloLoMejor', u'text': u'With all due respect, you've defeated me through sheer volume here, I'd prefer to wait for your memoirs.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519298493000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12475077', u'in_reply_to': u'112563845', u'id': u'112574183', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SoloLoMejor', u'text': u'Your "solutions" are pie in the sky. If this is a global problem it needs a global fair and realistic solution.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519298154000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12475077', u'in_reply_to': u'112572118', u'id': u'112573874', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Samuel', u'text': u'Nice to see you admit you are wrong about science again.
