You'll be quiet now, then, won't you?', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519297368000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13496713', u'in_reply_to': u'112571110', u'id': u'112573100', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"I want to hear your solution on global warming."
I told you mine and you said"good luck with your uncomfortable frugal guilt laden existence while the rich do what they like", having also claimed erroneously that I was proposing to tax the worlds poorest people, and that the possums under my house and my resident scrub turkey were a fantasy which may work with middle class hippy commune types, plus also erroneously claiming that I or my frugality had nothing to do with the building of hospitals, roads and universities my rapidly growing state where we have been building these things at a phenomenal rate. You completely ignored the fact that my worklife and frugality had enabled the poorest people in my region to climb out of poverty and contributed to our ability to grow food to feed the people of this planet but instead erroneously claimed the exact opposite.
All because I gave you a solution to the current global greenhouse warming.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519296340000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'all i gave you a solution to the current global greenhouse warming', u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'112553929', u'id': u'112572118', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Samuel', u'text': u'Deniers just don't like that Gore is essentially right and they are totally wrong.
BQSTART
The plaintiff sought to prevent the educational use of An Inconvenient Truth on the grounds that schools are legally required to provide a balanced presentation of political issues. The court ruled that the film was substantially founded upon scientific research and fact and could continue to be shown, but it had a degree of political bias such that teachers would be required to explain the context via guidance notes issued to schools along with the film. The court also identified nine of what the plaintiff called 'errors' in the film which were departures from the scientific mainstream, and ruled that the guidance notes must address these items specifically.
BQEND
Try again.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519295815000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13496713', u'in_reply_to': u'112571110', u'id': u'112571567', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Anthonyhu', u'text': u'I`ll fix your quote John with the rest of what Justice Michael Burton said 
BQSTART
"An Inconvenient Truth," while "broadly accurate," contained nine significant errors.
BQEND

BQSTART
1.) The sea level will rise up to 20 feet because of the melting of either West Antarctica or Greenland in the near future. (This "Armageddon scenario" would only take place over thousands of years, the judge wrote.) 
2.) Some low-lying Pacific islands have been so inundated with water that their citizens have all had to evacuate to New Zealand. ("There is no evidence of any such evacuation having yet happened.")
3.) Global warming will shut down the "ocean conveyor," by which the Gulf Stream moves across the North Atlantic to Western Europe. (According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, "it is very unlikely that the Ocean Conveyor will shut down in the future…")
4.) There is a direct coincidence between the rise in carbon dioxide in the atmosphere and the rise in temperature over the last 650,000 years. ("Although there is general scientific agreement that there is a connection, the two graphs do not establish what Mr. Gore asserts.")
5.) The disappearance of the snows on Mount Kilimanjaro is expressly attributable to global warming. ("However, it is common ground that, the scientific consensus is that it cannot be established that the recession of snows on Mount. Kilimanjaro is mainly attributable to human-induced climate change.")
6.) The drying up of Lake Chad is a prime example of a catastrophic result of global warming. ("It is generally accepted that the evidence remains insufficient to establish such an attribution" and may be more likely the effect of population increase, overgrazing and regional climate variability.)
7.) Hurricane Katrina and the consequent devastation in New Orleans is because of global warming. ("It is common ground that there is insufficient evidence to show that.")
8.) Polar bears are drowning because they have to swim long distances to find ice. ("The only scientific study that either side before me can find is one, which indicates that four polar bears have recently been found drowned because of a storm.")
9.) Coral reefs all over the world are bleaching because of global warming and other factors. ("Separating the impacts of stresses due to climate change from other stresses, such as overfishing and pollution, was difficult.")
BQEND
No need to thank me for doing it .........was a pleasure. The last time 44 post above the post of yours that I'm now replying to.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519294762000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'112547659', u'id': u'112570545', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'The lies about WMDs (weapons of mass destruction) in Iraq came from George W. Bush, the previous Republican president's, administration who were very critical of United Nuclear Disarmament Inspector Hans Blix in much the same way as the current Republican administration under Donald Trump has been critical of the UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) reports and recommendations and on the international agreements arising out of UN sponsored climate change conferences. The actions of the current US administration and those such as you who criticise international and UN reports on and constructive efforts to reduce CO2 emissions are what remind me of the WMD lies.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519293335000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'112503967', u'id': u'112569091', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'In regard to what climatologists have discovered about the current global warming and consequent climate change, you say "I don't like alarmism".

Yes. That's why we have roof insulation, secure cross ventilation, shade from a good canopy of rainforest trees, LED light bulbs, rooftop solar panels nearby and a small car.
I first came across bedroom mounted overhead fans in the 1980s when a girlfriend had them in hers. They are very good for the things that young people get up to. The old woman I took shopping has an overhead fan in her living but would never even consider sleeping with a pedestal fan let alone an overhead mounted one. She raised four kids on a wood machinist's wage plus some shop work and paid weekend gardening by her sadly departed husband and now pays half price as a pensioner for her electricity.
"Your follow up fantasy land of living with possums etc."
I just checked. The four possums living under my house are real Brush Tailed Possums. They're not a fantasy. There's a large dominant male. A female who always has a baby - very cute when they're out of the pouch and riding on their mother's back.And there's an absolutely geriatric old male with saggy marsupial balls - they hang from above the penis - who turned up in spring in the middle of the day. Someone must have turfed him out. The scrub turkey's not a fantasy either. He's currently over in the neighbor's yard raking her leaves. He been here since he hatched from the mound which he inherited upon his father's death.
"may well work for those middle class hippy commune types"
I never took to the hippy thing - too mainstream and wrapped up in my science. My friend who did came from a very working class background. My partner's teenage boyfriend was one of the people, in four different parts of the globe, credited with starting up what came to be referred to as punk rock. While he never accepted the term, he and she shared the punk disdain for hippies.
"who cleanse their conscience by living such a life"
It's a very good and downright enjoyable life but I can't what it has to do with me cleansing conscience or why I would feel any need to cleanse my conscience.
"but it won't get schools hospitals roads universities built or food grown to feed the planet."
The taxes I gladly paid through a lifetime of work got schools, hospitals, roads and universities built. My work at expanding universities as a researcher, teacher and staff representative helped get more of those universities built. By raising a daughter who has been a Minister for Education and a Minister for Innovation, I've indirectly assisted the building of universities. My work on public health and disease control stopped many people needing the facilities of a hospital by reducing the frequency of infectious diseases. I initiated of the financing of a major road intersection upgrade. I trained future agricultural scientists who went on to ensure we have enough food to feed the people on this planet and worked on diseases of livestock.
"It certainly won't allow the poorest half of the planet to climb out of abject poverty."
What I did at work helped the several billion people - half the people on the planet - in the countries of my region - climb out of abject poverty.
What I do at home is not very different to what some of the poorest people do in climates much like the one I live in. But what I did at work made a larger contribution.
 
 Actually, by reducing the need to build expensive coal fired power stations that private enterprise for economic reasons refuse to build, I've saved the Government money, allowing them to spend the money so saved on hospitals, roads, universities and research and projects which allow more food to be grown to feed the people on this planet.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519278921000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'112546023', u'id': u'112561332', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Anthonyhu', u'text': u'BQSTART

BQSTART
Here we show that even when scientists are motivated to promote the truth, their behaviour may be influenced, and even dominated, by information gleaned from their peers’ behaviour, rather than by their personal dispositions. This phenomenon, known as herding, subjects the scientific community to an inherent risk of converging on an incorrect answer and raises the possibility that, under certain conditions, science may not be self-correcting.
BQEND

"So, as 50% of the global accumulated wealth last year went to the 1%, you want to apply an energy tax on the world's poorest,"
I was taking about a price on carbon, not a tax. That price didn't apply to all sources of energy, just those that produced net CO2 emissions.
I've lived with some of the wold's poorest people and they don't live in Australia. So the carbon price I was talking about was not affecting the world's poorest people.
In my country, the people on lower incomes were reimbursed the increase in the cost of energy due to the carbon tax.
"knowing full well the rich will just carry on with their energy rich lives knowing they can easily afford it financially."
The rich often have large houses and cars. 
Their large houses have large air conditioners. When there was a price on carbon it applied to the wholesale price of electricity which increased the use of renewable energy sources within the Australian electricity network. So even the rich with high electrical energy use from the grid reduced their CO2 emissions.
Increased demand for fuel from the countries of my region, which once had contained the world's poorest people, increased the price on crude oil in the East. This resulted in prices increases in liquid fuel a order of magnitude greater than that caused by the price on carbon. In my country most of the rich can afford to live close to their place of work, so while they usually have parking supplied free of charge, they don't have a long commute by car.
Note my reasons for describing the advantages of our price on carbon have nothing to do with the accumulation of wealth by the 1%. Australia's richest person, who at times has been the world's richest woman, owns a large number of coal mines and opposed that price on carbon, financing the extreme right wing politicians who also opposed it.

I have not put forward a carbon tax. I have put forward a price on carbon combustion and the resultant net CO2 emissions and mentioned that when my country had a price on carbon our emissions dropped.
"which means that every joule of energy that you use will be subject to a tax."
Every joule of energy I used was not subject to a carbon price which is not a tax. There was no carbon tax.
The rooftop solar panels, which provide the joules of energy to power the overhead fans, household appliances, this laptop and the air conditioner on days when the wet bulb temperature exceeds 35 degrees C, attracted no carbon price. Neither did the windfarms and hydro-electric power stations that feed large amounts of power into the Australian electricity network. I didn't pay a carbon price on the joules of energy that heated the water from a rooftop solar hot water system.
With an only somewhat insulated house in the warm subtropics we have no need to consume joules of energy in heating our very small house. Here the largest peaks in electricity demand occur on very hot sunny days due to domestic air conditioner use. On such days rooftop solar panels provide carbon price free joules to power our small reverse cycle air conditioner. Without rooftop solar panels our electricity grid would not have sufficient supply to meet peak demand on hot sunny days.
In the same way as a modicum of insulation reduces the need to use joules of energy in domestic heating and cooling, the generous canopy of local rainforest trees on the northwest side of the house plus the secure through ventilation in that living area eliminates the need for air conditioner use on all but the hottest days. In winter the lower angled sunlight can be allowed into the living room to provide both warmth and light. The joules of energy from that sun are free.
So you are wrong. BQSTART
In the Northern Hemisphere, the atmospheric radiocarbon peak occurred in 1964 where the signal is preserved in European trees. That same peak took until late 1965 to reach the Southern Hemisphere atmosphere. With that, the signal became global, precise and detectable in the geological record, meaning it fitted the requirements as a marker for a new epoch.
BQEND

As for the Little Ice Age and related matters, there's lots of interesting material (far better that the article ATL) in this:
"Frost fairs, sunspots and the Little Ice Age" - Lockwood et al, 2017
A couple of useful quotes follow (but really those who are interested in these matters should read all of Lockwood et al, 2017 - it's an easy read)
BQSTART
Combining all the available chronicles, there are six reported severe winters in England in the 50 years prior to 1565 and six in the 50 years after. This is a much higher occurrence rate than we experience today, but it is not an ice age – little or otherwise.
BQEND
 
BQSTART
Thames freeze years are slightly more frequent before the Maunder minimum began and also considerably more common 65 years after it ended. The association of the solar Maunder minimum and the Little Ice Age is also not supported by proper inspection and ignores the role of other factors such as volcanoes.
BQEND

description: From light clothes in medieval times to fur in the 1500s, fashion reveals how climate has changed
headline: m
og_fields.og:description: From light clothes in medieval times to fur in the 1500s, fashion reveals how climate has changed
og_fields.og:title: Weatherwatch: fashion shines a light on climate change
text:
The history of fashion can give a fascinating glimpse of how climate has changed. Medieval times were notably mild and illustrations in manuscripts show people wearing light and loose clothes, without capes, fur or hats. That changed in the Little Ice Age, roughly spanning the 1300s to 1800s, which included some bitterly cold times.
Fashions responded, especially in the 1500s, when heavy textiles in clothes were used more widely. In Hans Holbein’s famous painting The French Ambassadors of 1533, the two courtiers wear thick dark velvets, fur-lined overcoats and fashionable caps. And some of the oldest surviving gloves, hats, capes and coats in museums come from those times. By Charles II’s reign in the second half of the 1600s, ladies’ gowns used layers of heavy fabric and gentlemen wore long coats, large breeches and wigs. And the muff handwarmer became popular, as Samuel Pepys noted on a bitterly cold day in November 1662: “This day I first did wear a muffe, being my wife’s last year’s muffe, this serves me very well.”
Other fashion accessories reflect the wet British climate – the Burberry, the Barbour, the wellington boot, and of course the umbrella, a foreign invention originally designed for keeping cool.

article_tags: [South Australian politics, Australia news, South Australia, Jay Weatherill, Energy, Climate change, South Australian state election 2018]
description: Premier’s position on oil drilling and fracking described as ‘disingenuous’ after debate
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Premier’s position on oil drilling and fracking described as ‘disingenuous’ after debate
og_fields.og:title: South Australia election: Jay Weatherill criticised over fossil fuel expansions
text:
The South Australian premier, Jay Weatherill, did not oppose some of the country’s largest fossil fuel expansions during an environment-focused election debate, prompting conservation groups to question his government’s leadership on climate change.
On Tuesday the leaders of the four most popular parties answered questions curated by OurFutureSA, a coalition of 33 climate and nature groups who say they collectively represent 130,000 members in South Australia.
“The single biggest environmental challenge in our state, the nation, the world is action on climate change,” Weatherill said. “And I’m proud to say that this state government is a leader not just in the nation but in the world.”
The state Labor leader listed his government’s achievements in renewable energy, which have attracted worldwide attention and proved popular with voters.
Weatherill said that those moves – which include shifting the state’s electricity supply from “basically 99% fossil fuels” to 48.9% – would be the dominant issues at voting booths.
“Make no mistake, this next election will be treated, whether we like it or not, as a referendum on renewable energy,” he said. “If we go down, they will be wagging their fingers at everybody around the nation, to say that’s what happens if you push too hard into renewable energy. That’s what the prime minister is trying to do and that’s what is going to happen.”
The audience applauded that statement but was less pleased when attention turned to large-scale fossil fuel expansions in the state.
Several companies including Statoil are lining up to explore for oil in the virtually pristine waters of the Great Australian Bight. The potential oil reserves there have been compared to the Gulf of Mexico, one of the world’s most productive off-shore oil regions.
Weatherill said he supported existing processes, where any application to drill for oil would be assessed by the federal regulator, the National Offshore Petroleum Safety and Environmental Management Agency.
The Liberal leader, Steven Marshall, took a similar line, while the SA Best leader, Nick Xenophon, and the Greens leader, Mark Parnell, repeated their opposition to the proposed drilling.
The parties lined up differently when it came to another proposed fossil fuel expansion – fracking in the state’s south-east.
The Liberal party has proposed a 10-year moratorium, supported by both the Greens and SA Best. The Labor party continues to support expansion of fracking there, despite strong community opposition based on fears about contamination of the water resources in the prime agricultural region.
“A government championing its climate change credentials while also pushing for massive expansions to the fossil fuel industry is pretty disingenuous,” said Peter Owen, the South Australia director of the Wilderness Society and spokesman for OurFutureSA.
“South Australia is currently supporting massive expansions to the climate damaging fossil fuel industry in the state’s south-east, north and offshore in the Great Australian Bight.
“This could lead to hundreds of times more carbon pollution than SA’s current emissions, completely undermining the government’s leadership position on renewables. We must stop the expansion of the fossil fuel industry to have any chance of providing our children with a liveable climate.” • This article was amended on 21 February. It previously incorrectly stated that Chevron was involved in oil exploration in the Great Australian Bight. Chevron abandoned plans to drill there in 2017.

article_tags: [Donald Trump, Trees and forests, US news, Environment, World news, Climate change]
description: Environmentalists say forest the size of Kentucky could compensate for ‘monumental stupidity’ of US withdrawal from Paris climate agreement
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Environmentalists say forest the size of Kentucky could compensate for ‘monumental stupidity’ of US withdrawal from Paris climate agreement
og_fields.og:title: Trees for Trump: 1m plants pledged to offset U-turn on climate change
text:
More than 1m trees have been pledged for Trump Forest, a bid by environmentalists to offset the US president’s curtailing of Obama-era clean energy initiatives by planting 10bn trees around the globe. 
“US president Donald Trump doesn’t believe in the science of human-caused climate change,” reads the website for the project, launched before Trump withdrew the US from the Paris climate accord.
“So we’re planting a forest to soak up the extra greenhouse gases Trump plans to put into our atmosphere. We’re planting a global forest to offset Trump’s monumental stupidity.”
The project was launched last March and in less than a year over a million trees have been pledged from people around the world, but particularly in the US and Europe. 
The donated trees are to go towards offsetting the 650m tonnes of CO2 that will be released into the atmosphere by 2025 if the president’s plans to backtrack on US climate commitments go ahead, organisers say. 
The figure of 650m tonnes – equivalent to the annual carbon footprint of 33 million Americans – is calculated from Trump’s decision to roll back the US 2015 Paris agreement pledge to lower emissions by at least 26% below 2005 levels by 2025.
It would take 10bn trees – covering a landmass roughly the size of the state of Kentucky – to offset the full amount.
“We’re really pleased at how quickly it happened,” co-founder Adrien Taylor told Newshub. 
“We’re just pleased to see we’re not the only people in the world who care about climate change, because sometimes it can feel like that.”
The project’s co-founder, British climate scientist Dr Dan Price, said: “In 30 years from now, when people look back on the Trump presidency as an attack on the planet and on rational thought, it would be pretty cool if the history books say his actions were negligible because the global community offset the administration’s additional emissions.
“It’s clearly a big challenge, but only recently the world record was broken when India put 66m trees in the ground in a day. If we all chip in, it is a completely realistic goal.”

article_tags: [Polar regions, Climate change, Antarctica, Climate change, Environment, Science, World news]
description: British Antarctic Survey is trying to reach a newly revealed ecosystem that had been hidden for 120,000 years below the Larsen C ice shelf
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: British Antarctic Survey is trying to reach a newly revealed ecosystem that had been hidden for 120,000 years below the Larsen C ice shelf
og_fields.og:title: Scientists race to explore Antarctic marine life revealed by giant iceberg
text:
A team of international scientists is due to set off for the world’s biggest iceberg on Wednesday, fighting huge waves and the encroaching Antarctic winter, in a mission aiming to answer fundamental questions about the impact of climate change in the polar regions.
The scientists, led by the British Antarctic Survey (BAS), are trying to reach a newly revealed ecosystem that had been hidden for 120,000 years below the Larsen C ice shelf on the Antarctic peninsula.
In July last year, part of the Larsen C ice shelf calved away, forming a huge iceberg - A68 - which is four times bigger than London, and revealing life beneath for the first time.
Now scientists say it is a race against time to explore these new ecosystems before they are transformed by exposure to the light.
Marine biologist Dr Katrin Linse from the BAS is leading the mission which sets off on a voyage across the Southern Ocean from the Falklands Islands on Wednesday. They expect to reach the iceberg within a week. 
“The calving of A68 provides us with a unique opportunity to study marine life as it responds to a dramatic environmental change,” she said. “It’s important we get there quickly before the undersea environment changes as sunlight enters the water and new species begin to colonise … It’s very exciting.”
Prof David Vaughan, science director at BAS, said: “We need to be bold on this one. Larsen C is a long way south and there’s lots of sea ice in the area, but this is important science, so we will try our best to get the team where they need to be.”
He said climate change had already affected the seas around Antarctica and is warming some coastal waters.
“Future warming may make some habitats warm. Where these habitats support unique species that are adapted to love the cold and not the warm, those species are going to either move or die. How fast species can disperse, and how fast ecosystems can colonise new areas, is key to understanding where the Antarctic is likely to be resilient, and where it is vulnerable.”
Last week the Guardian printed the first images of creatures found in a previously unexplored region of the Antarctic seabed, taken during a Greenpeace research expedition to the Antarctic which is part of a wider campaign to turn a huge section of the region into the world’s biggest ocean sanctuary.
Speaking onboard the Greenpeaceship Arctic Sunrise, the group’s head of oceans, Will McCallum, said there was “still so much left to learn about ocean life here in the Antarctic”.
“From hidden ecosystems revealed by calving icebergs, to our research missions to the seafloor which have found an abundance of rare and vulnerable species - this place is bursting with life and a vast Antarctic Ocean sanctuary would help us protect it in all its forms.” 
There is growing concern about the possible impact of climate change in the Antarctic.
Earlier this month, a report revealed that melting ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica are speeding up the already fast pace of sea level rise.
The research published by the National Academies of Sciences said, at the current rate, the world’s oceans will be on average at least 60cm (2ft) higher by the end of the century.
However it found that the process is accelerating, and more than three-quarters of the acceleration since 1993 is due to melting ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica, the study shows.
Experts say the area around the Antarctic peninsula has seen widespread ice shelf decay and collapse in recent decades, leading to “glacier acceleration” and increased discharge of ice from the Antarctic continent into the sea.
However scientists are wary of attributing the calving of the Larsen C iceberg directly to global warming. 
Adrian Luckman, professor of glaciology at Swansea University and leader of a project studying the state of the ice shelf, said: “Whilst the Larsen C ice shelf has reduced in area since records began, suggesting that over the long-term the environment of the Antarctic peninsula is becoming less able to support ice shelves, we have no evidence to link this particular calving event to changing conditions. Iceberg calving is a natural part of the ice shelf cycle and, whilst large, the calving of A68 is not unprecedented.”

article_tags: [Environment, Trump administration, Climate change, US news, US politics]
description: A cascade of courtroom standoffs are beginning to slow, and even reverse, the EPA rollbacks thanks to the administration’s ‘disregard for the law’
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: A cascade of courtroom standoffs are beginning to slow, and even reverse, the EPA rollbacks thanks to the administration’s ‘disregard for the law’
og_fields.og:title: 'Sloppy and careless': courts call out Trump blitzkrieg on environmental rules
text:
In its first year in office, the Trump administration introduced a solitary new environmental rule aimed at protecting the public from pollution. It was aimed not at sooty power plants or emissions-intensive trucks, but dentists.
Every year, dentists fill Americans’ tooth cavities with an amalgam that includes mercury. About 5 tons of mercury, a dangerous toxin that can taint the brain and the nervous system, are washed away from dental offices down drains each year.
In Trump’s first day in the White House, the administration told the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to withdraw an Obama-era plan that would require dentists to prevent this mercury from getting into waterways. But in June, the rule was unexpectedly enacted.
This apparent change of heart followed legal action filed by green groups, part of a cascade of courtroom standoffs that are starting to slow and even reverse the Trump administration’s blitzkrieg of environmental regulations.
“The Trump administration has been sloppy and careless, they’ve shown significant disrespect for rule of law and courts have called them on it,” said Richard Revesz, a professor at the New York University school of law. 
“I expect we will see a number of further losses for the administration on similar grounds. If they keep showing the same disregard for the law, their attempt to repeal all these environmental regulations will go badly for them.”
The reversal of Obama’s environmental legacy has been spearheaded by Scott Pruitt, who heads the EPA, the agency he repeatedly sued as Oklahoma attorney general. Pruitt, who accused Obama of “bending the rule of law” and federal overreach, has overseen the methodical delay or scrapping of dozens of rules curbing pollution from power plants, pesticides and vehicles.
Ironically for Pruitt, who has touted a “back to basics” approach rooted safely within the confines of the law, this rapidly executed agenda has run into a thicket of legal problems, causing the administration to admit defeat in several cases.
In July, a federal court ruled that the EPA couldn’t suspend rules designed to curb methane emissions from new oil and gas wells. This was followed by a hasty retreat in August when the EPA agreed to not delay new standards to reduce smog-causing air pollutants, the day after 15 states and environment groups sued. 
Then, in December, a federal court told the EPA it couldn’t delay a new standard for dangerous levels of lead in paint and dust.
Other arms of the federal government have also been stymied from implementing Trump’s deregulatory agenda. The US Fish and Wildlife Service, stung by a lawsuit, listed the rusty patched bumblebee as endangered in March after initially delaying the decision. And on Thursday, a federal court told the department of energy it must implement four energy efficiency regulations it was looking to scuttle.
Many of these legal problems have stemmed from the sheer pace of the rollbacks – required public comment periods have been set aside in some cases, any rationale for repeal or delay has been missing in others. Opponents of the administration also believe there is a determination to expunge every vestige of Obama’s environmental legacy, regardless of merit.
“They are trying to score political points or attempting to grant favours to corporations who don’t want to follow the rules,” said Aaron Colangelo, the litigation director of the Natural Resources Defense Council. “It all shows that this administration won’t protect the environment unless they are sued. They have been reckless and not followed the basic requirements of the law.”
The EPA now faces a fresh wave of opposition as it looks to craft replacements for major Obama rules such as the clean power plan, which sought to limit emissions from coal-fired power plants, and the waters of the US rule, which greatly expanded clean water protections.
If the proposed replacements are, as expected, far less onerous on industry than current iterations, environmentalists and around a dozen states, headed by New York and California, will be poised to further jam up the process in the courts.
“Over and over again, the Trump administration has put the profits of multinational polluters over the health and well-being of everyday Americans,” said Eric Schneiderman, New York’s attorney general. 
Schneiderman has been prolific in opposing Trump’s environmental revisions, filing more than 50 lawsuits during the administration’s first year to, among other things, protect the clean power plan, enforce stricter vehicle pollution standards and ensure that chlorpyrifos, a common pesticide linked to neurological harm to children, is banned.
“We’ve already beaten back several of this administration’s toxic policies, from energy efficiency rollbacks to smog,” Schneiderman said. “Our fight to protect public health and our environment will continue in court.”

http://www.climatechangenews.com/2012/05/23/coastal-seagrass-could-store-more-co2-than-forests/The study, published in the journal Nature Geoscience, found that coastal seagrass beds could store up to 83,000 metric tonnes of carbon per square kilometre – mostly in the soils beneath.This is compared to a typical terrestrial forest which stores about 30,000 metric tonnes per square kilometre – mainly in the form of wood.
https://phys.org/news/2017-08-biodiversity-negates-carbon-storage-seagrasses.htmlSeagrass meadows are great absorbers of carbon dioxide from the air. But the algae, animals, corals and plants that live among them release large amounts of carbon dioxide, according to newly released research. The scientists are now identifying seagrass locations with fewer emitters to target for conservation.
http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0181386Contribution of seagrass plants to CO2 capture in a tropical seagrass meadow under experimental disturbance', u'recommendation_count': u'16', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519169997000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4446531', u'id': u'112507569', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}]
description: Seagrass shelters fish and acts against erosion and climate change, but is under threat
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Seagrass shelters fish and acts against erosion and climate change, but is under threat
og_fields.og:title: Plantwatch: seagrass meadows are vital – but in serious decline
text:
Meadows of seagrass are one of our great but sorely neglected wild plant spectacles. This humble plant spreads out in lush green carpets that can stretch for miles around much of Britain’s coast. There they shelter young fish and shellfish, as well as protecting against erosion of the coast by storms and floods, by trapping sediment in their roots.And the seagrass meadows also play a big part in fighting climate change. They soak up carbon dioxide and hold tremendous stores of carbon on the sea floor, more than twice the carbon stored by a forest of similar area. And across the world, seagrasses are believed to lock away more than 10% of all the carbon buried each year in the oceans.
Seagrasses around the UK are in serious decline, though, and their immense reservoirs of carbon are being released. Development and dredging are to blame, as well as pollution from sewage and farming washing huge amounts of nutrients into the sea, which kills the seagrasses. Old sewage plants overflow with untreated sewage during heavy rainfalls, which is illegal but common. And excessive nutrients from livestock waste slurry runs off into rivers and ends up in the sea.

- he wasn't a left ideologue, Communist or post-modernist, whose real motivation was envy and contempt for Christianity and the middle-class, not love for the working-class and poor
- he wasn't a LGBT activist/Marxist feminist/"Progressive", hell bent on the destruction of the family because of their hatred for men
- he wasn't an intersectionalist looking for someone to blame for his own suffering
- he worshipped a God who loves all people, not the god of identity politics that seeks to divide.
He had a belief that all people are created in the image of God and that personal responsibility, strong families, objective moral standards, healthy patriotism and a love for God were better vehicles for changing the world than atheism, naturalism, moral relativism, nihilism, Communism, and the destruction of families and the murder of hundreds of millions of people. description: Racial tensions are rising, the earth is warming, and evangelicals are doing little to help. That may be Graham’s most significant, and saddest, legacy
og_fields.og:description: Racial tensions are rising, the earth is warming, and evangelicals are doing little to help. That may be Graham’s most significant, and saddest, legacy
og_fields.og:title: Billy Graham was on the wrong side of history | Matthew Avery Sutton
text:
When Billy Graham stands before the judgment seat of God, he may finally realize how badly he failed his country, and perhaps his God. On civil rights and the environmental crisis, the most important issues of his lifetime, he championed the wrong policies.
Graham was on the wrong side of history.
The world’s most famous evangelist let his apocalyptic anticipation of the coming kingdom of God blind him to the realities of living in this world.
For Graham, the Bible had a clear message for Christians living in what he believed were humans’ last days on earth. Individuals alone can achieve salvation; governments cannot. Conversions change behaviors; federal policies do not. 
These convictions shaped the evangelist’s views on civil rights.
In the late 1950s, Graham integrated his revivals and seemed to support the burgeoning civil rights movement. This is the Graham most Americans remember.
But as the movement grew, expanded and became increasingly confrontational, the evangelist’s position changed.
Once leaders like Martin Luther King Jr began practicing civil disobedience and asking for the federal government to guarantee African Americans’ rights, Graham’s support evaporated.
Within days of the publication of King’s famous 1963 Letter from a Birmingham Jail, Graham told reporters that the Baptist minister should “put the brakes on a little bit”.
He criticized civil rights activists for focusing on changing laws rather than hearts.
In 1971, Graham published The Jesus Generation, a book on the coming apocalypse. Looking for signs of Jesus’s second coming had become an obsession of Graham’s, as it was for millions of other evangelicals in the mid-20th century.
In the book, Graham praised the wisdom of young people who rejected the federal government as a tool for rectifying injustices.
Graham had the opportunity to lead fundamentalists into a new era, but he squandered it
“These young people don’t put much stock in the old slogans of the New Deal, the Fair Deal, the New Frontier and the Great Society,” he said. “They believe that utopia will arrive only when Jesus returns. Thus these young people are on sound Biblical ground.”
For six decades, Graham taught Americans that the federal government could not be an instrument of God to bring about justice, not on race matters and not on other significant issues. Although he believed in racial equality, his theology blinded him to what we now know was the best means for achieving that equality.
More recently, the evangelist denied the threat of global warming and rejected federal efforts to stymie it.
In a 1992 book focused on the signs that the world was nearing its end, the preacher suggested that if humankind were going to survive, businesses needed to reduce pollution and stop contributing to global warming.
In a revised 2010 version of the book, Graham eliminated the phrase “global warming” from the text altogether. Global warming no longer existed in the mind of Graham as a real threat.
He went on to assure readers that the earth would not “be saved through legislation”. The federal government, he indicated, had no business passing laws to protect the earth for future generations.
Graham’s positions on civil rights and the environment are not those of a rightwing crank, or of a paranoid anti-intellectual. Graham takes his Bible and his theology seriously. The political positions he has embraced derive from a careful and serious study of the scriptures.
Graham came of age during Franklin Roosevelt’s vast expansion of government power. But rather than join with social gospel advocates like Roosevelt’s aide Harry Hopkins in promoting the creation of a welfare state to serve the needy, the future evangelist was more influenced by apocalypse-obsessed, fundamentalist rabble rousers who rejected New Deal liberalism.
Graham, like most fundamentalists of his generation, determined that the New Deal state represented godless competition for the churches rather than a potential ally.
This is a message that appeared again and again in Graham’s many books on Jesus’s second coming. Only the return of Jesus would right social wrongs, he concluded.
The expansion of state power, in contrast, was a necessary precursor to the rise of the antichrist. The evangelist felt sure that as we approached the end of time, the world’s governments were going to take away Christians’ rights and liberties.
The New Deal, with its intrusive regulations, was the first step; Obamacare, with its contraception mandates, the most recent.
Yet Graham insisted that the inevitability of the second coming was no justification for indifference. “We must not feel that we are to sit back and do nothing to fight evil just because some day the four horsemen will come with full and final force upon the earth,” Graham wrote. Instead, he prodded evangelicals to elect people to office who shared his anti-statist worldview.
They did. White evangelicals have played an outsized role in recent political campaigns, supporting every Republican presidential candidate from Ronald Reagan to Donald Trump. 
Graham had the opportunity to lead fundamentalists into a new era. He could have pushed them to take social reform seriously as a God-given mandate to save the world from environmental destruction. He could have tackled racism, America’s original sin, by championing the federal government’s aggressive civil rights policies.
But he squandered it. He could not overcome the speculative end-times schemes of his cohort of evangelicals, with their anti-government hostilities.
Graham had good intentions, as his work desegregating his crusades demonstrated. But when his influence really would have counted, when he could have effected real change, real social transformation, he was too locked into last-days fearmongering to recognize the potential of the state to do good. We are all paying the price.
A different kind of last days may soon be upon us. Racial tensions are rising, the earth is warming, and evangelicals are doing little to help. That may be Graham’s most significant, and saddest, legacy.

description: Study highlights urgent need to adapt urban areas to cope with floods, droughts and heatwaves
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Study highlights urgent need to adapt urban areas to cope with floods, droughts and heatwaves
og_fields.og:title: Climate change 'will push European cities towards breaking point'
text:
Major British towns and cities, including Glasgow, Wrexham, Aberdeen and Chester, could be much more severely affected by climate change than previously thought, according to new research.
The study, by Newcastle University, analysed changes in flooding, droughts and heatwaves for every European city using all climate models.
Looking at the impact by the year 2050-2100, the team produced results for three possible outcomes – low, medium and high-impact scenarios.
But even the most optimistic case showed 85% of UK cities with a river, including London, would face increased flooding.
In the high-impact scenario, some cities and towns in the UK and Ireland could see the amount of water per flood as much as double. The worst affected is Cork, which could see 115% more water per flooding, while Wrexham, Carlisle, Glasgow, and Chester could all see increases of more than 75%.
The increase in severity in the predicted impact has come after the team, in a first of its kind, examined all three climate hazards together in the largest study of its kind ever undertaken.
After around three years of analysing the information across hundreds of cities in Europe, they found every outcome was worse than previously thought.
Wrexham, Carlisle, Glasgow, Aberdeen, Derry and Chester were the worst-hit UK towns and cities for river flooding, with Dublin, Cork and Waterford the worst in Ireland.
All 571 cities studied saw a worsening in heatwaves and the high-impact scenario predicted southern Europe experiencing droughts 14 times worse than today.
The lead author, Selma Guerreiro, said: “Although southern European regions are adapted to cope with droughts, this level of change could be beyond breaking point.
“Furthermore, most cities have considerable changes in more than one hazard, which highlights the substantial challenge cities face in managing climate risks.”
While southern European cities saw the biggest increase in the number of heatwave days, central European cities saw the greatest increase in temperature during heatwaves – ranging between 2C to 7C for the low scenario and 8C to 14C for the high scenario.
A co-author, Prof Richard Dawson, said: “The research highlights the urgent need to design and adapt our cities to cope with these future conditions.
“We are already seeing at first hand the implications of extreme weather events in our capital cities.
“In Paris, the Seine rose more than four metres above its normal water level. And as Cape Town prepares for its taps to run dry, this analysis highlights that such climate events are feasible in European cities too.”
Published in the journal Environmental Research Letters, the research found the European capitals worst hit by flooding would be Dublin, Helsinki, Riga, Vilnius and Zagreb.
Under the high-impact scenario, several European cities saw more than 80% increases on peak river flows.
Stockholm and Rome could see the greatest increase in number of heatwave days, while Prague and Vienna could see the greatest increase in maximum temperatures during heatwaves.
Lisbon and Madrid are in the top capital cities for increases in frequency and magnitude of droughts, while Athens, Nicosia, Valletta and Sofia might experience the worst increases in both drought and heatwaves.
Next month the United Nation’s Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change is holding its first cities and climate change science conference, after recognising the important role cites must play in tackling climate change.
Over 75% of the population of the EU currently lives in urban areas, and this percentage is expected to grow to 82% by 2050.
And already the impact is being felt, as between 1998-2009 floods in Europe caused 1,126 deaths and at least €52bn in insured economic losses.
Dawson, who sits on the scientific steering committee for the conference, said: “A key objective for this conference is to bring together and catalyse action from researchers, policymakers and industry to address the urgent issue of preparing our cities, their population, buildings and infrastructure for climate change.”
The team used projections from all available models associated with the high emission scenario RCP8.5, which implies a 2.6C to 4.8C increase in global temperature.
They found the British Isles have some of the worst overall flood projections, with the high scenario predicting half of UK cities could see at least a 50% increase on peak river flows.

How about you first demonstrating the causes (with science, not speculation) of the contradictions to the warming trend as occurred between 1940 and 1978, and from 1998 to 2012. (I suspect you'll just tell me the pause never happended)
BQEND
Asking for "science, not speculation" is meaningless as it sets you up as an arbiter of whether or not evidence meets some arbitrary, undefined standard. See your reply to this post for details.
Post-war temperature was suppressed by increases in aerosol pollutants which reduced the amount of solar radiation reaching the surface, known as "global-dimming". You can see the negative forcing of these aerosols in the IPCC graphic of forcings relative to 1750. The patterns of temperature evolution in this period provide further evidence that aerosols were a dominant factor - with days cooling but nights warming. The various clean-air acts of the 1970s reduced this pollution at a time when CO2 was rising rapidly and overwhelmed the climatic system. This has been successfully hindcasted by GCMs.
As for the period 1998-2012 - it has been known for several decades that slowdowns and speed-ups would occur during the projected warming. This was a surprise only to the so-called skeptics. It was caused primarily by the ocean-atmospheric coupling, primarily ENSO and the PDO. 1998 was an unusually warm year because of a massive El Niño event, so starting in 1998 gives a data point above the long-term trend. 1998-2012 then saw the largest pre-ponderance of La Niña events in several decades. There are further complementary explanations involving solar and aerosol activity, but bog-standard ocean-atmospheric coupling is enough to slow or speed temperature evolution by several tenths of a degree over short-term periods. Tellingly, the scientists who explained this during the slowdown made projections that warming would see a rapid increase very soon, which was followed by 3 hottest years in a row - a first in the temperature record.
Skeptical scientist Judith Curry projected the slowdown would continue until 2030, so yet another example where the explanations and projections of mainstream science are superior to those of your favoured scientific grouping.
Now, there is plenty of reading for you and there's more where that came from. Please respond to all of the evidence and provide your own in any reply.
Otherwise stamp your foot and hold you breath and demand that phenomena which have perfectly bog-standard, evidence-based explanations are "excuses" because, err, alarmism, or something.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519389059000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the ocean atmospheric coupling primarily enso and the pdo', u'effect': u'it'}, {u'cause': u'a massive el ni\xf1o event', u'effect': u'1998 was an unusually warm year so starting in 1998 gives a data point above the long term trend'}], u'author_id': u'18495475', u'in_reply_to': u'112618676', u'id': u'112621061', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DennisHorne', u'text': u'BQSTART

That said, if west-east progression of midlatitude weather systems has slowed then I'd expect that after tropical cyclones have moved to midlatitudes then their tracks would show less latitudinal movement. 
BQENDThis is one of my favourite images in meteorology

https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/23/Global_tropical_cyclone_tracks-edit2.jpg
The curving tracks that are especially notable in the Western Pacific and N Atlantic basins are in a big part down to trade winds (recurvature) and what is called beta drift, that is the movement to the north and west (in the N Hemisphere) from the movement of the Earth. Tropical cyclones themselves, in these latitudes, lose their orginisation as there is not enough warm water to keep the warm core low pressure pulling the air in and recondensing. Instead they break down to be frontal system, extra tropical cyclones. They do encounter the polar jet on that journey. But as always its complex. And its getting more complex. Here is where the likely impact of Arctic warming slowing the progression of Rossby Waves has its impacts. When a blocking pattern is set up you can get circumstances where the deep amplitude of the wave can pick up low pressure systems and zip them across the Atlantic with a fair old clip. 2013/14 winter and its "storm factory" was such a set up.

https://www.reading.ac.uk/news-and-events/releases/PR561957.aspx
If an ex tropical cyclone get caught in this kind of set up it can be rushed to the higher latitudes with lots of heat and moisture. In 13/14 we had a right exit right over the Bristol Channel

http://www.eumetrain.org/data/3/3/Content/fi.htm
So to stop prattling on all over the shop, its complex. Lots of different effects pulling cyclones around. (Damn that post went places I did not mean it to go. Hmmmmm, apols all)', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519421495000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16773618', u'in_reply_to': u'112625397', u'id': u'112642680', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"How about you first demonstrating the causes (with science, not speculation) of contradictions of the the warming trend as occurred between 1940 and 1978 and from 1998 to 2012."
First you have to ask yourself what it is that you are talking about the warming of. In this case you appear to be talking about the warming of the Earth's climate. The temperature of the Earth's climate for any particular year is the average global temperature of that year added to the global average temperatures of the preceding 29 years divided by 30.
The global average temperature is the average of a set of temperatures representative of series of quadrants covering the surface of the Earth. On the 30% of the globe covered by land the surface air temperature is measured while on 70% covered by oceans and seas the surface water temperature is measured.
See the histogram of yearly global average temperature anomalies from the 20th average from 1880 to 2016 in the following.https://climate.gov/news-features/understanding-climate/climate-change-global-temperature
Note that a change in average yearly global temperature is not a change in climate as it takes 30 years to measure climate temperature. Note also that warming of the global climate is not the same thing as global warming as more the atmosphere at the surface and the ocean surface are not the only parts of the globe that warm. More significantly the ocean warms to a considerable depth.
I suspect that what you mean by a contradiction to a warming trend is the opposite of a warming trend which is a cooling trend. Note that the period from 1940 to 1978 contains a equal balance of anomalies in the yearly average global temperature above and below the 20th century average which represents a period of neither cooling nor appreciable warming. 
Note also that the period from 1998 to 2012 shows a warming trend. Note also that a 15 year period is not long enough to affect the rate of warming of the climate as climate needs 30 years. Even though those 15 years showed a slower warming trend than the four years that followed and the 11 years that preceded them, each of which included an extreme record breaking El Nino year, the warming of the global climate has continued for those 30 years. 
That 1998 to 2012 period has been referred to as the pause but because there has been no pause in warming of the climate people will tell you there is no pause. However there was during that period a pause in the rate of warming trend of the average global yearly temperature and there was a longer and more distinct pause in the rate of warming trend in the period 1940 to 1978. 
When I finish downloading some PDFs from the wet and soggy copper wires that are called broadband internet in Australia I will explain why these slowdowns in the rate of warming of the average yearly global temperature have occurred.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519459204000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'112618676', u'id': u'112649140', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID2310987', u'text': u'Bloody hell! https://discussion.theguardian.com/comment-permalink/112613985', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519417159000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'you ca nt', u'effect': u'whining that you should not be criticised and demanding at the same time i do even more of the heavy lifting than i already do'}], u'author_id': u'16773618', u'in_reply_to': u'112637649', u'id': u'112640260', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Kathleen Kelly', u'text': u'Living in our current society full of distractions, it can be necessary to compartmentalize the sections of our life into what we see and what we chose to ignore to accomplish a given task. It can be painful to shift our world view from the narrow regions we chose to recognize, to the scientific reality of the global implications of climate change. When interacting with others who chose a narrow, comfortable view of the world, we should challenge ourselves to broaden their perspective with stories or facts about a single field. Connecting climate change to weather scales that individuals are familiar with challenges the separation of hurricanes and cyclones from the environmental impacts of mining, the car industry, and sewage dumping. Vulnerable populations suffer the most consequences from tropical storm affects, but contribute very little to the climate change producing the stronger storms (1-3). Addition of another number to storm severity forces a bridge that can threaten individuals’ world view. Seeking to slowly decrease the compartmentalization can help to create a space where dialogue on structural societal shifts to reduce pollution, plastic production, and innumerable other factors to improve our local and global environments can occur.

og_fields.og:description: Traditional scale used goes only to five but strength and intensity of storms is increasing, says scientists
og_fields.og:title: Stronger storms mean new 'category six' scale may be needed
text:
The increasing strength, intensity and duration of tropical cyclones has climate scientists asking whether a new classification needs to be created: a category-six storm. 
The Saffir-Simpson hurricane wind scale currently runs in severity from one to five, with five describing near-total destruction. 
But climate scientists meeting at a conference in the New Zealand city of Wellington have floated the idea of creating a category six to reflect the increasing severity of tropical cyclones in the wake of warming sea temperatures and climate change.
Climatologist Michael Mann, the director of the Earth system science center at Penn State University said the current scale could be viewed as increasingly outdated. 
“Scientifically, [six] would be a better description of the strength of 200mph (320km/h) storms, and it would also better communicate the well-established finding now that climate change is making the strongest storms even stronger,” he said.
He pointed out that category five was previously considered the highest category necessary because it led to essentially total destruction of human infrastructure. But that was no longer true owing to sturdier construction
“Since the scale is now used as much in a scientific context as it is a damage assessment context, it makes sense to introduce a category six to describe the unprecedented strength 200mph storms we’ve seen over the past few years both globally [Patricia] and here in the southern hemisphere [Winston].”
New Zealand’s climate change minister, James Shaw, said cyclone Winston in 2016 – the strongest cyclone on record in the southern hemisphere – was an example of a cyclone that could have been scaled up to a category six; if the category existed. 
“The international cyclone rankings don’t go higher than category five, the only reason it wasn’t a category-six cyclone is because we don’t have a category six, but we might need one in the future,” Shaw told the conference.
But Chris Brandolino, principal scientist at the National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research in New Zealand, said the ramifications of introducing another category to the scale could be complex, because meteorologists were trained in the old scale, and the public were educated about what the scale means, and how to prepare.
“Categories are engaging to the public and its easy for us to understand and communicate the severity of a storm,” said Brandolino. “I always encourage us re-evaluating the science, we should always be asking ‘is what we are doing appropriate for the time?’ But I think if we are seriously to consider this it requires a holistic approach, looking at the whole scale, not just adding a category. Maybe the whole scale gets rejigged to reflect the times.”
Mann said re-evaluating the scale or adding a category six would have implications for the preparedness of communities in the cyclone’s path, and on scientists’ ability to understand cyclone behaviour as it changes in an age of climate change.

description: Labor frontbencher says party must ‘get the policy mechanisms right’ over Carmichael coalmine
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Labor frontbencher says party must ‘get the policy mechanisms right’ over Carmichael coalmine
og_fields.og:title: Anthony Albanese rules out retrospective legislation to fight Adani
text:
Anthony Albanese says Labor should not single out existing projects, like the Adani coalmine, that have already gone through approval processes “and then retrospectively change existing laws, which would have ramifications across the board”.
The Labor frontbencher has effectively ruled out Labor overhauling the Environmental Protection Biodiversity and Conversation Act as part of a strategy to boost legal options of killing the controversial Queensland coal project.
While Labor has been considering a range of policy options, including the possible insertion of a climate trigger in the Act, Albanese told the ABC “certainly there has been no suggestion from Labor that that is something that we should do”.
“We haven’t said at any stage that we would do that.”
He added that the Adani project had already secured the required environmental approvals “not once, but twice. It was approved firstly and then they made a decision that what they would need to do is to re-examine it in light of the potential impacts on the Great Barrier Reef and again it was approved”.
“It has received its state approvals – both of those rounds of approvals by the way under Coalition governments, not Labor governments.”
And referencing the byelection in the Melbourne electorate of Batman, where the Greens are already escalating their ground campaign efforts against Labor on Adani – Albanese explicitly warned colleagues against making a short-term political decision that would have long-term policy implications.
“What you can’t do is look at any one electorate and say this is why we are going to determine national policy on something like mining or energy or climate change action,” Albanese said.
“What you have to do is to get the policy mechanisms right and that is what we have done.”
The Labor leader, Bill Shorten, has been publicly telegraphing a hardening of Labor’s position on the Adani project since late January, but has yet to clarify what specific options the ALP might take.
This week, Shorten has been visiting Queensland coastal electorates, and sending a positive message about the future of coal, while also highlighting his concerns about the Adani project.
Labor’s climate change spokesman, Mark Butler, delivered a much less equivocal message. On Monday he used his speech to the Sydney Institute to argue developing the Galilee Basin was not in Australia’s national interest because it would displace mining and jobs in existing coal regions, and would not help the world meet its obligations under the Paris climate agreement.
Internal views within Labor are mixed, with some key players favouring killing the project on climate grounds, but others concerned that option will expose Labor to a damaging political backlash about sovereign risk.
The mining union has urged Labor not to toughen its position on the project, because stopping Adani will trigger an internal debate inside the party about the future of coalmining, and will cost the ALP politically in Queensland.
Albanese said he did not believe the Adani project would ultimately proceed, because it would not get government subsidies, which would help the mine attract private finance.
“The conservation movement said to me repeatedly ... this project doesn’t stack up unless it gets some public subsidy through the rail line,” Albanese said.
“Now we ensured that that would not occur and indeed the Queensland Labor government has also said that they won’t support that subsidy and hence we have a project that doesn’t have any finance here in Australia, unable to raise funds in the US, unable to raise funds in China – and therefore it is hard to see this project going ahead because of the economics of the project”.
Adani has confirmed it has now abandoned its March deadline for securing financing for the first stage of the Carmichael mine.

I'm surprised you cannot see how this kind of thinking would lead to neglect of the environment. You criticize religion yet it always had the most potential to protect the environment. If countries such as India were not influenced by Islam and western humanism the place would have remained a oasis for wildlife. I have also never found a person who's really into spirituality and not care about the environment and the treatment of animals. People can pray or meditate on some divinity and come to similar conclusions as science. In some ways it's actually more preferable because it is based on compassion and selflessness instead of cold logic and the need to preserve the environment solely for the sake of our civilization.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519724099000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'this kind of thinking', u'effect': u'neglect of the environment'}, {u'cause': u'it is based on compassion and selflessness instead of cold logic and the need to preserve the environment solely for the sake of our civilization', u'effect': u"in some ways it 's actually more preferable"}], u'author_id': u'17632173', u'in_reply_to': u'112766553', u'id': u'112782123', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GoldenAppleCorps', u'text': u'You deny it is possible to learn by example? Mostly this school represents the pueblo tribes of New Mexico and Navajo/dine of New Mexico, it is a native only school.And they had a ceremony at the local river which here is the rio grande a ceremony which I did witness ....the river there is the river here.Your words sound heartfelt to me and I find no offense with them..Others may I ask what tribe do you represent?
There is not a returning but the tribes still exist and will continue come what may. All continue to be educated to their great heritage in schools like this. And they act with that as their cause. Did you know hundreds probably thousands of poor kids nationwide were interested in and helping in what little way they could..probably not. It is intended they the tribes are only thought of as small past and not united.Forward is their direction, not back. 
These kids only gave small things like cans of stuff food, but their hearts were there with them. That is the future unity. When this all around us comes crashing down...and history tells us it will...who will be left standing the tribes or the rest....we will see....it is not over till its over.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519715575000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14139778', u'in_reply_to': u'112766256', u'id': u'112776460', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ronnewmexico', u'text': u'Fatalities I agree.The costs of a spill ruining the patency of a underground water source...very hard to measure.Albuquerque a city near where I live has had to deal with a leak of old jet fuel which once was at surface into the groundwater...the spill has spread for several miles last I checked and is continueing. The total cost for remediation which the airforce has to pay..I'd reasonably guess all said and done hundreds of millions. 
So it is a bit potential cost as well. Hard to figure a cost and consequence of oil in water underground.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519708246000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14139778', u'in_reply_to': u'112774415', u'id': u'112774567', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ronnewmexico', u'text': u'Not for spills.Pipelines produce much more actual oil into the ground and or the water underground than tanker truck in a accident. Accidents in total are far more for vehicles...but virtually none of it gets into the ground.
Most of it particularly in remote areas where a spill may not even be noticed for a day or two and response is perhaps very very difficult will get onto the soil and then into the groundwater.More carbon produced by truck transport..sure. It is a miniscule amount compared to the cost of a pipeline spill remedation by any standard measure.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519707493000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14139778', u'in_reply_to': u'112774289', u'id': u'112774415', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ChrisGordon1', u'text': u'http://www.engineeringnews.co.za/article/transnet-upgrades-fuel-pipeline-from-durban-to-johannesburg-2017-10-05
You are right. Nothing is perfect and over the years this pipeline has had its moments. However if carried by road there would undoubtedly have been a couple of hundred fatalities over the decades and far more pollution.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519706796000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16261177', u'in_reply_to': u'112774158', u'id': u'112774289', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ronnewmexico', u'text': u'To add each tanker truck as opposed to pipeline also provides at least a hundred truck driving jobs for each pipeline job produced. Pipelines are not labor intensive being in the main a automated maintance system. 
Never told you that as well I suspect. Cost varies from 5 USD per tanker truck to less than 1 pipeline. But each barrel of oil cost 50 or so it is then a manageable cost increase. But it hits at profit.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519706483000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14139778', u'in_reply_to': u'112774158', u'id': u'112774244', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ronnewmexico', u'text': u'In the US a alternative means of transport of crude is by tanker truck. In fact this is the means employed to the major refinery in Oklahoma. A pipeline provides least cost. AS to tanker ship it simply does not apply.Truck accidents are easily mitigated they do occur statistically more often but each spill by such accident is entirely managed. None of the pipeline spills are. Almost every drop from a tanker truck accident is retrieved. Millions of barrels may spill in a pipline accident all virtually unmanageable.
No offense but you are being deceived by the industry which favors pipeline to save cost.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519706050000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14139778', u'in_reply_to': u'112773979', u'id': u'112774158', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ChrisGordon1', u'text': u'And this is why I called the chief a N.I.M.B.Y.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519705210000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16261177', u'in_reply_to': u'112773979', u'id': u'112774000', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ChrisGordon1', u'text': u'We are talking to cross purposes (I think).
A pipline is a far safer method of transporting crude over a long distance as was perhaps evidenced by the disaster in the China Sea a couple of weeks ago.
Local deliveries of refined fuel to service stations are always by truck.
From what I read The United States is self suffiient in oil and it is thanks to new fields and pipelines such as this. A much better option than transporting it half way round the world in ships. A pipeline leak is easily addressed. An enormous tanker that goes down next to our penguin colony isn't.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519705119000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16261177', u'in_reply_to': u'112773862', u'id': u'112773979', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ronnewmexico', u'text': u'Safer is context. It is far safer for peoples in remote areas to have oil transported by oil tanker truck than pipeline. Oil tanker truck spill by accident is manageable. The problem is pipeline spill due to topography and remoteness is not.
More accidents occur than pipeline spills...sure but every spill by accident is able to be quickly remediated by response crews. By pipeline never.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519704579000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'topography and remoteness', u'effect': u'pipeline spill'}], u'author_id': u'14139778', u'in_reply_to': u'112773736', u'id': u'112773862', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ChrisGordon1', u'text': u'It sounds rather like rural Africa. Pipelines are by far the safest method of transporting oil and as long as a reasonable rent is paid I don't see the problem. We all need the stuff.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519703852000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16261177', u'in_reply_to': u'112648742', u'id': u'112773736', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'100suns', u'text': u'We did not need atomic weapons, but we probably do need atomic power, and being able to zap cancers is considered by people with cancer to be a benefit. You don't, sadly, get to know how to do one of these things without knowing how to do the other (and you probably don't get to know how to do lost of other things, like make semiconductors say).', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519693400000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13299353', u'in_reply_to': u'112655166', u'id': u'112771171', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'100suns', u'text': u'Yes, sea levels will change (and probably rise). How fast they change makes a fairly big difference, however: it's not the change that matters it's the rate of change. I don't know how fast sea-levels changed at the end of the last glaciation, but I do know how fast temperatures changed: about a degree every 900 years. my comment above:
