I'd also turn a critical eye on big hydro because of the environmental damage it causes. None of this is in any way, shape or form of a spiritual or religious in nature.
You can commune with the water elementals if you wish (or any other god or spirit of your choosing). And it won't do a damned bit of good. 
And I won't be praying for world peace anytime soon. Sounds like a beauty pageant.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519527500000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it', u'effect': None}, {u'cause': u'the environmental damage it causes', u'effect': u"i 'd also turn a critical eye on big hydro"}], u'author_id': u'4069809', u'in_reply_to': u'112659358', u'id': u'112674217', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Iconoclasm', u'text': u'We're all complicit in the oil economy, more or less. The question for each of us is: what are we doing about it? Criticising others is easier than taking personal action.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519520194000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12347221', u'in_reply_to': u'112647956', u'id': u'112672411', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ronnewmexico', u'text': u'Yes I have heard that as well. Famously they already had a significant leak related to these products.In any event locally it is just way preferable to manage a oil truck accident spill involving a limited amount of oil than a pipeline spill involving millions.
Containment of a tanker truck spill consequent to accident, virtually all first responders are trained in initial mitigation procedures followed up with and assisted to industry representative themselves and in a timely fashion.
. How long does it take a pipeline company to even know of a break in a remote area nevertheless even to access one in a very timely manner. Virtually all tanker trucks transverse interstates which have a built in local response infrastructure and identifying mechanism allowing for timely effective intervention. The choice is clear as I read it. So what we pay a bit more for tanker than truck transport, it is like 5 compared to less than one per barrel...per barrel is 50 plus in any regard.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519515274000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14139778', u'in_reply_to': u'112653876', u'id': u'112670204', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Yetypu', u'text': u'Yes. I've upticked your comment.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519509326000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4669086', u'in_reply_to': u'112662284', u'id': u'112666968', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'I'm of the view the mega fauna were probably in decline anyway whilst the warming climate reduced suitable mammoth [mammoths were just one of many species of mega fauna of course, it's unliklely we intentionally hunted Smilodon] habitat it enabled our spread across the planet. Homo sapiens were probably just the last nail in the mammoths coffin. As you say the African mega fauna evolved with Homo sapiens so they knew to keep out of our way, then came the greedy Europeans killing for fun & corrupting indigenous culture though i'm not aware when or where pastoralist's began grazing cattle in Africa that certainly isn't beneficial to African fauna & flora.
As you say it was a matter of survival of the fittest simple ecology really competition & predation. It's just a shame with all our advances in scientific knowledge we are still making the same basic mistakes when we know better. As with other threads below its not that i think science or technology is bad its that we don't seem to be able to discipline our use of it. Medicine is great but we did nothing to constrain our breeding when infant survival rates increased! And over population is the root cause of all our problems, consumption, habitat loss, pollution, climate change etc.
We seem completely impotent in controlling ourselves or our destiny despite our knowledge & technology.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519500817000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'112659813', u'id': u'112663489', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'I don't think its clear when agriculture began but think its now recognized it was earlier than 12 years ago.
The earliest flint tools & fire are scientific discoveries! Just not advanced technology. There was an article in the guardian only the other day suggesting Homo erectus had developed tools, speech & travel over water.
But i don't dislike technology, i don't hate science it's just a simple fact i can see the harm technology has done to the planet where we both agree is that its unsustainable what hurts is you & I & many others can see the future is bleak but we can do nothing about it.
Science is just a tool nothing more its neither good or bad, its how we use it that's bad. What i do hate is the micro management & control of the natural world. That will be our undoing because we never know better than nature.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519499016000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'we never know better than nature', u'effect': u'that will be our undoing'}], u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'112659005', u'id': u'112662678', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'Forgive me you are correct but the point i make is still valid', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519497925000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'112659766', u'id': u'112662284', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Raptorius', u'text': u'BQSTART
Science is about understanding reality, and has nothing to do with advancing our interests.
BQENDOf course it has everything to do with our interests. Universities receive financial support from governments and governments can dictate them what is or isn't deemed a societal necessity or in the economic interest. Scientists don't live in a vacuum.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519492518000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17632173', u'in_reply_to': u'112653187', u'id': u'112660423', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Raptorius', u'text': u'Possibly the megafauna were greatly diminished after previous ice ages in the Pleistocene and barely survived, but this time around with humans it's ice on the cake. Can't put much blame on our ancestors. They did what they had to for their survival and with the knowledge they had, and did not systematically study wildlife like we do today. The world was also bigger in that time, subjectively speaking. Today we know better so we deserve the blame.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519490162000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17632173', u'in_reply_to': u'112653957', u'id': u'112659813', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Raptorius', u'text': u'BQSTART
But agriculture faces big challenges if we don’t change our ways soon (1), as do our fisheries, and if they both decline significantly, forcing us back to being largely hunter-gatherers, history tells us that out of every 1000 people you see maybe one survives.
BQENDThis is by far the most depressing topic within environmental debates. Most farmers do not seem willing to change their ways (only when given heavy subsidies) even though consumer demand for organic food is rising. Farmers and governments alike are in the pocket of globalist dogma. You and most of your country don't want beef any more? We'll just ship it some place else. The entirety of the world needs to be educated in these matters and that's quite a task to fulfil.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519412827000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17632173', u'in_reply_to': u'112609470', u'id': u'112638144', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Yetypu', u'text': u'BQSTART
Oil is a tree! Just fossilised
BQEND
No, fossilized trees are coal. Oil was detritus, lots of little living things.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519490022000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4669086', u'in_reply_to': u'112653150', u'id': u'112659766', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Dialectician', u'text': u'You dismiss spirituality as piety. That, right there, is the sickness.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519488446000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10761302', u'in_reply_to': u'112606016', u'id': u'112659358', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Raptorius', u'text': u'It's an interesting thought but I too suspect it's a way to put blame away from humans. We cannot deny that large mammals died out everywhere with the arrival of mankind. These large megafauna of the pleistocene survived ice ages before. African mammals had more experience with humans, or perhaps it's also a matter of African people living less destructively. Either way, it's a blatant fact that the self obsessed colonialists looked down upon both African people and African wildlife.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519412437000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17632173', u'in_reply_to': u'112618290', u'id': u'112637993', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'EnviroCapitalist', u'text': u'According to the (excellent) book "Guns, Germs and Steel" there was a thriving native population living in the Mississippi area. When the Europeans arrived, they found abandoned cities and death. well over 90% of the native population had been killed by smallpox, which had raced ahead of the European settlers.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519406939000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3578530', u'in_reply_to': u'112619141', u'id': u'112635164', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GoldenAppleCorps', u'text': u'Humans started their exuberant population growth 12 thousand years ago, long before science cane along. Science is about understanding reality, and has nothing to do with advancing our interests. Palentology has little to offer in terms of technology (which I think you confuse with technology), but it is s science. Understanding bacteria is a scientific issue, utilisation of antibiotics is a medical technology. It sounds like you dislike technology, which is a valid perspective. I would contend that humans are as natural as any other organism - our technology has allowed our species to overshoot the carrying capacity of our niche (Earth) and our fate will likely be the same as all the other organisms that have done the same.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519487122000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17327071', u'in_reply_to': u'112655166', u'id': u'112659005', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'In fact science is not about learning, science is a tool to advance our own interests, we use learning to progress those interests. But perversely progress is often confused with greed & ego, & has never been beneficial to our planet.
If you think i'm religious your very much mistaken, if you think i don't understand, use or appreciate the benefits science provides you are also very much mistaken. But the sad reality is science is used to exploit natural resources for our own convenience & profit, sadly even ecology & conservation is used to manipulate the natural world to suit our own lifestyles.
The trouble with science it is neither good & bad, we use it selfishly. Did we ever really need the atom bomb? NO Does nature need science? NO. Do Homo sapiens need nature YES!
Science is great, i'm not anti science, but it has lots to answer for. As an example envirocaplitst's comment about small pox, if it weren't for the science & technology involved in ship building there wouldn't have been any native population wipe-out from smallpox. Vaccines are great for society & our children, they are devastating for the natural world. 
It comes down to the understanding what is more important constant learning/progress [growth] or living in balance with something much greater than ourselves, the natural world. On our current trajectory our science is only destroying our planet & ourselves. That's what i've learnt & its sod all to do with religion.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519475259000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'112653187', u'id': u'112655166', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Yetypu', u'text': u'BQSTART
In a physical sense your argument is true. However
BQEND
Yes, it was tongue in cheek.
However, to make my point more specifically, CO2 is not re-absorbed by wood growth fast enough to justify, e.g. the subsidies & brownie points awarded to sleight of hand tricks like Drax.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519398202000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4669086', u'in_reply_to': u'112624360', u'id': u'112628185', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathonFields', u'text': u'The Black Snake of corporate greed devours our planet.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519472207000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4634960', u'id': u'112654097', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'FitzRolf', u'text': u'In a physical sense your argument is true. However you ignore the timescales and the rate of reintroduction. That carbon was stored millions of years ago and we are releasing it back to the atmosphere at a far higher rate than the environmental system can reabsorb it. It's never the production of the CO2 or other greenhouse gases that is the problem it's the rate of production Vs the rate of absorption. A tree grows much faster than oil forms.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519393345000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16471963', u'in_reply_to': u'112623669', u'id': u'112624360', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Yetypu', u'text': u'BQSTART
Burning wood is carbon neutral. When burned wood emits exactly* the same amount of CO2 as it absorbed when growing. Not a molecule more - not a molecule less*. These are the kind of things you should have been taught at about age 10. Did you miss school that day?
BQEND
Burning oil & gas is carbon neutral.When burned oil & gas emits exactly* the same amount of CO2 as it absorbed when growing. Not a molecule more - not a molecule less*.These are the kind of things you should have been taught at about age 10. Did you miss school that day?
* - not exactly. :)', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519392454000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4669086', u'in_reply_to': u'112613508', u'id': u'112623669', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'But can you back up your beliefs with evidence, because mother nature is disagreeing with.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519472045000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'mother nature is disagreeing with', u'effect': u'but can you back up your beliefs with evidence'}], u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'112593346', u'id': u'112654040', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'As soil fertility is lost even organic farming sounds an environmental nightmare, we need to look much closer at permaculture methods of farming, good luck with that, what would farmers do all day if they couldn't play with their tractors.
You are lucky you got away with that remark blaming the dear old colonials for their corruption & destruction of Africa. True but the truth often seems to upset guardian readers LOL.
As much as all the evidence points to Homo spp for the mega fauna extinctions its hard to accept that even then we were being so destructive. So ironic that such an intelligent species is incapable of learning the lessons of history.
Climate change will play its part but the key will be the loss of biodiversity Homo sapiens will soldier on until we cross the biological line & the system collapses entirely, we'll only regret it when the Tesco grocery order isnt delivered at our chosen time & we run out of bottled water.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519471825000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'112638144', u'id': u'112653957', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'FitzRolf', u'text': u'I agree. However to understand the larger picture properly it is important to think through the details even though these may appear trivial, the shed burning is inconsequential on a global scale, however the lack of understanding that it was a wasteful thing to do is very important. We waste far too much energy and stuff. The thinking of 'oh it's only one shed' or 'who cares if I leave a light on for 10 minutes while I'm not in the room' is seriously part of the problem. I doubt we will move on much until people really start to consider the cost of their actions.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519392293000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16471963', u'in_reply_to': u'112618432', u'id': u'112623547', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'As I understand it the oil piped from Canadian tarsands has tiny particles of sand in it creating an abrasive medium- as it gets pumped it creates its very leaks.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519471630000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'112648881', u'id': u'112653876', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'quokkaZ', u'text': u'BQSTART
I'd explain its meaning to you but somehow i think it would be a waste of time.
BQEND
Zealots often believe themselves in possession of special knowledge that few others comprehend.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519388592000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4069809', u'in_reply_to': u'112618688', u'id': u'112620681', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'persep', u'text': u'Fine. Put it through your backyard then. Oh, wait...https://www.pri.org/stories/2016-12-01/bismarck-residents-got-dakota-access-pipeline-moved-without-fight
What a nasty little racist you are.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519470419000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15187619', u'in_reply_to': u'112647956', u'id': u'112653411', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'quokkaZ', u'text': u'BQSTART
if we subvert natural controls we simply cause new problems in the future
BQEND
Yeah, let's bring back the death toll from infectious diseases. That should start to set things right. Eh?', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519388532000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'we', u'effect': u'new problems in the future bqend'}], u'author_id': u'4069809', u'in_reply_to': u'112619141', u'id': u'112620635', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'BQSTART
Not quite in the same league as Guns, Germs and Steel. 
BQEND
well despite the horrors of war, no amount of guns will ever match the harm caused by mass extinction.

BQSTART
The normal way of population control is infant mortality, that would have been achieved by killing billions.
BQEND
Your right & what always strikes me as odd, are claims that science is objective & rational yet its use is almost entirely emotive & sentimental.
Watching your own child die must be horrendous & heartbreaking but the simple fact is if we subvert natural controls we simply cause new problems in the future, sadly its something science seems to fail in teaching us. The harm Scientific advances have provided our species has a lot to answer for & we will one day in the future have to face those consequences.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519386303000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'we', u'effect': u'new problems in the future'}], u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'112611392', u'id': u'112619141', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Petefram', u'text': u'Talk about water, how many times and in how many places do I still see people dumping cardboard and paper into landfill bins when recycling bins are next next to them. We are a wasteful society !!!', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519310638000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3985524', u'id': u'112584907', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GoldenAppleCorps', u'text': u'Science is about learning; if that is failure then the alternative is religion. I choose science every time. Science shows us what predicament we are in (ecology) and explains why are unwilling to address it (psychology).', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519469761000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17327071', u'in_reply_to': u'112641693', u'id': u'112653187', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'Your comment resembles many of my past remarks, i understand your points but to take offense at the burning of a small wooden building over a needless pipeline transporting millions of gallons of oil is ridiculous.
If we get pedantic about it, the second the tree that produced the wood was felled it started to decay & the CO2 was unlocked. burning it just sped up the process. Oil is a tree! Just fossilized & the CO2 locked into the depths of the planet.
In any case if the shed were to be bulldozed it would have been useless to anyone other than firewood, it would have been burnt one way or another!', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519469666000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'112623547', u'id': u'112653150', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our
community standards.
Replies may also be deleted. For more detail see our FAQs.', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519385752000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"it did n't abide by our community standards", u'effect': u'this comment was removed by a moderator'}], u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'112611362', u'id': u'112618747', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'I'd explain its meaning to you but somehow i think it would be a waste of time.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519385669000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'112606016', u'id': u'112618688', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'uncommodified', u'text': u'Good on these heroes and more power to them', u'recommendation_count': u'13', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519310046000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18309811', u'id': u'112584433', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GoldenAppleCorps', u'text': u'You don’t need to be a scientist to spot people splitting hears.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519469506000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17327071', u'in_reply_to': u'112612435', u'id': u'112653077', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: Chief Arvol Looking Horse: A call for continued efforts to protect our water and our Earth
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Chief Arvol Looking Horse: A call for continued efforts to protect our water and our Earth
og_fields.og:title: Standing Rock is everywhere: one year later | Chief Arvol Looking Horse
text:
One year after the closing of the camp at the Standing Rock Reservation, Standing Rock is everywhere. Our collective water has been assaulted for many generations to the possible point of no return. 
Our Elders foretold of a Black Snake and how the Water of Life — “Mni Woc’oni,” which is our first medicine — would be affected if we did not stop this oncoming disaster. Mni Woc’oni is part of our creation story, and the same story that exists in many creation stories around Mother Earth.
When we say “Mni Woc’oni” — Water of Life — people all over the world are now beginning to understand that it is a living spirit: it can heal when you pray with it and die if you do not respect it. We wanted the world to know there have been warnings in our prophecies and, as we see it, those warnings are now taking place. It was said water would be like gold. It was said that our spirit of water would begin to leave us. 
We are at the crossroads.
In April 2016, after receiving concerns about the construction of an oil pipeline, I was invited to Sacred Stone Camp at the northeastern border of the Standing Rock Reservation in North Dakota to assist with a water ceremony. At that time, not many were there, but it was enough to create a prayer to wake up the people. I told the young people that Standing Rock is everywhere. 
Later that month, our indigenous youth set out on foot to run from the Standing Rock Reservation to Washington D.C. in an attempt to bring attention to the poisonous bitumen oil pipeline coming through our treaty territory. For our young people, it was important to explain to U.S. government leaders that this was unacceptable. 
As I look back at my experiences at Standing Rock, I think about the circle we created through prayer on December 4, 2016. Our traditional Elders asked all nations to join us and stand in prayer. Thousands, including many religious representatives, joined in prayer on that very cold day. An invitation video was made and sent all over the world. 
After the prayers were offered to the fire, I asked the people to surround the camp and ride horseback around the whole perimeter. On this day, President Obama and his administration halted the Dakota Access Pipeline by denying the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers an easement that would have allowed the pipeline to cross beneath Lake Oahe. 
The closing of the camp at Standing Rock a year ago and the continued construction of the Dakota Access Pipeline has been a great disappointment. So, too, was the November 2017 spill of 210,000 gallons of oil from the Keystone Pipeline, west of the Sisseton Wahpeton Reservation, despite the tribe’s fight against it since 2003. So, too, was the April 2011 spill of 1.2 million gallons of oil onto Lubicon Cree territory, northeast of Peace River. 
What happened at Standing Rock has awakened many of my own people, and people across the world. 
It was at Standing Rock that so many came together to share their stories and knowledge of what was happening in their territory, sharing ideas on how to move toward sustainable living in our relationship to land, water, and food. 
Standing Rock has marked the beginning of an international movement that will continue to work peacefully, purposefully, and tirelessly for the protection of water along all areas of poisonous oil pipelines and across all of Mother Earth. 
In the protection of Mni Woc’oni, it is more than oil pipelines threatening the well-being and future of our water. Near the native territory of the Sisseton Wahpeton Oyate, concentrated animal feeding operations or “CAFOs” are draining and degrading the land and water. As a result, the air is toxic, swamps have dried up, and aquifers, to which the people are supposed to have water rights, are being drained. Residents have mortgaged their homes to fight these threats in court and lost. In other places — in mining spills across South America and Africa and at Fukushima — man has gone too far. 
Water is a source of life, not a resource. 
My life’s work has been to bring attention to water and to unite all nations, all faiths in one prayer. As Keeper to the White Buffalo Calf Woman Bundle, I have also brought attention to the white animals being born, signaling us of changes globally. 
As an indigenous leader, I have supported the establishment of a World Peace and Prayer Day, the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples and, most recently, the Nayzul Declaration. 
In our tradition, we pray for everything we eat and drink so our minds can be good. When the environment that we live in is sick and suffering, so too are the minds and decisions of our leaders. 
We must continue to work together for the health and well-being of our water and our Earth. 
In a Sacred Hoop of Life, there is no ending and no beginning.
Hec’ed Onipikte (that we shall live).
Chief Arvol Looking Horse is the 19th Keeper of the Sacred Bundle and Spiritual Leader of the Lakota, Dakota, Nakota People.

If by 'self-regulating' you mean to imply humans are immune to MME's, don't fool yourself. There's no reason to assume a population won't fall sharply when it's just rapidly overshot its carrying capacity.
BQEND
It's blindingly obvious that humans change the carrying capacity. It started with agriculture. Without modern agriculture, there is no way that 7 billion humans could be supported. There are no known hard limits on carrying capacity for humans. There are many identifiable risks but no known hard limits. For example, if push came to shove it would probably be possible to feed very large numbers of people using (possibly GM) algae and develop that capability quite quickly.
This is not to suggest that the huge human population does not have major adverse environmental impacts. Neither is it suggesting that indefinite population growth is desirable. It is, however, stating that crudely transcribing the notion of carrying capacity from biology/ecology to modern human societies is grossly misleading. Humans change the rules in ways that all other known forms of life are simply incapable of.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519697677000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4069809', u'in_reply_to': u'112754011', u'id': u'112772341', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'cumberdickbenepatch', u'text': u'Sorry, I didn't intend to imply that.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519696915000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15515196', u'in_reply_to': u'112737056', u'id': u'112772149', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'The US produces around 16 tons of CO2 per capita annually.

That is thought to be highly unlikely because of the distance from Earth to the Sun and the fact that the oceans didn't boil away during previous episodes of high atmospheric CO2 concentrations (and it would take around a billion years).
But consider that a population of a few million human hunter-gatherers was apparently beyond the carrying capacity of the planet as everywhere we showed up the megafauna disappeared.
Around 10-12,000 years ago, when large climate oscillations settled down, we developed agriculture which allowed us to double our population many times into the billions.
But agriculture faces big challenges if we don’t change our ways soon (1), as do our fisheries, and if they both decline significantly, forcing us back to being largely hunter-gatherers, history tells us that out of every 1000 people you see maybe one survives.
1 IPCC Western N America drought 1900-2100

Really?
Actually it's a matter of evidence.
There are about 8 million research scientists in the world.
Around 70,000 or so publish research papers connected to climate change.
The websites run by so-called climate sceptics constantly quote the same handful of scientists, because they don't have anyone else.
Most of their handful are retired - and are connected to various right-wing political 'think-tanks' in the USA, and/or various fringe eccentric religious organisations.
In fact, climate change is probably the most scrutinised area of science ever, and the current scientific position meets the standards of other scientific paradigms like evolution, plate tectonics, and relativity.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519684068000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"they do n't have anyone else", u'effect': u'the websites run by so called sceptics constantly quote the same handful of scientists'}], u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'112740683', u'id': u'112767241', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'What a boring planet we’re creating. description: Scientists are alarmed by a rise in mass mortality events – when species die in their thousands. Is it all down to climate change?
headline: d
og_fields.og:description: Scientists are alarmed by a rise in mass mortality events – when species die in their thousands. Is it all down to climate change?
og_fields.og:title: The terrifying phenomenon that is pushing species towards extinction
text:
There was almost something biblical about the scene of devastation that lay before Richard Kock as he stood in the wilderness of the Kazakhstan steppe. Dotted across the grassy plain, as far as the eye could see, were the corpses of thousands upon thousands of saiga antelopes. All appeared to have fallen where they were feeding.
Some were mothers that had travelled to this remote wilderness for the annual calving season, while others were their offspring, just a few days old. Each had died in just a few hours from blood poisoning. In the 30C heat of a May day, the air around each of the rotting hulks was thick with flies.
The same grisly story has been replayed throughout Kazakhstan. In this springtime massacre, an estimated 200,000 critically endangered saiga – around 60% of the world’s population – died. “All the carcasses in this one of many killing zones were spread evenly over 20 sq km,” says Kock, professor of wildlife health and emerging diseases at the Royal Veterinary College in London. “The pattern was strange. They were either grazing normally with their newborn calves or dying where they stood, as if a switch had been turned on. I’ve never seen anything like that.”
The saiga – whose migrations form one of the great wildlife spectacles – were victims of a mass mortality event (MME), a single, catastrophic incident that wipes out vast numbers of a species in a short period of time. MMEs are among the most extreme events of nature. They affect starfish, bats, coral reefs and sardines. They can push species to the brink of extinction, or throw a spanner into the complex web of life in an ecosystem. And according to some scientists, MMEs are on the rise and likely to become more common because of climate change.
The MME that has pushed the saiga closer to extinction struck in 2015. Kock was part of an international team studying the animals as they gathered for the calving season. For most of the year, saiga are on the move, able to avoid predatory wolves and human poachers by sprinting at more than 40mph, making them one of the fastest ungulates, or hoofed animals. But once a year they put their migration on pause to calve in vast groups when the grass is at its lushest, before it is scorched by the sun.
In 2015, the main gathering in the Betpak-Dala region of central Kazakhstan, an area roughly the size of the British Isles, numbered 250,000. Nearby, other groups were thousands strong. Saiga are remarkable animals. Their bulbous noses, which hang over their mouths, give these antelopes an almost comical appearance. The nose is flexible and can be inflated, helping them to breathe warm air in the freezing winters and filter air in the arid summers as they sprint with their heads down in a cloud of dust. The species has been hit by mass die-offs before. In 1981, around 70,000 died suddenly in a few days, while in 1988 another 200,000 died. The creatures are also victims of poachers.
These reports of mass mortality events are probably underestimates in terms of occurrence and sheer magnitude
“In 2014, we believed there were about 250,000 adults and they produced a good number of calves – perhaps a couple of hundred thousand. It looked a viable population and we’d expected a population of a million soon. There was even talk of them coming off the critically endangered list,” Kock says.
But as the scientists watched a year later, the mothers fell sick and began to drop dead. “It wasn’t as if the disease started at one end and spread – there was no time for transmission of the pathogen from animal to animal. It was too quick,” he says. “Within two or three days, everything was dying. By the end of the week, every single one was dead.”
The scientists on the ground pinpointed blood poisoning as the cause, but were puzzled as to why whole herds were dying so quickly. After 32 postmortems, they concluded the culprit was the bacterium Pasteurella multocida, which they believe normally lives harmlessly in the tonsils of some, if not all, of the antelopes. In a research paper published in January in Science Advances, Kock and colleagues contrasted the 2015 MME with the two from the 1980s. They concluded that a rise in temperature to 37C and an increase in humidity above 80% in the previous few days had stimulated the bacteria to pass into the bloodstream where it caused haemorrhagic septicaemia, or blood poisoning.
The weather link raises the spectre of climate change. Just as it is rarely wise to link a single extreme weather event – whether it’s the Australian heatwave, last summer’s Hurricane Harvey or this winter’s North American cold snap – to climate change, it is equally difficult to blame an MME on global warming. But what can be said with confidence is that the sorts of extreme weather events linked to MMEs – such as the temperature and humidity rise that nearly wiped out the saiga – will become more frequent.
Australians know all about extreme weather. While much of Europe and North America has endured a bitter start to the year, the Australian summer has been a scorcher. In January, temperatures in Sydney topped 47C, the city’s highest since 1939. The toll on wildlife has been devastating. As the mercury rose, corpses of critically endangered flying foxes – or fruit bats – began to pile up under the trees in New South Wales. Horrified wildlife campaigners at one colony in Campbelltown, south of Sydney, discovered 400 dead bats. Some were still hanging from trees. Many were babies, abandoned by their parents in their own desperate search for shade.
Flying foxes are well adapted to normal Australian summers. But above 40C, they are unable to regulate their body temperature and can die from overheating. This year’s deaths were grim enough, but they were dwarfed by the MME of 2014, when at least 45,000 flying foxes were killed on one hot day in south-east Queensland. Some colonies had more dead bodies than living bats. Their corpses were piled thick on the ground as the three species there – the black, little red and grey-headed – were hit.
Events like the disaster that struck the flying foxes and saiga appear to be growing in number. The most thorough study of its kind published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences in 2015 uncovered 727 accounts of MMEs involving 2,407 animal populations since 1940. It found that not only are reports of MMEs on the increase – by about one event a year – but the number of animals killed in each event is on the rise for birds, fish and marine invertebrates.
Adam Siepielski, an evolutionary ecologist at the University of Arkansas and a co-author of the paper, became fascinated by the phenomena after hearing a radio report of millions of sardines and anchovies dying. “These reports of MMEs are probably underestimates in terms of occurrence and sheer magnitude,” he says. “There is additionally a challenge in trying to understand whether this increased occurrence is a real event, or whether there are more people observing these things and [they are] more likely to report them. We call this the epidemic of awareness.”
The study found that disease was the biggest factor in MMEs, playing a role in a quarter of them. Around 19% were directly linked to human behaviour such as pollution. Factors linked directly to climate – including extremes of hot and cold, oxygen stress and starvation – collectively contributed to about a quarter.
Untangling the causes – and working out the role of climate change in MMEs is difficult. “In many cases, there are multiple stressors – such as, in the case of the saiga, a low-lying bacterial infection, slightly higher humidity and higher temperatures,” says Siepielski.
“There are some mass mortality events linked directly to extreme heatwaves or cold snaps. In other cases there could be indirect changes, where shifts in temperature cause diseases to be more common and which lead to an MME.”
That kind of temperature-related outbreak is now thought to lie behind one of the biggest die-offs ever observed in the natural world, in which hundreds of millions of starfish off the west coast of America began to “melt” into white gloop. More than 20 species of starfish along the coast from Mexico to Alaska were hit by the sea star wasting disease, a condition caused by a parvovirus – the group of viruses that cause gastrointestinal problems in animals. The virus left the starfish vulnerable to bacterial infection. Within one or two weeks of infection, white cuts appeared on their bodies and the creatures became listless. Some ripped off their infected arms and tried to walk away. But for most the disease was deadly. Like the bacteria that triggered the MME in saiga, the virus appears to have been present in starfish for decades – if not longer. Samples stored in museums since the 1940s tested positive.
An MME can push a species closer to extinction. But it can also have knock-on effects elsewhere in the fragile food web. In tidal pools on the west coast, where once there was a healthy mix of species, mussels – food for starfish – are starting to dominate. Off California, another source of starfish food, sea urchins, are also on the rise – causing a fall in the availability of kelp, the sea urchins’ main food source. That decline could hit species that depend on it for shelter, food and protection.
A paper published last year in the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society concluded that the die-off was probably linked to warmer seas. The team, led by Morgan Eisenlord at Cornell University, looked at the links between ocean temperatures and disease in the most common species on the west coast, the ochre sea star, as well as testing the effects of warmer water in the lab. Warmer than usual water didn’t just put the starfish under stress, it also made infectious agents more prevalent, they concluded.
Kock is confident that climate change will lead to more MMEs – pushing vulnerable species closer to extinction and altering the food web. He believes that conservationists should be on the lookout for other mortality events in species such as reindeer and elk. “The tragedy is, we will probably see more events like the event that affected the saiga,” he says. “Evolution takes millions of years and if we have a shift in environmental conditions, everything that’s evolved in that particular environment is under different pressures. Microbes adapt and can respond to changes quickly, but mammals take hundreds of thousands of years or millions of years to adapt. That’s the real worry.”

article_tags: [Fracking, Fossil fuels, Climate change, Energy, Environment, Energy industry, Business]
description: Fracking has been hailed as an energy miracle in the US, yet globally it faces blocks and even bans. Adam Vaughan explains what it is and why it is so controversial
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Fracking has been hailed as an energy miracle in the US, yet globally it faces blocks and even bans. Adam Vaughan explains what it is and why it is so controversial
og_fields.og:title: Fracking – the reality, the risksand what the future holds
text:
What is fracking?Hydraulic fracturing, or fracking as it is better known, is a method of extracting oil and gas trapped in shale and other rock formations.
The modern version involves pumping large amounts of water down a well at high pressure, along with sand and chemicals that make up a tiny fraction of the volume. Together, this “stimulation fluid” fractures the rock and releases the gas or oil, which flows to the surface. The hole drilled for a well is about the size of a manhole cover.
As the UK industry body explains, the sand is there to keep fractures in the rock open. The chemicals are included for several purposes, such as lubrication and keeping bacteria out.
The other big technological development that has made fracking economical is horizontal drilling. This means that several horizontal boreholes can be drilled off one well, like tributaries off a river, maximising the amount of oil and gas that can be recovered. This spring, either Third Energy in North Yorkshire or Cuadrilla in Lancashire will become the first company to frack in the UK since 2011.
Fracking can also be undertaken on a well that has already been drilled and for which conventional techniques were unable to extract more hydrocarbons.
What chemicals are used?Under UK regulations, operators have to submit a list of the chemicals they will use to the Environment Agency, or they will be refused consent. In the UK, one of the most commonly used chemicals is diluted hydrochloric acid. A government expert told the Guardian that in the case of a leak, the risk from the chemicals used is “very low”. In the US, the Environmental Protection Agency found a median of 14 chemicals for each sample it took. The most common were methanol (an alcohol), hydrochloric acid, and hydrotreated light petroleum distillates (a combination of hydrocarbons). 
Shale formations will be fractured at depths of more than 1km below the surface in the UK, after new regulations were introduced in 2015. The Kirby Misperton one, for example, is about 3,000m deep.
Who pioneered fracking?Fracking transformed the US energy landscape, putting the country on course to becoming a net exporter of oil after output declined over the last three decades of the 20th century. That trajectory means it is now starting to create similar shockwaves globally.
The modern version of fracking came of age in the late 1990s, unlocking oil and gas reserves across more than 20 US states. As a result, US oil production has increased faster than at anytime in the country’s history, dwarfing the giddy days of the country’s black gold rush in the 19th century. About half of US crude now comes from fracking. 
The boom has also been a boon for US householders, who have enjoyed falling gas prices to heat their homes and stable wholesale electricity prices. Around two-thirds of the country’s gas is produced by fracking.
The US now has so much oil and gas that it has dropped a decades long embargo on exports and is looking to step up shipments.
Dr Fatih Birol, executive director of the International Energy Agency, said the US is on course to become the world’s undisputed oil and gas growth story – and it’s because of fracking.
“What is happening in the US between now and 2025 [is] a huge expansion of oil production, about 80% of the global oil production growth comes from the US. It exceeds the huge expansion of Saudi Arabia which we witnessed in the 1960s and 70s,” he told the Guardian.
Where else is fracking taking place?For several years, Europe was talked up as a new frontier for shale exploration. Poland was seen as one of the most promising prospects, attracting US companies such as Chevron, ConocoPhillips and Exxon, as Warsaw hoped to ease its reliance on Russian gas. But the geology did not prove as promising as hoped and, one by one, companies pulled out. A similar pattern occurred in Romania.
Other European countries have gone further and banned fracking: France, Germany and Ireland have all imposed moratoriums. 
Despite bans in every part of the UK apart from England, the country now stands as one of the last parts of Europe where fracking firms are still actively drilling and hoping to frack.
While no well has been fracked since 2011 due to a moratorium, regulatory changes and planning delays, at least three sites look likely to be fracked in 2018. 
But even that new wave of activity looks fragile, with the sector at risk from any change in government. The SNP banned fracking in Scotland, while the 2017 election manifestos of Labour, the Liberal Democrats and Greens all promised fracking bans. 
The governing Conservative party still officially backs fracking, but has lately been much quieter in its support, with some MPs even questioning if there is still a need for it, and Conservative-controlled local authorities rejecting shale drilling applications. 
The right geology is key to success. The British Geological Survey found the best shale oil prospects are in southern England, in the Weald Basin between the North and South Downs. For gas, the group said the best resource appears to be in the Bowland shale, which stretches beneath much of Lancashire and Yorkshire.
On the other side of the world, the industry has largely stalled in Australia. 
Concerns over scarce water supplies have seen five of the country’s eight states and territories essentially temporarily banning fracking. The federal government wants to see the bans dropped, but polls have found 49% of Australians support the fracking ban in their state, compared to 24% against it.
Elsewhere in the southern hemisphere, South Africa and Argentina have both been eyed by fracking companies. But, as in many other parts of the world, neither country is yet to see a serious exploration and appraisal phase.
Why is fracking so controversial?The UK government has repeatedly said that fracking can be done safely and without harming the environment or human health, so long as it is properly regulated. New rules mean that companies have to closely monitor and report seismic activity, as well as potential water and air pollution.
But that’s not been the case throughout fracking’s history, particularly during some of the ‘wild west’ years when it grew rapidly in the US. 
Water contamination has been one of the biggest environmental concerns and where some of the most egregious incidents have occurred. A years-long piece of research by the US Environmental Protection Agency concluded in 2016 that in some cases fracking had harmed drinking water supplies. 
Most of the cases of water pollution in the US have involved boreholes that were not built properly, or mishandling of wastewater. Images of burning taps in the 2010 documentary Gasland arguably turbocharged the anti-fracking movement in the US, even though cases of gas contaminating water supplies have been hard to prove. 
What are the other concerns?Earthquakes caused by hydraulic fracturing have been another big concern. While the two earthquakes in 2011 that led to the UK’s fracking moratorium were both ranked minor on the Richter scale, the US has experienced much stronger ones. In Oklahoma, experts have reported a millennium’s worth of quakes in two years because of fracking there.
Other local concerns listed by fracking critics include industrialisation of rural areas, noise from lorries and the air pollution impact from flaring, when excess gas is burned off.
The big picture issue, of course, is climate change. Fracking advocates have argued the technology is good for global warming because, at least in the US, gas has been displacing coal in the power mix. 
But that coal is usually still burned elsewhere in the world, meaning fracking is simply adding to fossil fuel supplies – and the stock of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. 
The UK government was warned last year by its climate advisers that, without stricter rules, fracking on a large scale would bust the country’s legally-binding carbon targets.
It is this combination of local and global concerns that has galvanised a vocal, well-organised anti-fracking movement, including public figures such as author Naomi Klein and actor Mark Ruffalo.
What does the future hold?After years of delays, whether fracking in the UK ever takes off remains to be seen, but industry claims America’s continued progress will help them. UK-based iGas, which plans to frack one well and drill several others in 2018, told the Guardian it is taking advantage of advances in technology made in the US.
In the short term, fracking looks likely to stay as a largely American story, unless China decides to seriously invest in extracting its vast shale gas reserves, which are estimated to eclipse those in the US.
“What is happening in the US is all driven by the shale revolution,” said Birol. That revolution will have profound ramifications around the world for years to come, from Europe’s reliance on Russian gas to US foreign policy and headaches for the oil cartel, Opec.

As soon as you can figure out a way to get price discovery in a way that doesn't introduce all kinds of moral hazard issues, you need to let the world know. As it stands, merit-order pricing is the gold standard.
Wind & Solar always bid at $0; unless they can store the energy(which we are bravely told by some is just around the corner), there's no point doing otherwise. The nature of its supply-demand relationship makes electricity a little bit unique. They could organise amongst themselves to set a floor price, which is cartel-like behaviour and just a bit illegal. Also, in a world where they are the only providers, it's a scheme that lasts all of about 24 hours. No one wants to be the power plant that misses out on selling their product, so they undercut each other and we are back at $0 in the blink of an eye.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519784724000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16028971', u'in_reply_to': u'112828489', u'id': u'112828855', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathanSutanto', u'text': u'Currently 75% renewables (@ 1pm), 138gCO₂/kWh. BQEND
Sounds like a dumb market if it doesn't allow for profit and fixed costs in the bid price. The variable cost of production may be zero but basic economics/pricing theory requires a producer to recover their fixed costs and get a return.
If producers do bid below the total cost of production at $0 they collapse the market, but in most markets that is a form of "dumping" that drive others out of business and therefore is banned as uncompetitive. 
Renewables will reduce the market price but not to zero.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519783299000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3008405', u'in_reply_to': u'112823143', u'id': u'112828489', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathanSutanto', u'text': u'BQSTART

The press announcements this year so far are largely driven by the state election currently in progress, so 1) everyone is waiting for the dust to settle, to see what really holds up post-election, and 2) more renewables or storage, damages the prospects of existing projects, more than would otherwise be the case through simple competition.
This is the important point: that more of the same, either renewable generation or energy storage, will damage their own economic viability. In storage it is even more obvious, because it is fundamentally an exercise in arbitrage. And exploiting an arbitrage opportunity leads to the degradation of that same arbitrage opportunity. description: The number of cities getting at least 70% of their total electricity supply from renewable energy has more than doubled since 2015
og_fields.og:description: The number of cities getting at least 70% of their total electricity supply from renewable energy has more than doubled since 2015
og_fields.og:title: More than 100 cities now mostly powered by renewable energy, data shows
text:
The number of cities reporting they are predominantly powered by clean energy has more than doubled since 2015, as momentum builds for cities around the world to switch from fossil fuels to renewable sources.
Data published on Tuesday by the not-for-profit environmental impact researcher CDP found that 101 of the more than 570 cities on its books sourced at least 70% of their electricity from renewable sources in 2017, compared to 42 in 2015.
Nicolette Bartlett, CDP’s director of climate change, attributed the increase to both more cities reporting to CDP as well as a global shift towards renewable energy.
The data was a “comprehensive picture of what cities are doing with regards to renewable energy,” she told Guardian Cities.
That large urban centres as disparate as Auckland, Nairobi, Oslo and Brasília were successfully moving away from fossil fuels was held up as evidence of a changing tide by Kyra Appleby, CDP’s director of cities.
“Reassuringly, our data shows much commitment and ambition,” she said in a statement. “Cities not only want to shift to renewably energy, but, most importantly – they can.”
Much of the drive for climate action at city level in the past year has been spurred on by the global covenant of more than 7,400 mayors that formed in the wake of Donald Trump’s decision to withdraw from the Paris accord.
Burlington, Vermont, was the only US city reporting to CDP that sourced all of its power from renewable sources after having fully transitioned in 2015. Research from the Sierra Club states there are five such cities in the US in total.
Burlington is now exploring how to become zero-carbon.
Mayor Miro Weinberger said to CDP that its shift to a diverse mix of biomass, hydro, wind and solar power had boosted the local economy, and encouraged other cities to follow suit. Across the US 58 towns and cities, including Atlanta and San Diego, have set a target of 100% renewable energy.
In Britain, 14 more cities and towns had signed up to the UK100 local government network’s target of 100% clean energy by 2050, bringing the total to 84. Among the recent local authority recruits were Liverpool City Region, Barking and Dagenham, Bristol, Bury, Peterborough, Redcar and Cleveland.
But the CDP data showed 43 cities worldwide were already entirely powered by clean energy, with the vast majority (30) in Latin America, where more cities reported to CDP and hydropower is more widespread.
In the six months to July, Latin American cities reported having instigated $183m of renewable energy projects – less than Europe ($1.7bn) or Africa ($236m). Europe topped the list for projects open for investment, but laid claim to just 20% of the 101 cities to be predominantly powered by clean energy.
The Icelandic capital Reyjkavik, sourcing all electricity from hydropower and geothermal, was among them. It is now working to make all cars and public transit fossil-free by 2040.
Follow Guardian Cities on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram to join the discussion, and explore our archive here

[{u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'Something bugging you? Shoreline propery was a (ahem) joke son. The other comment about how good the satellite record functions, we could debate. This will cause a higher rise in the open ocean than at the coast because more energy is being absorbed there, it is not evenly distributed.
It affects the height of the water column at a location, but not the weight, so there is no flow between locations due to this component.

BQENDI disagree with your critique of the comment. Instead of raising the concern about the value of the satellite altimetry readings that were being used as the basis of this analysis, it glossed over the issue by making an aside about the "certainty of the measurement".

Of course you felt it was a good post. But you lack objectivity, are partisan, and are not too bothered about the science so long as it gives the answers you agree with.
Do you get it now?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520326591000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13022945', u'in_reply_to': u'113146431', u'id': u'113150674', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AvMichelCroz', u'text': u'BQSTART

BQENDActually no. Their paper does try to give the nod to the satellite altimetry, but simply does not agree with its results.
And I quote from the Abstract: 
BQSTART
"From 1972 to 2008, the observed sea-level rise (1.8 ± 0.2 mm yr−1 from tide gauges alone and 2.1 ± 0.2 mm yr−1 from a combination of tide gauges and altimeter observations) agrees well with the sum of contributions (1.8 ± 0.4 mm yr−1) in magnitude and with both having similar increases in the rate of rise during the period."
BQENDWhen this paper came out, the claimed rate of sea level rise from satellite altimetry was 3.3 mm/yr. Not only is this not within a bull's roar (well known scientific term) of the tide gauge result of 1.8 mm/yr, but it also does not correspond with the sum of contributions that the paper identified - which unsurprisingly agreed with the tide gauge results.
So the evidence has been there for some time that satellite altimetry is producing results that are at odds with sea level rise calculated by two independent means.
For normal science this would raise the alarm. But apparently not for the orthodoxy or for "climate science".
Perhaps you might care to explain, since you clearly have sufficient insight to have referred to the 2011 Church et al paper.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520326278000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13022945', u'in_reply_to': u'113145127', u'id': u'113150430', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'KingInYellow', u'text': u'BQSTART

Its that simple."
Incorrect! Your criticism of Erik's comment, which was a few words in a much longer post, was unfounded. I would remind you that you ridiculed it when the evidence showed it was basically correct.
"The heavier O18 precipitates out at lower latitudes leaving the O16 for the high lattitudes, so, as ice builds up in the polar regions the O18/O16 ratio changes. And glacial coverage is an indicator of temperature."
First of all, O18 in water doesn't "precipitate". However, they key point to understand is that more O18 ends up in ice in warmer conditions because it is easier for the heavier O18 water molecule to evaporate in such conditions, meaning that precipitation will contain a slightly higher proportion of O18. From the article you linked to:
"In fact, it has been shown that a decrease of one part per million 18O in ice reflects a 1.5°C drop in air temperature at the time it originally evaporated from the oceans."
"..which brings me back to my original point - how have you concluded the ETCW is simply a north polar phenomonen when in fact this method for calculating temperature has more to do with lower lattitudes?"
Did you not bother to read the papers I linked to above? Although there was some warming across the northern hemisphere over the ETCW period, there was a very pronounced warming in the Arctic. Also, if you read the paper you linked to, it points out that the enriched O18 in the ice cores of the early 20th century coincides with the ETCW previously discussed by others.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520323744000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it is easier for the heavier o18 water molecule to evaporate in such conditions meaning that precipitation will contain a slightly higher proportion of o18', u'effect': u'that more o18 ends up in ice in warmer conditions'}], u'author_id': u'16473314', u'in_reply_to': u'113143649', u'id': u'113148709', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'KingInYellow', u'text': u'BQSTART
Im not any expert in ice cap melting over the last 20,000 years mr Kingy. I couldnt begin to tell you the mechanisms behind it,
BQEND
That is patently obvious.
BQSTART
and the trend really is ice caps melting when looking at that timescale.
BQEND
Incorrect.There is no trend of melting ice caps.

Twentieth-Century Global-Mean Sea Level Rise: Is the Whole Greater than the Sum of the Parts?

BQSTART
In the last two decades, the rate of GMSLR has been larger than the twentieth-century time mean, because of increased rates of thermal expansion, glacier mass loss, and ice discharge from both ice sheets (Church et al. 2011). There may also be increasing contributions to GMSLR from the effects of water resource engineering: groundwater depletion is a positive and increasing term; the contribution from reservoir impoundment was negative in the twentieth century but may now be positive, as existing reservoirs become silted up.

The heavier O18 precipitates out at lower latitudes leaving the O16 for the high lattitudes, so, as ice builds up in the polar regions the O18/O16 ratio changes. And glacial coverage is an indicator of temperature.
""H2O is evaporated from sea water. The oxygen in the H2O is enriched in the lighter 16O. This H2O condenses in clouds, falling on land as precipitation. Thus, H2O that is part of the terrestrial water cycle is enriched in the light 16O isotope and sea water is enriched in the heavier 18O isotope. Glacial ice is therefore made up primarily of water with the light 16O isotope. This leaves the oceans enriched in the heavier 18O, or “more positive.” During glacial periods, more 16O is trapped in glacial ice and the oceans become even more enriched in 18O. During interglacial periods, O16 melts out of ice and the oceans become less 18O rich, or “more negative” in 18O"" http://pages.uoregon.edu/rdorsey/geo334/O-isotopes.html

Seriously."
Your example of the CO2 annual cycle is a very poor analogy. Either you're being deliberately obtuse or you aren't as clever as you think. You are missing a key step in the process of "critical thinking": scientific reasoning.
In case you hadn't noticed, this is science we're discussing; science is specific and requires careful attention to detail. The reason why I picked you up on your assertion about sea levels rising for 20,000 years is because you were using it as part of an obvious narrative to give the impression that the present sea level rise is nothing unusual. However, when you consider the full picture, your assertion is patently false in every detail.
Empirical physics is sufficient to say that ice will retreat and sea levels rise in response to a warming of the planet. As albedo is a key positive feedback, minimum ice extent should coincide fairly closely with the highest temperatures, but sea level may well lag a little behind...... but certainly not thousands of years!
Evidence from a variety of proxy records show that the mid-Holocene "optimum" was reached at least 5000 years ago and that temperatures have declined a little since then:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holocene_climatic_optimum#/media/File:Holocene_Temperature_Variations.png
Certainly, temperatures (and hence sea level) have fluctuated somewhat since this period, but the net direction of travel has been slightly down rather than up. The sea level reconstructions don't go back far enough to make this obvious. However, what is obvious is that the past 200 years have seen a comparatively rapid rise and physics dictates that this will continue unabated for as long as the Earth warms.
"i know very little about science in the scheme of things.and it will probably remain that way... . Same goes for you Paul."
I know I'm not an expert, but with a science based PhD and having followed the evolving research in this field for the best part of 40 years now, I do have a pretty good "feel" for it.
"OOh? Where have you demonstrated this trait in our discussion?"
Perhaps you misunderstood the point I was making. I know the limits to my knowledge and understanding. As I pointed out on a previous thread, if I spot something in the science that doesn't seem to make sense, I know it is far more likely that I have missed something than the professional scientists! I will, where time allows, go and read up until I discover the point I was missing. After all these years, I have never encountered a situation where I was right and the researchers wrong!
You, on the other hand, have started from the position that there is no acceleration in sea level rise and simply cherry-picked older papers that appear to conform to your narrative. For the record, what you actually said in response to KingInYellow (ie. not Erik, as you previously claimed)was:
"Ever since the last glacial maximum (20,000 odd years ago) - sea level has been rising due to melting ice caps and thermal expansion."
This statement is demonstrably false.', u'recommendation_count': u'13', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520115891000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16473314', u'in_reply_to': u'113040371', u'id': u'113043904', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BuzzBloodOhio space', u'text': u'""Now, if you really reckon you're such an expert, it's time to write that paper!"" oh im very far from an expert in sea level and its measurement.
I'm pretty sharp with critical thinking though, and hopefully after finishing this degree i'll be able to publish my own findings. Although it wont be on sea level. It'll probably be on Atmospheric processes and clouds.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520114883000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17722198', u'in_reply_to': u'113007561', u'id': u'113043283', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BuzzBloodOhio space', u'text': u'"When you posted a series of links to papers that you have been shown are not global, you were trying to show what ?""
Correction - one was global, one was not. The non-global one was Houston & Dean 2011.. and i wrote 
""The key is that the latest satellite data is highly unreliable..
as " Sea-Level Acceleration Based on U.S. Tide Gauges and Extensions of Previous Global-Gauge Analyses" Houston & Dean (2011) states:
"measurements were in good agreement up until 1999 and thenbegan to diverge with the altimeters recording a significantlyhigher sea-level trend than worldwide-tide gauge records.Domingues et al. say that an explanation for the divergence is‘‘urgently needed’’ (p. 1092) This divergence adds significantuncertainty to the altimeter measurements because tide-gaugerecords are used to calibrate the altimeter and correct for drift(Bindoff et al. , 2007)."""
You and the other posters here have a serious problem with keeping tabs on the actual conversation. 
""Pull the other one, your efforts to undermine a paper on GMSLR trend accelerating with dated papers that miss the latest global data sets is just a continuing exercise in FUD.""""
Erm, thats just patently false. ive linked a handful of papers - one is global showing no sea level rise, one is with satellite altimetry showing no acceleration, one is quoted (as above) as evidence the satellite data (post 1999) isnt robust..
So, my conclusion looking at the available peer reviewed literature is that sea level acceleration only exists in the JASON 1/2 satellite records, and ive shown that those records are not reliable - and even linked to NASA's reasoning for why they want to replace JASON2.. 
But hey, if you want to take one paper as gospel, that uses 25 years of data - relies on the last 10yrs, while literature out there disputes using such data, and come to such a conclusion, you go for it! I wont.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520110292000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'tide gaugerecords are used to calibrate the altimeter and correct for drift(bindoff', u'effect': u'this divergence adds significantuncertainty to the altimeter measurements'}], u'author_id': u'17722198', u'in_reply_to': u'113014744', u'id': u'113040642', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BuzzBloodOhio space', u'text': u'""Of course it's key, because any long term trend in sea level has to have a physical explanation."
I fail to see your purpose in your messages Paul. Like this point you make isnt obvious? You seem to want to hijack my original comments with your own agenda, or obfuscate it into some quasy climate denial speak so you can then show me how wrong I am. I'm fully aware of the research and findings of sea level on a holocene timescale - and my original comment still holds true that the ice sheets have been melting for thousands of years. 20,000 to be exact.
Now if you wanted to get more detailed about it, sure you could outline all the rise and fall periods within that 20,000 - the Earth has too many shifts in climate to even outline here, but by and large the biggest trend in thousands of years has been a large sea level rise. I dont think there's any reason to discuss this (boring) point anymore really..', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1520109676000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'any long term trend in sea level has to have a physical explanation', u'effect': u"of course it 's key"}], u'author_id': u'17722198', u'in_reply_to': u'113007511', u'id': u'113040371', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: John Abraham: Faster melting of ice sheets is speeding up sea level rise
headline: i
og_fields.og:description: John Abraham: Faster melting of ice sheets is speeding up sea level rise
og_fields.og:title: Scientists have detected an acceleration in sea level rise | John Abraham
text:
As humans emit heat-trapping gases like carbon dioxide, the planet warms, and over time consequences become more apparent. Some of the consequences we are familiar with – for instance, rising temperatures, melting ice, and rising sea levels. Scientists certainly want to know how much the Earth has changed, but we also want to know how fast the changes will be in the future to know what the next generations will experience.
One of the classic projections into the future is for sea level rise. It is expected that by the year 2100, the ocean levels will rise a few feet by the end of the century. This matters a lot because globally, 150 million people live within three feet of current ocean levels. We have built our modern infrastructure based on current ocean levels. What happens to peoples’ homes and infrastructure when the waters rise?
But projecting ocean levels into the future is not simple; we need good data that extends back decades to understand how fast the climate is changing. The classic way to measure ocean levels is by using tide gauges. These are placed just offshore, around the globe to get a sense of how the ocean levels are changing. The problem with tide gauges is they only measure water levels at their location, and their locations are always near shore. 
In order to get a better sense of how oceans are changing everywhere, a complementary technology called satellite altimetry is used. Basically, the satellites shoot a radar beam from space to the ocean surface and watch for the reflection of the beam back to space. From this beam, the satellite can calculate the height of the water. Satellites can emit beams continuously as the satellite passes over open oceans, and can gather data far from shorelines. In doing so, they provide the equivalent of a global network of nearly half a million tide gauges, providing sea surface height information every 10 days for over 25 years.
Just recently, in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, a paper has been published that collects all the available satellite altimetry data and asks whether the sea level rise is accelerating. The authors of the paper are a well-respected team and include Dr. Steven Nerem from the Cooperative Institute for Research in Environmental Sciences (CIRES) and Dr. John Fasullo, from the National Center for Atmospheric Research. 
The authors collected data from four generations of satellites that have carried out this altimetry task. The most recent satellite is called Jason 3, launched in 2016. The satellites generate the data shown below. While in any given year ocean levels may rise a bit or fall a bit, the authors focused on the long-term trend (the white line). They found that the long-term trend is, indeed, accelerating. The rate of acceleration is approximately 0.084 mm per year per year. That may not sound like much, but were this rate of acceleration to continue (a conservative estimate), the authors project that by the end of the century oceans with rise approximately 65 cm (more than two feet). 
In the study, the authors quantified what was causing the ocean waters to rise. Part of the rise is related to what’s called thermal expansion (warmer water is less dense so it expands). In the past, this was responsible for the majority of sea level rise. More recently, however, melting ice has contributed more and more to sea level rise. As land-based ice melts, the liquid water flows into the oceans and increases the mass of water in the oceans.
The two largest ice sheets (also the two largest contributors to sea level rise) are found on Greenland and Antarctica. There are other sources of melting ice, such as mountain-top glaciers that also are contributing, but the lion’s share of melting contribution is from the Greenland and Antarctica ice sheets.
Is this acceleration very important? Well the authors answer that question. They calculate that the acceleration will cause more than half of the sea level rise that will occur by the year 2100. Right now, sea levels are rising at a rate of about 3 mm per year. If that rate remained constant until the year 2100 (no acceleration), oceans would be about 25 cm higher than they are today. But a continued acceleration would cause a rise of 65 cm. So, this seemingly small acceleration makes a huge impact. 
The authors are careful to note that if anything, their results are conservative. They don’t account for potential catastrophic losses of major ice sheets. Just recently a study appeared that showed an acceleration in land-ice loss from Antarctica. Meanwhile, at the northern tip of our planet, temperatures are soaring. If these trends continue, we may be in store for a rude awakening with a rapid destabilization in a major ice sheet that would have dire implications for coastal communities around the world.

If it was costing no more, I'd buy EV, but that would only work if I was doing a much greater mileage than do. So my car saves the planet not by being an EV, but by not being used much.p', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519891496000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2602427', u'in_reply_to': u'112863187', u'id': u'112897266', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'johnbok', u'text': u'If there are "enough" charging points, then they are not evenly spread around the country.
