Include this in your next green article', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519864030000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17975026', u'id': u'112888438', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'local_lad', u'text': u'The Nissan leaf is a great car and is another example like Tesla, if they can produce good cars with good ranges, where are the fords, the GMs, the Merc etc. If they wanted to sell the cars they could, currently demand outstrips supply for many of the models available.Hopefully the Jag ipace will create some pressure to get more models launched.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519856177000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11866446', u'in_reply_to': u'112872236', u'id': u'112883837', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'christophertill', u'text': u'Obviously lack of choice is the problem. Range is basically solved. And public charging is good enough and getting better every day. It will be outstanding in short order. But with the ranges of new cars, how often are you going to be charging away from home anyway?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519853655000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4266804', u'id': u'112882264', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Guess11', u'text': u'You might want to reconsider that link! Dynamos in the wheels of an electric car as a power source? Perpetual motion machine, methinks!', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519849893000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4520258', u'in_reply_to': u'112801906', u'id': u'112879308', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'HairyDave', u'text': u'BQSTART
Finally, small vans? I want a vehicle like a Berlingo.
BQEND
You mean like the Electric Berlingo? It's only £500 more expensive than the fossil fuel version after grants are taken into account. Admittedly it doesn't currently have much range. Presumably that's at least partly due to Citroen trying to match the prices of the two models. Given the cost of batteries has been falling rapidly, it probably won't be long before it's got a significantly better range for the same price.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519849456000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1525023', u'in_reply_to': u'112814315', u'id': u'112878963', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'HairyDave', u'text': u'BQSTART
There is not sufficient capacity to have just electric vehicles on the road...Put in hydrogen Infrastructure and have all cars run on that
BQEND
You would have to generate the hydrogen from electrolysis using renewable energy for it to be carbon emissions free, store this under pressure and then use this in a fuel cell. This is less efficient than simply charging an EV battery, so your comment makes no sense. If there isn't sufficient capacity for EVs, there's even less capacity for hydrogen.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519848657000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1525023', u'in_reply_to': u'112809186', u'id': u'112878310', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Rosemary Maddock', u'text': u'Has anyone thought of cyclists. BQEND
What do you base that on?
Being on a smart meter has nothing to do with dual tariff supplies.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519841709000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13885577', u'in_reply_to': u'112832644', u'id': u'112872494', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'75drayton', u'text': u'But Tesla do not dominate the market. They get the most press luv but AFAIK the Nissan Leaf outsells all of the Tesla models.
If i am wrong please do provide links, and I will stop suggesting that Tesla do not dominate the market.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519841358000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13885577', u'in_reply_to': u'112814051', u'id': u'112872236', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'derekthetree', u'text': u'Its not the numbers that are the problem, its the geographic spread, differing charger sockets and mainly the differing access systems that are the issue.

BQENDComplete nonsense. That's Tesco thinking, you need 10 varieties of canned tomato before a customer comes through the door. Lidl showed one variety at half the price will outsell it.
EVs at the moment are hampered by not fitting the usage pattern of existing car buyers. THe life of a mid size car has to cope with several phases. Heavy use at the beginning as part of a fleet is going to see range problems. Battery leasing makes lighter use by the second or third owner uneconomic. There is a market for EV but it's a fairly narrow band. They buy new, have a regular commute distance within range and keep up that pattern of use for 6-10 years. 
Charging isn't a problem for most households, two thirds of UK households have a garage or off road parking. Public charging points are only for occasional use, it's far cheaper overnight on the drive and there's no pressure to free the space for the next vehicle. It's mostly about cost, the premium for buying an EV new isn't paid back outside specific use patterns and the second hand market isn't mature enough yet to be sure of the resale value.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519822311000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2602427', u'id': u'112850267', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ChicagoSoph', u'text': u'With the current weather this is absolutely my favourite feature of my EV. A high speed pump, like they have in motorway services, 80 litres a minute and the pumps used by trucks, delivery diesel at 130 litres per minute. 
So if I want to add 90 miles of range (typical range of an EV) to my old petrol "gas guzzling" estate... which does 30 MPG... I need 3 gallons, which rounding up is 15 litres but lets make the maths easy and be kind to the EVs... and go for 20 litres... which will take me 30 seconds to pump at your plane old fashioned petrol station.
If EV manufacturers could make their cars, as efficient as taking on energy as old fashioned petrol cars... everyone would be buying them. Who cares if you have to stop every ninety miles.... if it would only takes 30 seconds to recharge?

If you do not have dedicated off road parking at home or work you will be usually stuck with using rapid charging. Right a 50KW charger will get you 25KWh into your battery in half an hour. That's about 80 miles driving. So if your are used to shoving 50 litres in 5 minutes once a month to go for say 600 miles you had better get used to charging more than once a week for half and hour each time instead.Progress? Well it gets better. When and where to charge? On the way home from work whilst doing a bit of shopping at the local supermarket. So all around the country at 5.30 p.m. in January in the dark and freezing cold with no wind and the National Grid already breaching past 50GW demand and creaking under the strain.........100,000 cars nationally want to add 50KW each. Houston we have a problem.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519769776000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11644402', u'id': u'112823125', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TBombadil', u'text': u'Hydrogen cars can be recharged for a 300 mile range in a few minutes in comparison to half an hour to recharge an electric car for 100 mile range. So there are some advantages to the hydrogen powered cars but their development is several years behind the pure electric cars. I suspect both will be in use but with the choice dependent on the application.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519807168000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3382782', u'in_reply_to': u'112807708', u'id': u'112834702', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TBombadil', u'text': u'BQSTART
they are partly wind and solar-powered in the UK around a quarter of the UK's power mix last year was from renewables including biomass
BQEND
If you switch your electricity supply to a company like Good Energy or Ecotricity, then for every KWh you take from the grid they will supply and charge you for 1KWh of renewable energy. Most of their supply does come from wind and solar with small contributions from hydro and biomass, so it is possible to power electric cars from renewable sources.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519805949000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3382782', u'in_reply_to': u'112801906', u'id': u'112834058', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'raykalon', u'text': u'It got up my nose as well - surely a guy with an English degree (who knows sweet fa about science and engineering) could at least get that bit right.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519768974000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11644402', u'in_reply_to': u'112806539', u'id': u'112822752', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Darren', u'text': u'BQSTART
Look forward to hearing what car buyers think about this. 
While the range of electric car models available today is pretty small, I suspect perception about charging points is still putting people off (even though are 15,000 in the UK to the 120,000-plus EVs and plug-in EVs).
BQEND
In all honesty it's not that but just that I'm not interested in EV's just now so am sticking with the combustion engine.
I'm a petrol head so am selfishly enjoying the best of what's on offer until the roar of a straight six/V8 etc. gets consigned to history.
In the interim I'm more likely to move to hybrid but only when car manufacturers actually make something for the enthusiast. Driving an EV/hybrid need not be a bore-fest but it seems that way right now. The possible exception is stuff from Tesla but I'm not sinking £70k+ on something that will be obsolete in 18 months.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519805896000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17835314', u'in_reply_to': u'112801231', u'id': u'112834032', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'raykalon', u'text': u'That "statistic" is about as valid as the old 60's claim that the average British household had 2.4 children when no such thing could possibly exist. Figures like that are known as the arithmetic meaningless.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519768689000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11644402', u'in_reply_to': u'112810766', u'id': u'112822588', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'raykalon', u'text': u'Good point, I looked at a Leaf when changing my second car. Hyundai i20 with a zillion extras thrown in for £10,500 cash. The Leaf never stood a chance.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519768341000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11644402', u'in_reply_to': u'112817796', u'id': u'112822429', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Adam1', u'text': u'They can be. My wishlist includes a zappi home charger that can be set to trickle charge from your onsite renewables. Good for homeowners with solar or wind and off street parking. For everyone else they'll have to wait for the grid to go 100% renewable. That said, charging overnight (cheaper off peak) is already low carbon (even 320g CO2 per kWh = 50g per km in an EV that gets 4 miles per kWh) and we often get below 200g per kWh at night and the grid's carbon intensity is dropping year by year.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519805281000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1418047', u'in_reply_to': u'112801601', u'id': u'112833774', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Adam1', u'text': u'Am just pre-heating the EV now from remote app...happy windscreen scraping fossil owners. [/smugness off] :)', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519804640000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1418047', u'id': u'112833524', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'raykalon', u'text': u'Well spotted. I take it that as it is a projection only it cannot be disputed at this stage. In reality it could be complete fiction.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519768049000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11644402', u'in_reply_to': u'112814328', u'id': u'112822285', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'malibudebumbum', u'text': u'I think they are deliberately over-pricing electric vehicles to protect their dealer networks. A Nissan Leaf is £25,000 - a car without an exhaust system, a gearbox or radiator. Makes you wonder. Allow £1,000 depreciation per year. Spend £15,000 on a new car & you expect 15 years out of it. Would you get 25 years out of a new Nissan Leaf?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519767755000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13873352', u'id': u'112822134', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Adam1', u'text': u'Lots of vehement opinions are being expressed BTL here from non-EV owners. The article is correct in saying that there are too few types of EV. No equivalent to a transit van yet. Trucks are on the way but not ready to buy today. Buses are coming too - not sure about the economics there.
For private car users EVs already meet most owners' needs. The problem is for people without off street parking. Costs are comparable with equivalent fossil cars. There are second hand EVs out there, quite a few EV owners where I live drive them. Fuel and maintenance savings outweigh the extra cost of purchase. And EVs are easier, less stressful and more fun to drive. Ethical issues around sourcing of materials are certainly no worse than the fossil fuel industry (Iraq war anyone).', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519804452000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1418047', u'id': u'112833451', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'doge', u'text': u'Lousy deal, £8000 down, Loan cost £29500 with 4.9% interest!
Forget it.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519756458000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2977981', u'in_reply_to': u'112812847', u'id': u'112814435', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'raykalon', u'text': u'"In England, the average driver is four miles from a charging point,"Is it just me or did nobody else notice the singularity in that sentence. And that is my only point!', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519767727000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11644402', u'id': u'112822113', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Newmacfan', u'text': u'I am currently on the look out for a car.....two things, which amaze me, they are not interested in anything apart from selling their financial packages with a car.....which is frankly disgusting! On the electric cars, if you take the "cold" into account, the distances you can "guarantee" in an electric car are still not acceptable, unless you want to go big big money? I am waiting for a 150 mile single trip, in the cold, in the dark with heaters and music playing.....when they will guarantee that, I will go for some test drives. The other problem is the batteries, longevity, cost, do you buy or lease.....it is still a bit of a minefield and there are no concrete answers....yet. Maybe yesterday's news from Bristol are going to hearald some good news?', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519803060000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4682771', u'id': u'112833025', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ChicagoSoph', u'text': u'Actually Smart meters will make it easier to charge your car at off peak times when power is cheaper.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519801748000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2500341', u'in_reply_to': u'112814881', u'id': u'112832644', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jl5480', u'text': u'And when the local kids start vandalising them?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519756419000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10101060', u'in_reply_to': u'112811352', u'id': u'112814405', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'raykalon', u'text': u'The notion of a hydrogen infrastructure is false. All that is needed is a potable water supply,a three phase electricity supply and these.http://www.itm-power.com/product/hfuelhttp://www.itm-power.com/news-item/first-hydrogen-refuelling-station-with-shell-opensThere are less than 8500 filling stations in the entire UK and all that is needed is to plug in and play.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519767517000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11644402', u'in_reply_to': u'112811642', u'id': u'112822025', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID9066711', u'text': u'"What if you turn up at the services and the chargers are in use? Add an extra hour to the trip waiting?"
The electric highway app tells you if "pumps" are occupied, so you can stop elsewhere. Think it's happened twice in the year I've been an EV owner - once I drove onto the next services, the other time the fella charging saw me waiting and terminated his charge early - one of the benefits of being an early adopter is the sense of community. No doubt that'll change as they become more popular.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519767226000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2960210', u'in_reply_to': u'112814464', u'id': u'112821867', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Cavirac', u'text': u'I have a fast charging point (the charger is in the car by the way). It has a 16A breaker, same as my electric oven. The charging point is intelligent in that it knows when it's off peak then charges the car. It can be switched between normal and fast charge depending on your car use and when you next want to use it. The only snag with fast charging older cars is that it can reduce the life expectancy of the batteries by about half if you do it all the time. Mine is a company car so not my problem.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519801504000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4522871', u'in_reply_to': u'112823125', u'id': u'112832591', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ChicagoSoph', u'text': u'Don't you care about air quality in your city?', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519801407000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2500341', u'in_reply_to': u'112831099', u'id': u'112832566', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'thedoc', u'text': u'Question about why add a graph about the expected charging points in 2 years time. What does this prove? Why not have actual figures in this article? Where is Spain in this graph? A country where wages are quite low but charges for electricity are one of the most expensive in Europe.The graph is published by the Platform for Electromobility.reading the website FAQ does not quite give the same headline as this article.
BQSTART
Q: What share will electro-mobility take in the upcoming years? A: The future market will depend upon the development of the ecosystem but there are already some encouraging signs, both from the public and private sectors.
BQEND
Nothing about the lack of models in that quote, or anywhere else from what I read.
And to be honest the whole website is full of 1984 double speak I in the end had to give up.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519756322000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1930708', u'id': u'112814328', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'raykalon', u'text': u'Nice one!', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519767109000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11644402', u'in_reply_to': u'112813580', u'id': u'112821795', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'raykalon', u'text': u'Regarding your solutions link, do you what is the power rating of the connection is?A conventional street lamp circuit would have only been wired to handle a modest lighting load probably measured in watts not kilowatts.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519766885000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11644402', u'in_reply_to': u'112816794', u'id': u'112821685', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Cavirac', u'text': u'Assuming your talking about new existing models rather than second hand ones I work in Ford R&D here in Germany and that is exactly the route they are going down.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519801143000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4522871', u'in_reply_to': u'112828854', u'id': u'112832508', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Cavirac', u'text': u'I think the government should offer councils incentives to move to electric vans where possible for a start. This is happening more and more in Europe.
Councils in turn can offer incentives in big cities and towns. Many people have to use on road parking for which they can pay massive annual fees. There is a company going around modifying lamp posts so they can also charge cars. Why not offer a reduction in the annual on road parking fees for those that own electric cars? It would be worth it because these people are helping to reduce emissions in their city/town making it a more attractive and safer place to live. It might also help the NHS in these areas by reducing the amount of asthma suffers (over time of course). Better to lead with a carrot than beat with a stick is my philosophy.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519800983000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'these people are helping to reduce emissions in their city town', u'effect': u'it would be worth it'}], u'author_id': u'4522871', u'id': u'112832467', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ChicagoSoph', u'text': u'This is very true. I can pay to park my car in many places using my phone, why can't paying to charge the car be as simple?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519756321000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2500341', u'in_reply_to': u'112813494', u'id': u'112814326', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jl5480', u'text': u'So your ev won't do my annual two day trip from Yorkshire to the Vendee on two five minute fillups then. In fact, it will struggle to get me to the Eurotunnel.
Secondly, where in the Pennines are charging points? I live in a terraced house where parking is on the road.
Finally, small vans? I want a vehicle like a Berlingo. 
Would be happy if they did a petrol electric version.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519756308000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10101060', u'in_reply_to': u'112812415', u'id': u'112814315', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'nick kelly', u'text': u'"suppressing electric cars, which is shameful" 
What is shamefully nutty is thinking the makers would avoid a product on which they make a profit. So far no one does, Tesla being the poster child. This is not a 'build it and they will come' business. That's how you go bust. The public is slowly catching on and yes charging stations are spreading. But this is not a burger biz where you try a jalapeno cheddar melt and if it doesn't sell you try something else. The availability of electrics has to lag demand. Apparently the Nissan Leaf is back ordered and GM's Bolt is doing well. But this is not GM's first rodeo with an electric. 
One personal feeling: I would like an electric purely for its fuel savings. To me (not a spring chicken) they have no cool factor beyond the "look at me I'm different' which IS a factor. I no more want an electric than I want an automatic trans. I like the rumble of the exhaust and the slight vibration as the motor revs. To me a electric sports car is a contradiction. 
OK so maybe I'm a minority, but a car maker has to be very careful about tooling up based on 'cool' because it can sure change fast. This is a problem for the Japanese as they try to analyze the US male buyer. Who does he want to be this year: James Bond, Crocodile Dundee or a rancher. For the latter a free bale of straw to throw in the box of the truck which may not see another load for months.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519766172000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it can sure change fast', u'effect': u'a car maker has to be very careful about tooling up based on cool'}], u'author_id': u'14563109', u'id': u'112821271', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: Analysis shows just 20 battery models on sale in Europe against more than 400 conventional ones
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Analysis shows just 20 battery models on sale in Europe against more than 400 conventional ones
og_fields.og:title: Lack of models, not charging points, 'holding back electric car market'
text:
The rise of electric cars in Europe is being hampered by a lack of models for consumers to choose from rather than a lack of public recharging points, according to energy companies and carmakers.
Some motoring groups and insurers have warned over the past year that the number of chargers is putting the switch to electric transport at risk. But an analysis by the Platform for Electromobility – whose 31 members include Tesla, Renault-Nissan, Brussels-based campaign group T&E and industrial groups Siemens and Alstom – found there are already enough points in Europe.
Across the EU, there are about six electric cars for each public charging point, almost twice as many as the 10 cars per point recommended by the European commission. Charging infrastructure is expected to keep pace with the number of electric cars on the road until at least 2020, based on a review of governments’ plans. One fast charger is expected for every 40km of highway by 2020, well ahead of the one per 65km that Brussels wants by 2025.
Greg Archer, one of the authors of the analysis, said: “It is a myth that has been spread by the car industry to create the impression they would love to sell more electric cars but there just isn’t the charging points out there. It’s a smokescreen.”
A sufficient number of public chargers is essential if the electric car market is to grow beyond the early adopters who have access to off-street parking and can charge at home, the group said. Provided governments deliver on their plans, it’s seen as unlikely that there will be a shortfall in public points.
By comparison, carmakers have launched only a small number of fully electric models. There are just 20 battery electric vehicles on sale in Europe against 417 conventional petrol and diesel ones, according to T&E.
Some of the electric models, such as the Opel Ampera-E – known as the Chevy Bolt in the US – are on limited supply and have months-long waiting times.
“The car industry has deliberately suppressed the market for electric cars, which is shameful,” said Archer. 
Next Green Car, an online guide that monitors the electric car market, expects about 13 new fully electric car models in the UK this year. These include the new Nissan Leaf, which is aimed at the mass market, and the high-end Jaguar i-Pace, the British carmaker’s first all-electric vehicle. A further 19 models are expected to go on sale in the UK during 2019.
Experts told MPs on Tuesday that a lack of models was holding back growth in electric cars, but that was likely to change soon.
“The key barriers we’re seeing is the range of vehicles on the market at the moment,” Andrew Benfield, the group director of transportation at the Energy Saving Trust, told the business, energy and industrial strategy select committee.
Mark Squires, the head of the industry group that represents car dealers, said: “There isn’t a broad range of pure electric vehicles available.”
But the choice issue is likely to be addressed in the next two years, MPs were told. “There are some very viable cars coming in the next 18 months,” said Georg Ell, director of western Europe at Tesla. He also confirmed the firm had taken UK orders for its electric semi-truck, which it unveiled last year.
However, Squires said some drivers still believed there were not enough charging points. “There is a perception, it may not be the full reality, that easy charging access is going to be an issue and that is putting consumers off,” he said.
In England, the average driver is four miles from a charging point, in Scotland it is three miles and in Wales it is 12 miles, the Energy Saving Trust has found. 
The worst area is Devon, with an average of 45 miles, and the best is London, with a tenth of a mile in some boroughs. “What we’re seeing is something of a postcode lottery,” said Benfield.
A growing number of energy companies are moving into car charging infrastructure, such as Npower’s German owner, Innogy, and Italy’s Enel, while the UK’s National Grid is in talks with carmakers to build a network of super rapid chargers at motorway service stations.
The car industry rejected the charge it was not making enough electric models available.
“Europe’s auto manufacturers undertake every effort to make e-mobility a success,” said a spokesperson for the European carmakers’ body, the ACEA. “Apart from manufacturing electric vehicles, we also need to consider factors that are beyond the auto industry’s responsibility, such as investments in the necessary recharging infrastructure.”

Quite possibly.', u'recommendation_count': u'15', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519762205000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4580224', u'id': u'112818711', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'BQSTART
Can anyone explain how historically rising CO2 levels always followed rising temperatures rather than preceeding them?
BQEND
Yes.
That's the case in a specific context, which doesn't apply now.
That lag is seen in cores from ice sheets, specifically as glacial stages end, and it's clear the initial warming was due to astronomical cycles.
That warming drove CO2 out of oceans.
This CO2 then boosted the warming - most of the warming that changes glacial stages into interglacials comes from that CO2 in the second phase.
The current situation is different, because most of the extra CO2 now comes from burning carbon-rich fuels.
We're not currently coming out of a glacial stage, and the astronomical cycles are in a different phase at present.
You need to look at different geological contexts.
When igneous activity heated up coal seams in the end-Permian event, the extra CO2 produced by the process caused global warming and ocean acidification. 
There's an interesting paper on that -
"Initial pulse of Siberian Traps sills as the trigger of the end-Permian mass extinction" - Burgess et al, 2017.
Events like the end-Permian, the PETM, the Toarcian, and the ETM2 are seen in the geochemical record as negative carbon isotope excursions.
Sudden releases of sequestered carbon, always associated with global warming and extinction events of varying severity.
The best outline of what's coming that I've seen is in a particular paper -
"A human-induced hothouse climate?" - Kidder & Worsley, 2011', u'recommendation_count': u'19', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1519761500000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'astronomical cycles', u'effect': u'the initial warming was'}, {u'cause': u'most of the extra co2 now comes from burning carbon rich fuels', u'effect': u'the current situation is different'}, {u'cause': u'the extra co2 produced by the process', u'effect': u'global warming and ocean acidification'}], u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'112817690', u'id': u'112818185', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bluecloud', u'text': u'And so it goes.

I choose life, but we're in this together. BQSTART
Now consider Earth's climate history. These curves for global temperature, atmospheric CO2 and sea level were derived from ocean cores and Antarctic ice cores, from ocean sediments and snowflakes that piled up year after year over 800,000 years forming a two-mile thick ice sheet. As you see, there's a high correlation between temperature, CO2 and sea level. Careful examination shows that the temperature changes slightly lead the CO2 changes by a few centuries. Climate change deniers like to use this fact to confuse and trick the public by saying, "Look, the temperature causes CO2 to change, not vice versa." But that lag is exactly what is expected. 
09:20Small changes in Earth's orbit that occur over tens to hundreds of thousands of years alter the distribution of sunlight on Earth. When there is more sunlight at high latitudes in summer, ice sheets melt. Shrinking ice sheets make the planet darker, so it absorbs more sunlight and becomes warmer. A warmer ocean releases CO2, just as a warm Coca-Cola does. And more CO2 causes more warming. So CO2, methane, and ice sheets were feedbacks that amplified global temperature change causing these ancient climate oscillations to be huge, even though the climate change was initiated by a very weak forcing.
10:07The important point is that these same amplifying feedbacks will occur today. The physics does not change. As Earth warms, now because of extra CO2 we put in the atmosphere, ice will melt, and CO2 and methane will be released by warming ocean and melting permafrost. While we can't say exactly how fast these amplifying feedbacks will occur, it is certain they will occur, unless we stop the warming. There is evidence that feedbacks are already beginning. Precise measurements by GRACE, the gravity satellite, reveal that both Greenland and Antarctica are now losing mass, several hundred cubic kilometers per year. And the rate has accelerated since the measurements began nine years ago. Methane is also beginning to escape from the permafrost.
BQEND

description: Record warmth in the Arctic this month could yet prove to be a freak occurrence, but experts warn the warming event is unprecedented
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Record warmth in the Arctic this month could yet prove to be a freak occurrence, but experts warn the warming event is unprecedented
og_fields.og:title: Arctic warming: scientists alarmed by 'crazy' temperature rises
text:
An alarming heatwave in the sunless winter Arctic is causing blizzards in Europe and forcing scientists to reconsider even their most pessimistic forecasts of climate change.
Although it could yet prove to be a freak event, the primary concern is that global warming is eroding the polar vortex, the powerful winds that once insulated the frozen north.
The north pole gets no sunlight until March, but an influx of warm air has pushed temperatures in Siberia up by as much as 35C above historical averages this month. Greenland has already experienced 61 hours above freezing in 2018 - more than three times as many hours as in any previous year.
Seasoned observers have described what is happening as “crazy,” “weird,” and “simply shocking”.
“This is an anomaly among anomalies. It is far enough outside the historical range that it is worrying – it is a suggestion that there are further surprises in store as we continue to poke the angry beast that is our climate,” said Michael Mann, director of the Earth System Science Center at Pennsylvania State University. “The Arctic has always been regarded as a bellwether because of the vicious circle that amplify human-caused warming in that particular region. And it is sending out a clear warning.” 
Although most of the media headlines in recent days have focused on Europe’s unusually cold weather in a jolly tone, the concern is that this is not so much a reassuring return to winters as normal, but rather a displacement of what ought to be happening farther north.
At the world’s most northerly land weather station - Cape Morris Jesup at the northern tip of Greenland – recent temperatures have been, at times, warmer than London and Zurich, which are thousands of miles to the south. Although the recent peak of 6.1C on Sunday was not quite a record, but on the previous two occasions (2011 and 2017) the highs lasted just a few hours before returning closer to the historical average. Last week there were 10 days above freezing for at least part of the day at this weather station, just 440 miles from the north pole. 
“Spikes in temperature are part of the normal weather patterns – what has been unusual about this event is that it has persisted for so long and that it has been so warm,” said Ruth Mottram of the Danish Meteorological Institute. “Going back to the late 1950s at least we have never seen such high temperatures in the high Arctic.”
The cause and significance of this sharp uptick are now under scrutiny. Temperatures often fluctuate in the Arctic due to the strength or weakness of the polar vortex, the circle of winds – including the jetstream – that help to deflect warmer air masses and keep the region cool. As this natural force field fluctuates, there have been many previous temperature spikes, which make historical charts of Arctic winter weather resemble an electrocardiogram.
But the heat peaks are becoming more frequent and lasting longer – never more so than this year. “In 50 years of Arctic reconstructions, the current warming event is both the most intense and one of the longest-lived warming events ever observed during winter,” said Robert Rohde, lead scientist of Berkeley Earth, a non-profit organisation dedicated to climate science.
The question now is whether this signals a weakening or collapse of the polar vortex, the circle of strong winds that keep the Arctic cold by deflecting other air masses. The vortex depends on the temperature difference between the Arctic and mid-latitudes, but that gap is shrinking because the pole is warming faster than anywhere on Earth. While average temperatures have increased by about 1C, the warming at the pole – closer to 3C – is melting the ice mass. According to Nasa, Arctic sea ice is now declining at a rate of 13.2% per decade, leaving more open water and higher temperatures.
Some scientists speak of a hypothesis known as “warm Arctic, cold continents” as the polar vortex becomes less stable - sucking in more warm air and expelling more cold fronts, such as those currently being experienced in the UK and northern Europe. Rohde notes that this theory remains controversial and is not evident in all climate models, but this year’s temperature patterns have been consistent with that forecast.
Longer term, Rohde expects more variation. “As we rapidly warm the Arctic, we can expect that future years will bring us even more examples of unprecedented weather.” 
Jesper Theilgaard, a meteorologist with 40 years’ experience and founder of website Climate Dissemination, said the recent trends are outside previous warming events. “No doubt these warming events bring trouble to the people and the nature. Shifting rain and snow – melt and frost make the surface icy and therefore difficult for animals to find anything to eat. Living conditions in such shifting weather types are very difficult.”
Others caution that it is premature to see this as a major shift away from forecasts. “The current excursions of 20C or more above average experienced in the Arctic are almost certainly mostly due to natural variability,” said Zeke Hausfather of Berkeley Earth. “While they have been boosted by the underlying warming trend, we don’t have any strong evidence that the factors driving short-term Arctic variability will increase in a warming world. If anything, climate models suggest the opposite is true, that high-latitude winters will be slightly less variable as the world warms.” 
Although it is too soon to know whether overall projections for Arctic warming should be changed, the recent temperatures add to uncertainty and raises the possibility of knock-on effects accelerating climate change. 
“This is too short-term an excursion to say whether or not it changes the overall projections for Arctic warming,” says Mann. “But it suggests that we may be underestimating the tendency for short-term extreme warming events in the Arctic. And those initial warming events can trigger even greater warming because of the ‘feedback loops’ associated with the melting of ice and the potential release of methane (a very strong greenhouse gas).”
